Foreword
This concluding volume of my autobiographical trilogy Garry Kasparov on Cany Kasparov 
contains one hundred of the most memorable games and endings played during the 12 
years after my withdrawal from FIDE (1993-2005), and also a selection of my best games 
from simultaneous displays with professionals, as well as from rapid and blitz tournaments.
As regards drama and the intensity of events, this last period of my career was not inferior 
to all its preceding stages taken together. Whereas earlier the graph of my tournament 
successes, with slight exceptions, invariably proceeded upwards, now it more resembled a 
sinusoid. There were various reasons for the slumps in my play, but the chief of these was the 
psychological discomfort caused by the almost constant opposition with FIDE.
After winning matches under the aegis of the Professional Chess Association (PCA), 
against Short (1993) and Anand (1995), I remained the ‘historic’ champion. But Karpov, after 
winning his match against Timman (1993) became the FIDE version of the champion and 
then, after defeating Kamsky (1996), he retained his title. The situation at the chess summit 
became complicated, and I even had to explain to the public: ‘I am the world champion. Not a 
version, but the chess world champion!’
The arguments should finally have been resolved by a unification match, envisaged in a 
declaration of cooperation between FIDE and the PCA. The guarantor of a sixth (!) Kasparov- 
Karpov match was the new FIDE president Kirsan llyumzhinov, who in August 1996 signed a 
preliminary agreement with the contestants. The chess world was on the verge of unifica­
tion. But instead of this, breaking with an historic tradition, llyumzhinov began staging mass 
world championships on a knock-out system.
Although at that time I won a number of notable tournaments, including Las Palmas 1996 
and Linares 1997, the time had come to again defend my title. After the collapse of the match 
with Karpov and the departure from chess of the powerful PCA sponsor - the Intel company 
- I was forced myself to find a worthy match opponent. In February 1998 Senor Rentero, the 
permanent organiser of the tournaments in Linares, came to the rescue. He suggested hold-
5

ing an Anand-Kramnik candidates match in the early summer, a world championship match 
in the autumn, and then setting up a full qualifying cycle. Alas, this plan was also wrecked. 
First Anand refused to play, and when his replacement Shirov defeated Kramnik, money 
could not be found for my match with Shirov...
But the intensive preparations for a world championship match were not wasted and led 
to a new upsurge in my play in 1999-2000. This period became the second peak of my career 
(the first, I should remind you, was in 1988-1990). I won six super-toumaments in succession 
and achieved the unprecedented rating of 2851 - despite rating inflation, this world record 
stood for 13 years.
Early in 2000 English organisers suggested holding a world championship match in the 
autumn between me and Anand. However, Vishy again declined (it would appear that our 
1995 match had traumatised him psychologically), and I chose the most difficult opponent - 
Kramnik, who shared victory with me in Linares 2000. Kramnik fully exploited this chance 
opportunity: by winning the match he became the 14th world champion.
After this I scored another four tournament victories, twice finishing ahead of Kramnik (I 
beat him in Astana 2001), and I established another world record - ten super-tournament 
victories in succession. In my view, Kramnik was morally obliged to sign an agreement to a 
return match. But apparently back in November 2000 he decided for himself: he would not 
play Kasparov again for the world championship!
Particular hopes were raised by a resolution to unite the chess world, signed on 6 May 
2002 in Prague by the FIDE president llyumzhinov together with the 13th and 14th champi­
ons. FIDE became the sole legal holder of the title of world champion and the only organisa­
tion that could hold official world championships, and in return it approved a unification 
plan, according to which Kramnik would play a match with the winner of a qualifying tour­
nament in Dortmund 2002, the FIDE knock-out world champion Ponomariov would play 
Kasparov, the No.l in the rating list, and ‘the winner of these two matches would meet in a 
unifying match for the world championship in October-November 2003’.
Alas, these efforts were in vain: first my match with Ponomariov collapsed, and then also 
with the next knock-out champion Kasimdzhanov. I was left in a suspended state and I lost 
two years of normal life. But llyumzhinov again showed that he keenly perceived the mood of 
the chess elite and officials, who did not want to give me a chance to regain the title. After 
losing my goal, I began seriously thinking about giving up professional chess. And I decided 
on this at the age of 41, after victories in the 2004 Russian Championship Super-Final and 
Linares 2005.
Since the times of the GMA I had been dreaming of organising tournament life and the 
world championship far more professionally than it is done by FIDE. But my attempts to 
unite the leading players failed because their sense of cooperative solidarity always receded 
in the face of internal disagreements. As a result, despite enormous efforts, I was not in fact 
able to repair the mistake of 1993.
I should like to express my gratitude to my long-standing trainer Alexander Shakarov, and 
also to the chess compilers Vladislav Novikov and Yakov Zusmanovich, for their help in prepar­
ing the manuscript for publication.
Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three

Chapter One
Short, Anand and Las Palmas
Match with Short
World Championship Match Kasparov - 
Short (London, 7 September - 21 October 
1993) - 12V2-TA.
On 23 March 1993 an abrupt zigzag in 
chess history occurred: the FIDE president 
Campomanes, after depriving me and Nigel 
Short of the rights of champion and chal­
lenger, announced the urgent staging of a 
match ‘for the world championship’ be­
tween the finalist and a semi-finalist of the 
previous qualifying cycle - Jan Timman and 
Anatoly Karpov.
Of the leading grandmasters, the only one 
who openly condemned this unprecedented 
decision was Vassily Ivanchuk: on 9 May he 
sent a letter to FIDE, in which he emphasised 
that he considered it unlawful to stage a 
match for the world title between Timman 
and Karpov, since in the qualifying cycle they 
had both lost their matches to Short, and in 
addition the other semi-finalist in the cycle - 
Yusupov, who had lost to Timman - had 
completely equal rights with Karpov. ‘The
loss of a match to Short should not give the 
right to participate in a match for the world 
championship or other privileges’, declared 
Ivanchuk, who suggested that the cham­
pion’s title should be left vacant and a new 
qualifying cycle held. The 12 winners of the 
July Interzonal Tournament in Biel should be 
joined by Karpov and Yusupov, and the 
seven winners of the matches between them 
should then by joined by Timman. However, 
as the press reported, ‘Ivanchuk's proposal 
was rejected by FIDE because it did not want 
to lose the money from the organisation of 
the Timman-Karpov match’.
Meanwhile it became known that in the 
autumn in London, under the aegis of the 
PCA and The Times newspaper, a Kasparov- 
Short match for the world title would be 
held, with a prize fund of 2V2 million dollars.
I began a period of purposeful preparation, 
in the course of which I played just four 
official games - for Auxerre in the French 
Club Championship (+2=2; May 1993).
For me this was a terribly difficult time: 
there was the war with FIDE, organizational
7

Carry Kasparov on Carry Kasparov: Part Three
problems with the PCA, the future of which 
still looked very obscure, the split with the 
Russian Chess Federation, caused by the 
political crisis in the country, and serious 
family discords (in the end I separated from 
my first wife, and she and her parents with 
our daughter Polina left for the USA). It was 
impossible to invent a greater number of 
problems before a match. My nerves were on 
edge, and my mental state left much to be 
desired, but I believed that I would be able to 
beat Short, since the score in our previous 
meetings with the ‘classical’ time control 
was +10-1=4 in my favour.
The first lengthy training session took 
place in the summer on the Croatian coast, 
the first time I had been there (and after that 
I went there every year, trying to recreate the 
atmosphere 
of 
the 
irretrievably 
lost 
Zagulba). Apart from my mother, with me 
were my chief trainer Sergey Makarychev, 
Alexander Beliavsky, Zurab Azmaiparashvili 
and Alexander Shakarov - together with 
press attache Vladimir Dvorkovich, it was 
they who later comprised my team in Lon­
don, the first two being my official seconds. 
We worked quite productively, although the 
greater part of what we found in our open­
ing preparations came in useful to me only 
after the match.
With White it was planned to alternate l 
e4 and l  d4. After l  e4, of course, we studied 
both of Short’s favourite replies - l...e6 2 d4 
d5 (with the variation 3 £>c3 -&b4 4 e5 c5 5 
a3 .&.XC3+ 6 bxc3 and ^ 4 )  and l...e5 2 £>f3 
£>c6, after which both 3 -&b5 and 3 d4 were 
prepared. And after l  d4 we looked at the 
Queen’s Gambit and the Slav Defence, and 
less at the Nimzo-lndian, where I had my 
own preparations in the set-up with 4 Vic2 
(cf. Game No.4).
Fot Black, anticipating l  e4 and guided by 
the principle Heave well alone’, we analysed
only the Najdorf Variation of the Sicilian 
Defence - but not those variations which 
occurred in the match! Here, unfortunately, I 
lacked flexibility, as also later in my 2000 
match with Kramnik, whereas in the 1995 
match with Anand I had in reserve the 
‘Dragon’, which came as an unpleasant 
surprise for my opponent (Game No.2l).
At the end of August, now at a training 
session in Podolsk on the outskirts of Mos­
cow, I looked a little at the French Defence 
with Lputian (cf. Game No.10), at the 7~Wb6 
variation in the Najdorf with Magerramov, 
and I met with Geller, who gave me a num­
ber of pieces of valuable opening advice - in 
particular, how to advantageously avoid the 
sharp Marshall Attack in the Ruy Lopez 
which was employed by Short (cf. Game 
No.2).
This match was splendidly organised and 
was even broadcast on TV. Therefore for the 
first time in the history of world champion­
ship matches the contestants played strictly 
three times a week, without any time-outs 
and with a six-hour time control: two hours 
for 40 moves and an hour for the next 20 
(followed by an adjournment, but things did 
not come to that). Also for the first time, 
immediately after a game the players were 
obliged to give a short press conference 
(although the loser had the right not to take 
part). The chief arbiters were Yuri Averbakh 
(Russia) and Carlos Falcon (Spain).
We played in the Savoy Theatre, and my 
team and I lived ten minutes’ drive from 
there - in a house on Chester Terrace, close 
to Regent’s Park. The opening ceremony and 
the drawing of lots, together with a charity 
lunch, took place in the restaurant adjoining 
the theatre, Simpson’s-in-the-StTand, where 
in 1851 the first international tournament 
in the history of chess was played. Within 
these walls Morphy, Steinitz, Chigorin,
8

Short, Anand and Las Palmas
Lasker, Capablanca and Alekhine all per­
formed... It was here that the famous ‘im­
mortal’ Anderssen-Kieseritzky game was 
played, and 142 years later it was repro­
duced by grandmasters Keene and Speel- 
man, robed in 19th century costumes (the 
former was one of the match organisers, and 
the latter, along with Kavalek, the chal­
lenger’s official second).
In the first game I drew the white pieces. 
The symbolic first move in the match - 1 e4 
- was made by Peter Stothard, the editor-in- 
chief of The Times. Then he pressed the clock 
button with his palm, and the game began. 
Short chose l...e5, immediately threatening 
the Marshall Attack. After replying as ad­
vised by Geller - 8 a4 (cf. Game No.2, note to 
Black’s 8th move), gradually I completely 
outplayed my opponent, but in a time 
scramble, with more time on my clock, I 
missed a win on the 35th and 36th moves. 
The position became equal, but Black was a 
pawn up, and to be on the safe side I offered 
a draw on the 38th move. In the heat of the 
moment Short declined - and a move later 
he lost on time! This dramatic start greatly 
influenced the further course of the match - 
it was not without reason that at the end I 
was presented with two elegant chairs, 
white and black, on the backs of which were 
carved the final position from the first game.
In the second game Short played 6 JLgS 
against the Najdorf Variation, and to start 
with I employed a bit of cunning - I trans­
posed into a comparatively rare variation of 
the Rauzer Attack (cf. Game No.l, note to 
Black’s 6th move), confidently neutralised 
my opponent’s slight initiative and in a 
sharp time-trouble battle I gained a draw. I 
could have done with more such cunning in 
the 2000 match with Kramnik.
The third game was again an ‘anti- 
Marshall’, again I managed to outplay my
opponent (cf. Game No.2, note to Black's 9th 
move), and again I blundered in his time- 
trouble - I missed a win on the 27th move, 
allowing Black equalizing counterplay, and 
Short almost saved himself, but he stumbled 
on the 3lst move and after desperate resis­
tance he nevertheless lost.
The score became iVi-Vi in my favour. But 
Short, seeing that I was also making mis­
takes, did not become depressed and was 
hoping to pull one back in the very next 
game.

accomplished a competitive feat, by defeat­

in the candidates cycle, in the world cham­

I remember that, when Patrick Wolff ar­
rived in London after the fourth game, he 
said to me: ‘Well, that’s it, the match is over. 
Now we will work on finding a more worthy 
opponent for you next time.’ He had already 
begun helping Vishy Anand, who many 
regarded as the favourite in the forthcoming 
cycle.
However, Short had not given up hope, 
sensing that I was psychologically unpre­
pared for a difficult battle. In the fifth game 
for the sake of variety I played 1 d4, but on 
encountering a novelty in the Nimzo-lndian 
Defence I did not find the strongest con­
tinuation and had to be satisfied with a 
quick draw (cf. Came N0.4, note to White's 
llth  move). Nigel was very satisfied at 
having solved all his problems in 11 minutes, 
whereas on my 18 moves I spent 1 hour, 29 
minutes!
Short also demonstrated the quality of his 
opening preparation in the sixth game, in 
which he sprung a fresh surprise on me - for 
the first time he played 6 i.c4 e6 7 i-b3 
against the Najdorf. Before the match we

The most surprising thing is that with the 
8 a4 plan I scored 3 out of 3 and effectively 
won the match, although my entire prepara­

venerable grandmaster: ‘You should play 
£)bd2!’. But it was during the course of the 
match that I had to delve into the subtleties 
of this set-up. Indeed, from c3 all the same 
the knight has to move (after ...bs-b4) to e2 
and then to g3, whereas after £)bd2-fl it can 
go to both g3 and e3. In addition, on fl the 
knight does not hinder White so much as it 
does on e2, and there is the useful develop­
ing move ^.d2l. Subsequent practice con­
firmed that Geller was strategically correct.

A very nervy game and in its way a typical 
one: Short regularly ‘cracked’ in the time- 
troubles that pursued him. Nevertheless, at 
the end of this clash he declared: 'For the first 
time in the match Kasparov won thanks to 
his own strong play, and not my blunders.' 
And the press commented on the pretty 
finish: 'Garry, not suspecting that Princess 
Diana was present in the royal box, produced 
a truly royal game’.
The score rose to SVi-iyi. In the eighth 
game, to his credit, Nigel did not lose heart 
and continued fighting in the fearless man­
ner of the 19th century.

6 i.g5 h6 7 ±h4 c5 (7-.g5 - Game No.63 in 
Part II of Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov) 
8 dxc5 g5 9 iLg3 £se4
After weakening his pawns in the centre 
and on the kingside, Black immediately 
attacks the c3-point. White can parry the 
threats in one of two ways: either launch a 
counter-attack, even at the cost of material 
sacrifices, seeing as the black king is poorly 
covered, or exchange Black’s active pieces 
and exploit his pawn weaknesses in the 
endgame. The variations of both plans are 
closely interwoven in the calculations, and in 
avoiding the first one can end up in the 
second, and vice versa. In the present game 
White carhes out the second plan, the 
overall drawback to which is that the great 
simplification often ends in a draw.

duel with Spassky (Game N0.65 in Part II of 
Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov).

Although not without its mistakes, this 
was a very interesting game. Psychologically 
it set the seal on the match: the score be­
came 7-2, or 5-0 with four draws. Short 
found himself in an even worse situation 
than I did in my first match with Karpov 
(1984/85): in that match the winner was to 
be the first to win six games, not counting 
draws, whereas in this one each draw 
brought the leader closer to his goal. Never­
theless, the subsequent struggle in the 
match was quite tense, and I had to solve 
numerous problems.
Already in the tenth game Short was 
closer than ever to a win, although he chose 
an incorrect opening variation (cf. Game 
No.3, note to White’s 9th move). After my 
error on the 14th move he flamboyantly 
sacrificed his queen and developed a dan­
gerous initiative, and after 28...1i rxh2? 29 
£sc6 he obtained an absolutely won position, 
but in his usual desperate time-trouble he 
allowed me to escape in what turned out to 
be one of the most fascinating games of the 
match. When he was signing the score- 
sheets, Nigel could hardly hold back the 
tears...
In the 11th game I played the Scotch 
Game for the first time, employed an inter­
esting novelty and reached an obviously 
better endgame (cf. Game No.14, note to 
Black’s 10th move), but then I squandered 
my advantage, almost overstepped the 
mark, and after adventures reached the 
haven of a draw.
Also typical of the entire match was the 
fighting 12th game, where an unusual 
position with a disrupted material balance 
occurred.

Short, Anand and Las Palmas
scored a sixth win, and had it been an

shortest in history. But here ‘on my last legs’ 
a further five games had to be played. In the

and the remaining games, also by no means 
peaceful, ended in draws.
The match result ll'h-T h speaks for it­
self, but Short was proud of the 5-5 score in 
the last ten games and said that he was 
confident about the future. However, the 
score in our subsequent ‘classical’ encoun­

Soon Karpov won the ‘match of the un­
derstudies’ against Timman (l21/2-81/2), and 
for the first time in the entire history of 
world championships there was a duumvi­
rate at the chess summit: my historic title 
was opposed by the official one.
New Test
International Tournament in Linares (22 
February - 15 March 1994): 1. Karpov - 11 
out of 13; 2-3. Kasparov and Shirov - 8V2; 4. 
Bareev - 7V2; 5-6. Lautier and Kramnik - 7; 7- 
9. Kamsky, Anand and Topalov - 6V2; 10. 
Ivanchuk - 6; 11. Gelfand - 5V2; 12. Illescas - 
4V2; 13. J.Polgar - 4; 14. Beliavsky - 2.
On returning to Moscow from a lengthy 
tour of South America prior to the New Year, 
I promptly plunged into the maelstrom of 
chess life and began preparing for the new 
season - not only as a player, but also as an 
organiser. The contesting of the world 
championship between 1993 and 1995 was 
undoubtedly the most tense and unusual in 
chess history. The challengers fought simul­
taneously in two series, to qualify via the 
PCA line for a match with me, and via the 
FIDE line for a match with Karpov, although 
for greater legitimacy he was obliged to join 
in at the semi-final stage.
An enormous achievement of the Profes­
sional Chess Association was the two-year 
contract with the Intel Corporation, which 
became the main PCA sponsor. This enabled 
us to stage both an unprecedented series of 
rapid-play knock-out tournaments, the 
Intel World Chess Grand Prix (Moscow - 
New York - London - Paris), and also a 
number of classical chess super-tourna­
ments, but above all - a complete world 
championship cycle. Our qualifying tour­
nament (Groningen, December 1993) was 
an unprecedentedly strong ‘Swiss’, and the 
prize fund here was three times greater 
than at the FIDE Interzonal Tournament 
(Biel, July 1993). The favourites in both 
cycles were the now experienced Anand 
and the rapidly improving Kamsky and 
Kramnik (Ivanchuk did not qualify for the 
Candidates in Biel and he did not play in 
Groningen).
It was at this unusual moment that Kar­
pov and I met at the regular super- 
tournament in Linares. For me this was a 
new test: on this occasion I faced the rivalry 
not simply of an ex-world champion, whom I 
had defeated in an official match for the title 
(1990), but of a newly-fledged FIDE cham­
pion. Of course, Karpov was experiencing a 
mental boost and was burning with a desire 
to demonstrate his strength. Especially as for 
many years he had been quite unable to win 
in Linares and, moreover, in 1992 and 1993 I 
had finished first with a score of 10 out of 
13, while Karpov had finished behind me, 
respectively, by 2V2 and l ’/i points. Now he 
was eager for revenge. In addition, he was 
openly supported by the organisers, by the 
leaders of the Spanish Federation, and by 
television and the press. The psychological 
atmosphere at the tournament was excep­
tionally difficult for me, but that was some­
thing I was accustomed to.
31

Carry Kasparov on Carry Kasparov: Part Three
An important role, as it later transpired, 
was played by the drawing of lots, which 
placed us alongside each other: I drew num­
ber 10, and Karpov ll. I remember being 
pleased that I would have White against him, 
but the experienced arbiter Vladimir Dvork­
ovich commented: ‘It’s too early to be rejoic­
ing! All the contestants, except one (Lautier), 
will play the two of you in succession - first 
you, and then Karpov. Can you imagine what 
state they will be in?’ I did not attach any 
importance to his words, but they proved to 
be prophetic. Averbakh: ‘It is quite possible 
that the pairings were the secret of such a fine 
result by Karpov: after their games with 
Kasparov, all the players were pretty ex­
hausted when they came to play him.’ How­
ever, this alone can hardly explain the miracle 
which occurred or the staggering good 
fortune which accompanied the FIDE cham­
pion right from the start.
‘One’s mood is affected by luck’, Karpov 
was to say after the tournament. This 
thought was confirmed in the very first 
round, when with Black in a time scramble 
he snatched victory ‘out of nothing’ against 
Lautier (extracts of this and other games by 
Karpov are given in Part V of My Great 
Predecessors). That day I defeated Bareev 
with Black in a Benko Gambit.
In the second round I quite cleanly out­
played lllescas in a Tarrasch, while Karpov 
‘took over’ Bareev from me and, knowing his 
attachment to the French Defence, remem­
bered his old love - 1 e4, and initiated his 
favourite play against an isolated pawn. 
Bareev equalised, but five moves before the 
time control, now in a dead-drawn ending, 
he inexplicably blundered a rook and a mate 
in one move!
So, we started with two wins and in the 
third round we both had Black: after a com­
plicated battle I made a draw in my first duel
with Topalov, but Karpov played the opening 
badly against lllescas and stood clearly worse 
- when his opponent suddenly ‘cooperated’ 
by allowing his queen to be trapped in the 
middle of the board. 3 out of 3!
In the fourth round I managed to beat 
Vassily Ivanchuk in impressive style. Our 
games were always gripping, and with 
White between Moscow 1988 and Linares 
1994 I contrived to win six times in a row. 
And each time I had to solve a difficult 
problem in my choice of opening strategy, 
since the Ukrainian grandmaster’s reper­
toire is extraordinarily broad and anything 
can be expected of him.

Despite the mutual mistakes, an interest­
ing game, rich in adventures. Immediately 
after it Judit and I sat down to analyse 
variations. Journalists and photographers 
crowded round our table, and they were 
joined by Judit’s elder sister Susan and her 
mother Klara. And, according to the press, 
after a lengthy analysis everyone departed 
content.
I now had 4'h out of 5. But that day Kar­
pov received a valuable present from Ivan­
chuk, who employed a novelty with White, 
obtained a favourable position and an hour 
in hand on the clock, but suddenly ‘floun­
dered’, blundered an important pawn on the 
28th move and promptly resigned. 5 out of 
5! It was then that the anxious thought first 
crept into my mind: suppose this continues?
In the sixth round I again had Black and 
with difficulty I saved half a point in a skir­
mish with Gelfand, while Karpov again 
remembered about 1 e4 and methodically 
outplayed Polgar: l...c5 2 c3l? e6 3 d4 d5 4 
exd5 exd5 5 £tf3 £k6 6 Jk.b5 c4?! 7 £Je5l ^ 6  
8 &xc6+ bxc6 9 0-0 JLd6 10 b3l, etc.
Meanwhile, the Spanish newspaper ABC 
published a report by Roman Toran (a well- 
known FIDE official, and a colleague of Cam- 
pomanes and Karpov), in which he claimed 
that in the game with Polgar I had supposedly 
made the move 36...£k5, and then replaced it 
with another. This had allegedly been estab­
lished by examining the TV footage - Spanish 
TV had filmed the game.
Vladimir Dvorkovich: ‘Here were given the 
words of the chief arbiter Carlos Falcon, who 
observed the time scramble in this game: “At
no point did Kasparov break contact with the 
knight. And Polgar did not appeal to me." But 
this ‘news’ also found its way into other 
organs of the press. They began saying that 
journalists were about to be shown the video 
recording of this episode. A scandal blew up. 
Here Luis Rentero, who had also watched the 
game, acted resolutely: he put out a press­
release, in which he stated that a number of 
unscrupulous journalists were inflating a 
made-up episode, that this was damaging 
the tournament's prestige and that he would 
not allow any demonstrations of the video 
tape. Things immediately quietened down! I, 
however, was shown the video tape. An 
examination of it at normal speed does not 
demonstrate anything. When slowed down (I 
looked at the tape several times at various 
speeds) one can see the fingers parting, but it 
is impossible to establish that the piece was 
completely released.'
The psychological attack on me had not 
only immediate, but also long-term conse­
quences. A recent pronouncement by Evgeny 
Bareev, one of the players in that tourna­
ment, is typical: 'In his time Kasparov said: if 
you have slightly let go of the piece, this does 
not count. Well, for him it does not count. 
That is, his 'code of ethics’ allows him to take 
a move back. It is good that the cameras were 
filming and the video was later shown. Since 
then I have never believed Kasparov.’
It was on this terrible background that in 
the seventh round I had White against 
Karpov. I was on 5 out of 6, but my eternal 
opponent had 6 out of 6! Everyone realised 
that this was the decisive game of the tour­
nament. Before it there was a free day, and 
Sergey Makarychev and I spent a long time 
racking our brains over how on this occasion 
to try and breach the Caro-Kann Defence. In 
it I twice won against Karpov in Amsterdam 
(1988), and twice in Linares (1992 and 2001),
42

Short, Anand and Las Palmas
but on this occasion, in 1994, something 
went wrong, and evidently I burned myself 
out even while preparing for the game. I find 
it hard to remember another similar prepa­
ration for a game, after which, playing 
White, by the 13th move I already found 
myself in such an unpleasant position. I was 
obliged to tTy and save myself - as it is said, 
a game where things just didn't happen 
(Game No.39 in Kasparov vs. Karpov 1988- 
2009).
Averbakh: ‘Whereas in the previous two 
Linares tournaments it was his victories over 
Karpov that, to a large extent, determined 
Kasparov’s ultimate success, this time it was a 
case of ‘diamond cut diamond’: the game 
ended in a draw, and the gap remained 
unchanged.’
In the eighth round I drew with Black in a 
very complicated game with Shirov, but the 
inspired, leader, also with Black, outplayed 
Gelfand in time-trouble, although initially 
the latter gained an obvious advantage, on 
the 24th move he could have set his oppo­
nent very difficult problems, and on the 37th 
he could at least have maintained equality. 
7V2 out of 8! I was now one and a half points 
behind.
In the ninth round I played the 19-year- 
old Gata Kamsky, against whom things 
usually went quite well for me. By that time 
he (like both Anand and Kramnik) was 
already a quarter-finalist in the candidates 
matches of both series, PCA and FIDE.

1-0
A short but interesting battle. I now had 7 
out of 9 - more points than in all my previ­
ous victorious tournaments in Linares. But 
on this occasion I merely reduced the gap 
behind the leader: Karpov was unable to win 
a superior ending against Shirov and was on 
‘only’ 8 out of 9.
I still had to play Kramnik, Anand, Be- 
liavsky and Lautier. As in previous years, I 
was pinning my hopes on a powerful finish, 
but here there was the dreadful tournament 
atmosphere, apparently in keeping with the 
ideas of my enemies about how the official
FIDE world champion should be helped. No 
sooner had the talk of my ‘released hand’ in 
the game with Polgar begun to die away, 
when persistent rumours began circulating 
about how Kramnik and Beliavsky were 
bound to ‘throw’ their games against me. 
This had never happened in my life! All this 
preyed hugely on my nerves, and in the end I 
cracked under the pressure.
In the tenth round - a rare instance in this 
tournament - fortune turned its back on my 
rival: after reaching an endgame against 
Kamsky with an extra pawn and winning 
chances, he threw away his advantage with 
his hasty 33rd move. Alas, this did not help 
me: aiming at all costs to win with Black 
against Kramnik, I played the King’s Indian 
Defence too riskily, overstepped the mark, 
came under attack in the endgame, and lost. 
It was with this game that my problems with 
Kramnik began: that same year I twice lost 
to him in PCA rapid tournaments - on 22 
April in Moscow and on 30 June in New York. 
Later, it is true, I began recouping my losses, 
but the complex of a difficult opponent had 
emerged.
The leader was again l'/i points ahead, 
and now there were just three rounds before 
the finish. My last hope was the llth  round, 
in which Karpov played Kramnik, and I 
played Vishy Anand. In this game I was 
successful.

I reached 8 out of 11. But Karpov won in 
good style against Kramnik, who had not yet 
regained his composure after his game with 
me, and was now on 9V2 out of ll! Aver­
bakh: ‘The question of first place was essen­
tially decided by Kramnik: after winning 
against Kasparov, in the next round he lost 
to Karpov’ (Game No.103 in Part V of My 
Great Predecessors). At this the race con­
cluded.
In the 12th round I had a highly painful 
game with Beliavsky, who performed ex­
tremely badly in the tournament: because of 
the talk about the ‘throwing’ of the game, I 
was by definition, so to speak, unable to win. 
This draw concluded our meetings in ‘classi­
cal’ play (+11-2=14). That day Karpov drew 
with Anand, and in the final, 13th round he 
crushed Beliavsky in a Catalan. But I, having 
completely lost my motivation, recklessly 
attacked with White against the 20-year-old 
tournament debutant Joel Lautier and 
resigned as early as the 30th move, allowing 
Shirov to catch me.
It is unlikely that anyone expected such a 
stunning victory for Karpov. Everything 
worked out for him, he won from almost any 
position, and in the end he achieved one of 
the most impressive tournament results in 
chess history (+9=4). When I had not yet 
cooled down after the battle, I said: ‘In my 
view, this competitive triumph was not 
supported by outstanding play. I have seen 
Karpov play better. Now he has found an 
optimal manner of play, which by virtue of 
his personal and playing qualities enables 
him to achieve the maximum results with 
the minimum expenditure of nervous 
energy. A kind of apotheosis of pragmatism! 
On this occasion I played badly, but my
52

Short, Anand and Las Palmas
attitude to this is simple: I will endeavour to 
play well in the next tournament.’
But for this I needed to replenish my store, 
firstly, of nervous energy, and, secondly, of 
opening ideas. It was after Linares 1994 that 
I sensed for the first time that my opening 
knowledge, accumulated in the 1980s and 
early 1990s, was largely exhausted, and that 
a leap to a new, qualitatively different level 
was needed. The young generation was now 
looking at other openings! Thus for me this 
amazing tournament became a turning- 
point, and its outcome a kind of historic 
punishment for the mistake of 1993-
For Karpov this was undoubtedly the 
"tournament of his life’. After it the FIDE 
champion apparently decided that by now 
he had demonstrated everything to every­
one, and he even made a bold statement in 
the press: ‘Yes, I would like to play another 
match with Kasparov, but now he needs this 
match more than I do.’ Soon Karpov’s tour­
nament successes began to decline and, as 
in the early 1980s, he endeavoured to avoid 
meeting me at the board. But even so I was 
able to tum the tables in Las Palmas 1996 
and Linares 2001.
Soon after my return from Linares a con­
venient opportunity at last presented itself 
for me to make peace with Botvinnik (I should 
remind you that we had had serious ideologi­
cal disagreements). In April 1994 Moscow 
together with the PCA was preparing to stage 
a grandiose festival - the ‘Kremlin stars’ 
rapid-play knock-out tournament. 
How 
honourable and symbolic it would be if the 
chief arbiter of the first super-tournament in 
the Kremlin were to be the great Botvinnik! 
And so with Andrei Makarov, the new Presi­
dent of the Russian Chess Federation, and 
grandmaster Averbakh, the organiser of this 
meeting, I went to see Botvinnik in his office 
on the second floor of the Central Chess Club.
By that time Mikhail Moiseevich’s eye­
sight was very poor, in fact he was almost 
blind: he moved about with the help of his 
nephew. But his mind was completely clear. 
Just as 15-20 years earlier, he knew exactly 
what he wanted and what he didn’t want. 
He listened impassively to our suggestion 
that he should be the chief arbiter of the 
tournament and, after a little thought, he 
rapped out: 'Rapid chess will be the death of 
our game!' Or something of that sort.
I said to him: ‘Mikhail Moiseevich, but this 
form of the game is one that will make it 
more popular...’ But he replied: ‘This will 
cause enormous damage, colossal damage.’ I 
tried again: ‘This is how everyone is playing 
- hundreds of grandmasters. Even Vasily 
Vasilievich is playing in this tournament!’ 
And he in reply: 7 don’t give a damn about 
the opinion of the majority! I am used to 
thinking with my own mind!'
That was Botvinnik to the core. And so we 
left empty-handed. That was my last meet­
ing with the Teacher.
Amsterdam Quartet
Double-Round Match-Toumament in Am­
sterdam (Euwe Memorial, 11-18 May 1994):
1. Kasparov - 4 out of 6; 2. Ivanchuk - 3!/j; 3. 
Timman - 2 Vi; 4. Short - 2.
My first ‘classical’ appearance after 
Linares was in May at the Euwe Memorial in 
Amsterdam. The organisers were intending 
to stage a double-round, four-player match- 
tournament of all the contestants in the 
recent title matches - Kasparov, Short, 
Karpov and Timman! As the press wrote, ‘in 
this case the event would have acquired the 
character of an absolute world champion­
ship - of FIDE and the PCA'. But, alas, after 
his Linares triumph Karpov declined to play 
and was quickly replaced by Ivanchuk - a
53

Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
player with truly champion-like playing 
potential, although without a champion-like 
stability of results.
Over such a short distance - just six 
rounds! - any of my three opponents could 
have been my rival. After obtaining No.l in 
the drawing of lots, at the start, to my dis­
tress, for the first time in my life I was un­
able to beat Ivanchuk with White - a draw 
as early as the 2lst move! Meanwhile, Short 
beat Timman with White and took the lead. 
But the second round, in which I played 
Nigel Short, brought a change of leader. That 
day I was able to make use of something 
from the extensive analytical knowledge 
accumulated for our 1993 match. At the 
time many were surprised by why Short 
avoided his usual French Defence, and at last 
something from the submerged part of the 
iceberg was revealed.

Partial Revenge
Double-Round PCA Super-Tournament in 
Novgorod (11-26 August 1994): 1-2. Kas­
parov and Ivanchuk - 7 out of 10; 3. Kramnik 
- 5; 4-5. Shirov and Short - 4; 6. Bareev - 3.
This was the first time that such a major 
chess event took place in Novgorod - an 
ancient Russian city, situated 500 km. north­
west of Moscow and 200 km. south of St. 
Petersburg. Together with the PCA, the 
organisers produced an optimal type of 
event: six leading grandmasters playing a 
double-round tournament. There were no 
doubts about the participation of Kasparov, 
Short, Ivanchuk and Shirov, but Kramnik 
agreed to play only after his failure in the 
summer Candidates matches, while Kamsky, 
by contrast, declined after his sensational 
match victories over Kramnik and Anand.
Karpov was also invited. The Novgorod 
organisers, armed with a high-powered 
delegation, sought him out in Moscow, but 
despite all their entreaties the FIDE cham­
pion declined the invitation, saying that he 
would not play in the PCA - ‘Kasparov’s 
personal organisation’. As a result Bareev 
became the sixth participant. But in any 
event, for the first time in the history of 
chess tournaments an average rating of 
2700 was exceeded and the 19th category 
achieved!
Despite the traditional training session 
and active relaxation by the sea, this tour­
nament was psychologically difficult for me. 
From the press: 'More often than usual 
Kasparov looked concentrated and detached 
from everything. Not as powerful as before,
there was an energy field surrounding him. It 
was sensed that he desperately needed to win 
the tournament: the world champion was 
clearly unhappy with both his results and his 
play in recent times.’
At the start I managed to win with White 
against Shirov in a rare variation of the 
English Opening - 1 c4 e5 2 £)c3 jLb4 3 £>d5 
&e7 4 d4 d6 5 e4 c6 6 £>xe7WxeT 7 £>e2, etc. 
In the second round came a fighting draw 
with Bareev in a Griinfeld. In the third I 
aimed for revenge against Ivanchuk, who 
had beaten me in Amsterdam; I played l  e4 
and obtained a promising position in a 
Sicilian (cf. Game No.79 in Part II of Carry 
Kasparov on Garry Kasparov, note to Black’s 
n th  move), but I was unable to develop my 
initiative - a draw on the 25th move. We 
both reached 2 out of 3.
In the fourth round, interchanged with 
the fifth to avoid a player having the same 
colour three games in a row, I again had 
White, this time against the. 19-year-old 
Vladimir Kramnik, my ‘1994 bogeyman’. This 
was a crucial game. When I was preparing 
for it I felt very nervous, remembering my 
three recent defeats against Kramnik (in 
Linares, Moscow and New York), but as soon 
as the first few moves were made, the 
concrete chess problems left no place for 
anxiety.

Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
After this spectacular win I reached 3 out 
of 4, but Ivanchuk kept pace, defeating 
Bareev with Black. Then I won with Black 
against Short, and Ivanchuk with White 
against Shirov, and with a score of 4 out 5 
we were confidently leading after the first 
cycle.
In the second half of the tournament the 
FIDE officials Macropulos and Iclicki arrived, 
as well as Makarov, the president of the 
Russian Chess Federation. ‘FIDE - RCF - PCA’ 
discussions began, as well as other prob­
lems, and these affected my play.
In a sharp Sicilian duel with Shirov I was 
the exchange up by the 28th move, but in 
time-trouble by some kind of miracle I 
missed a win. Meanwhile, Ivanchuk drew 
with Kramnik and then with Short. And I, by 
beating Bareev, at last moved half a point 
ahead - 5V2 out of 7! In the eighth round the 
status quo was maintained, as a compli­
cated King’s Indian with Ivanchuk ended in a 
draw. Then in the ninth round I drew with 
Short, after failing to exploit his errors in a 
rook endgame, and in the final, tenth round 
- with Kramnik. As a result I was caught by 
Ivanchuk, who again defeated Bareev.
From the press: ‘In an  in terview  before the

Indeed, I felt the need for a drastic re­
newal, and in particular of my opening
repertoire. However, with Makarychev I was 
unable to resolve this problem. Sergey, with 
his customary sensitivity, himself realised 
that a conflict had arisen and he wisely 
decided to give up his post of trainer. From 
November 1994 the 30-year-old grandmas­
ter Yuri Dokhoian began working with me, 
and we began patiently developing a new 
preparation conception, which was to bear 
considerable fruit in the late 1990s.
Three Best Games
International Tournament in Horgen (3-15 
September 1994): l. Kasparov - 8 V2 out of 
11; 2-3. Yusupov and Shirov - 7; 4-5.

After returning from Novgorod to Mos­
cow, within just a few days I flew to London 
to take part in the third stage of the Intel 
Rapid-Play Grand Prix - and I was knocked 
out in my very first mini-match, after in­
competently losing a dead-drawn position 
against the program Genius. But as one of 
the PCA directors I had to stay there right to 
the final itself, as a result of which I was late 
for the drawing of lots in my next 'classical' 
tournament.
One of the best known chess patrons. Dr. 
William Wirth, Chairman of the board of 
directors of the Credit Suisse Bank, on this 
occasion simultaneously organised two all- 
play-all tournaments in Horgen, a suburb of 
Zurich. As the press rightly commented, ‘th e

A very complicated game and, for pre­
computer times, one of high quality. After it I 
became the sole leader, but in the next 
round I drew quickly with Korchnoi, and I
was caught by Shirov. We each had 6 out of 
8, with Korchnoi and Yusupov on 5V2.
In the ninth round came the highly im­
portant ‘duel of the leaders’ with Alexey 
Shirov, and I was fortunate to be able to 
carry out an amazing positional exchange 
sacrifice, which to this day is not suggested 
by a single computer!

I now had 7 out of 9, but the competitive 
intrigue was not exhausted, since Yusupov,

8 £sa4l?
This, one of my key discoveries in the 
Scotch Game, was a 1993 match novelty 
(instead of the previous 8 ®f4 or 8 ii.d3). 
White plays his knight to the edge of the 
board, in order to drive the black bishop 
from its strong position and comfortably 
complete his development. His aim is to 
extinguish Black’s temporary activity and try 
to convert his extra pawn on the kingside (as 
in the ‘Berlin Wall’ or the Exchange Variation 
of the Ruy Lopez).
8...Sd8 9 i-d3 i-d4 10 0-0 a6

14 1i rxd3 Sxd3 15 £sc5 is also unfavourable) 
141i rxa4 bxa415 -&c2 White obtained clearly 
the better endgame.
11 #a5l?
And here is another novelty. In the 17th 
game of the match with Short I chose the 
insipid 11 £sc3 £se7 12 £se2 ^.b6 13 'Bfy and 
after 13...£sg6 14 'Sfxf6 gxf6 15 £sg3 I 
achieved a minute advantage, but in the 
event of 13...1Hfxf4 14 £sxf4 -a.c8 it would 
have been even more symbolic. After that 
game I couldn’t help feeling that you can’t 
play chess that way (£sc3-a4-c3?l), and I soon 
devised 11 #a5 - an attempt to cut the 
Gordian knot at one stroke.
It would seem risky to play a second piece 
to the edge of the board, especially the 
queen. But with gain of tempo White opens 
the path of the cl-bishop, and in view of the 
threats of Wxc7 and ^.g5 Black can no longer 
play on general grounds. However, the main 
thing is that to avoid ending up in an un­
pleasant position, he is forced to sacrifice a 
pawn. From the frown on Yusupov’s pensive 
face it was evident that this was all clear to 
him...

A draw at the finish with Miles completed 
my performance in the tournament - first 
place by a margin of one and a half points. 
‘Zurich helped me to forget London’, I de­
clared on my return to Moscow. ‘I was 
especially successful in the games with 
Shirov and Yusupov, which were exception­
ally important in the competitive sense. For 
the sake of them alone it was worth going to 
Zurich.’
Curiously, this tournament was arbitrarily 
divided into three stages (rounds 1-4, 5-8 
and 9-11), in each of which a prestigious jury 
(Dr. Wirth, grandmasters Hort and Kinder- 
mann) awarded special prizes tor the best 
games, and I won two of these - for my wins 
against Nikolic and Yusupov. And then my 
game with Shirov was voted the best in the 
6lst volume of Informator.
Before the end of the year I appeared in 
three more events. In November in Paris I 
won the fourth and concluding stage of the 
Intel Rapidplay Grand Prix, in Lyon I played 
three games for the Sarajevo team Bosna in 
the European Club Cup (+l-l=i), and I took 
a very active part in saving the 31st World 
Chess Olympiad, which Greece had suddenly 
withdrawn from staging.
These events took place against the back­
ground of the continuing schism in the 
Russian Chess Federation. The vice-president 
Yuri Averbakh recalls:
'At a critical moment for international 
chess, Makarov, the recently elected president 
of the Russian Chess Federation, and alto­
82

Short, Anand and Las Palmas
gether unexpectedly the world champion 
Kasparov came to the aid of FIDE, thereby 
dispelling rumours that he was intent on 
destroying FIDE. We in fact wanted to dem­
onstrate that we were aiming not for a 
conflict, but for collaboration, and were 
ready to do everything possible to help the 
development of world chess (although six 
months before this the previous leaders of the 
Federation, Bebchuk and Karpov, had sent 
FIDE a fax with the assertion that our organi­
sation had set itself the objective of destroy­
ing FIDE!). The FIDE board of directors headed 
by Campomanes greeted our proposal with 
delight and unanimously decided that, firstly, 
it would recognise our federation as the only 
one acting legitimately on the territory of 
Russia, and, secondly, it would entrust us 
with the staging of the Olympiad and the 
Congress at the previously planned dates.’
The Olympiad, which was organised in 
less than two months, took place in the 
gigantic Kosmos Hotel in Moscow (30 No­
vember - 16 December 1994). Those were 
incredibly intensive days. I still don’t under­
stand how I was able to combine my daily 
administrative and political chess functions 
with successful play in the tournament.
My three strong-willed wins at the finish 
- against Azmaiparashvili, Short and the 
‘new German’ Yusupov - helped our harmo­
nious team again, as two years earlier in 
Manila, to win Olympiad ‘gold’: 1. Russia-1 - 
371/2 out of 56; 2. Bosnia and Herzegovina - 
35; 3. Russia-2 and 4. England - 34V2; 5-7. 
Bulgaria, Holland and USA - 34 etc. (alto­
gether - 124 teams). The winning team 
comprised Kasparov {FP/i out of 10), Kramnik 
(8 out of ll), Bareev (51/2 out of 10), Dreev 
(51/2 out of 8), reserves Tiviakov (6’/2 out of 9) 
and Svidler (5'A out of 8).
Intuitively I felt that things were not right 
with the world championship, and I took the
opportunity to make a truce with Campo­
manes. At the FIDE Congress which took 
place at that time we signed a Declaration of 
Cooperation between FIDE and the PCA, 
according to which in the final of both 
qualifying series a ‘unifying’ match for the 
title was envisaged (the full text of this 
historic document, which, alas, was not put 
into practice, was published in Kasparov vs. 
Karpov 1988-2009).
From the perspective of the 21st century 
Yuri Vasiliev called 1994 a fateful one for 
chess: ‘The intrigue, at the centre of which 
were the key figures of that time - Kasparov, 
the Russian Chess Federation President 
Makarov and the FIDE President Campo­
manes, who was unexpectedly re-elected for 
a new term, gave birth the following year to a 
phantom by the name of llyumzhinov. The 
victory in Moscow proved to be a pyrrhic 
victory for Kasparov.’

Early in 1995 the qualifying Candidates 
series concluded for both versions of the 
world title - FIDE and PCA. In the FIDE semi­
final matches in February Kamsky crushed 
Salov (s'h-x'/i), and Karpov overcame Gel- 
fand (6-3). Now in the principal FIDE match 
Karpov had to meet Kamsky. But in March 
Kamsky also had to battle with Anand in the 
final match of the PCA Candidates. If Gata 
had won, a unique situation would have 
arisen: one contender challenging two 
champions! But Anand prevailed (FP/i-AVi), 
and he thereby became my next opponent in

Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
a match for the world championship.
Therefore our encounter in Riga at the Tal 
Memorial in April was awaited with height­
ened interest and was christened a ‘recon­
naissance’ and a 'dress rehearsal’. It was 
with this tournament that eleven grand­
masters of the Professional Chess Associa­
tion, in addition to the Intel Rapidplay Grand 
Prix, began contesting the PCA Grand Prix 
Super-classic, which consisted of three 
stages: Riga (spring), Novgorod (early sum­
mer), and Horgen (late autumn).
At the drawing of lots I received an un­
usual gift - ‘No.l’, thanks to which I was free 
in the first round, which coincided with my 
32nd birthday. In the second round I quickly 
defeated Timman with White (cf. Game 
No.62, note to Black’s 7th move), and in the 
third I even more quickly gained a draw with 
Black against Kramnik in a quiet Italian 
Game. Kramnik had the reputation of being 
an expert on the closed games, but in the 
mid-1990s he regularly played l  e4 against 
me, and I replied either 1...C5 or l...e5.
After the initial rounds a leading quartet 
emerged: Anand and Ivanchuk - 2'/i out of 
3, Kramnik - 2, Kasparov - l'/i out of 2. I 
need hardly explain the competitive impor­
tance of my game with Vishy Anand in the 
fourth round. Before it I experienced a great 
emotional surge and I even exclaimed: ‘I feel 
in the mood to sacrifice! I will dedicate this 
game to Tali’. And I did indeed create a 
spectacular miniature.

4b4l?
My first employment in ‘classical’ play of 
the ancient Evans Gambit! Makarychev and I 
began analyzing it back in 1992, but more 
for pleasure. On one occasion I chose it 
against my will - in the first game of my 
thematic gambit match with Short (London 
(rapid) 1993) and then for many months I 
hesitated: could it be played in a top-rank 
tournament? And now I thought: this is a 
tournament in memory of Tal - and I must, I 
really must play the gambit.
Thus, by the irony of fate, this preparation 
by Sergey and myself saw the light only at 
the end of the ‘Makarychev era’. We tried to 
introduce new content into this 19th cen­
tury opening, although a residue of strategic 
unsoundness remained: White gives up a 
pawn in a position where Black has not yet 
broken any of the rules.

The move 7 .&e2, with which White de­
clines to return the pawn and insists on a 
gambit, would appear to contradict the idea 
of Captain Evans (an attack on the f7-point), 
but Black’s knight has gone to a5, weakening 
his centre. White does not aim to give a 
quick mate, but wants to extract positional 
benefits from the opening of lines and his 
lead in development.

One of the underestimated ideas, giving

psychological comfort for the opponent.

This game was judged the best in the 
63rd volume of Informator. I remember 
Anand with a sad smile observing: The fate 
of our match will depend on how often 
Kasparov employs the Evans Gambit.’ And I 
predicted: ‘It is probable that now this 
opening will begin to occur frequently, and 
much will be determined simply by the 
method of exhaustive searching.’ And, 
although I was very proud of this win in the 
style of the old masters, in the match with 
Anand I played only 3 i-b5 or 3 d4. But the 
sweeping manner of play in the main, 10th 
game (Game No.19) evoked ‘Evans-style’ 
ideas.
After this I reached 2y/i out of 3, while Iv­
anchuk was leading with 3Vz out of 4. But 
then he slowed down and drew all his re­
maining games, including the one with me 
in the sixth round, after holding out with
88

Short, Anand and Las Palmas
difficulty as Black in a King’s Indian. I man­
aged, not without a degree of luck, to win 
with Black against Yusupov and Vaganian, 
and also in the tenth round with White 
against the ‘home’ player Kengis, an old 
opponent of mine in junior tournaments 
(just think: our first encounter took place 22 
years earlier). This brought me to ‘plus five' 
and first place.
Anand also produced a finishing spurt. As 
a result he finished just half a point behind 
me, so that our duel in the fourth round took 
on the status of the decisive game of the 
tournament.
The chairman of the Tal Memorial organ­
ising committee was the Latvian Prime 
Minister himself, and also present at the 
opening ceremony were the President of the 
country and the Russian ambassador! But, 
alas, the tradition 
of staging 
super- 
toumaments of this standard in Riga was 
not established. The prominent Baltiya Bank, 
the main sponsor, soon collapsed and was 
liquidated...
After Riga and before our match in the 
autumn, Anand played only in two Intel 
Grand Prix knock-out tournaments, whereas 
I twice took part in ‘classical’ events. First 
there was the regular match-toumament in 
Amsterdam (Euwe Memorial, 11-18 May 
1995): 1. Lautier - 4 out of 6; 2. Kasparov - 
31/2; 3. Topalov - 2V2; 4. Piket - 2. It was 
amusing that up to the last round I copied 
the previous year’s results - draw, two wins, 
loss, win, but at the end I contrived to lose to 
Piket and I nevertheless finished behind 
Lautier.
‘The root of the trouble lay in accumu­
lated fatigue and many years of lack of 
training: I was no longer in the habit of 
aiming for an ultra-complicated battle, 
where the price of every move is very high’, I 
declared at that time in an interview. ‘Posi­
tions such as in the game with Piket, where 
in a Griinfeld White had a passed pawn on 
d6, were ones that previously I sensed with 
the tips of my fingers. But now I am commit­
ting crude errors... I have got out of the habit 
of playing with great intensity! This is a 
warning signal, but it has sounded in time. 
Now the main thing is to mobilise myself 
absolutely before the match with Anand.’
From Amsterdam I travelled to Cologne, 
where on 20 May I played two 25-minute 
games with an opponent I had lost to the 
previous year in London - the program 
Genius (1V2-V2). Everything was decided by 
the dramatic first game. In the opening I felt 
extremely feverish 
- the 
‘Amsterdam 
wounds’ were still painful, and all around 
there was an incredible hullabaloo. On the 
18th move, in a roughly equal position, I 
made an inexcusable oversight, leading to 
the loss of a pawn. The machine could take 
either a ‘good’, healthy pawn, or a ‘bad’, 
doubled one, but leading to an endgame 
with winning chances. Fortunately, Genius 
grabbed the ‘good’ pawn (that was how it 
was programmed), and I immediately cre­
ated threats to the black king. After a couple 
of poor moves the machine came under a 
‘mortal’ pin and could no longer avoid 
defeat.

tournament in the same place, the Euwe

Great Play
International Tournament in Novgorod (26 
May - 5 June 1995): 1. Kasparov - 6'/i out of 
9; 2-5. Ehlvest, Short, Ivanchuk and Topalov - 
5V2; 6. Kramnik - 5; 7. Timman - 4; 8. Gulko 
- 3; 9. Yusupov - V/r, 10. Vaganian - 2.
The basic line-up for the second, Nov­
gorod stage of the PCA Grand Prix Super­
classic was the same as in Riga, except that 
Anand was replaced by Topalov.
‘Kasparov had plenty of organisational 
and purely chess concerns. His collapse at the 
finish of the Amsterdam tournament, when 
he lost two games out of three, did not allow 
Garry any peace', testifies Yuri Vasiliev. ‘In a 
telephone conversation with me the cham­
pion declared that in Novgorod he would 
definitely play far better than in Amsterdam. 
And he said this persistently and forcefully. 
But it is one thing to say this, and another 
thing to do it.’
At the start, after employing a fresh idea 
in the King’s Indian Defence, I finally 
achieved an ‘historic’ victory over Gulko - 
the only grandmaster in the world who had 
a score of +3=2 against me. In the second 
round, alas, I again was unable to do any­
thing with White against Ivanchuk, who for 
the first time chose the Caro-Kann Defence 
against my 1 e4. The d4-d5 breakthrough 
promised an advantage, but in the end it led
merely to simplification and an equal end­
game. A difficult game!
The next day I was paired against Artur 
Yusupov, who had begun the tournament 
with two losses with Black and now was not 
averse to recouping his losses with the white 
pieces, at the same time improving the score 
of our individual meetings. But I wanted to 
send a ‘black spot’ to my opponent in the 
forthcoming match - Yusupov was one of 
Anand’s trainers.

The following day I had Black against the 
rising star of Bulgarian chess, the 20-year- 
old Veselin Topalov. Despite his youth, he 
was already well known for his bold, un­
compromising style, and he had beaten me

Amsterdam 1995 the scores began to tum 
the other way, and our final balance in 
‘classical’ play was +9-3=13 in my favour. It is 
curious that all my losses against Topalov, 
including the last, tragic one (Game No.lOO) 
were suffered as Black in the Sicilian. How­
ever, in it I won even more games!

After then scoring a third successive win - 
over Vaganian - I was confidently leading 
the race: Kasparov - 4’A out of 5; Ivanchuk 
and Short - 3I/2. But in the sixth round I had 
a difficult draw with Kramnik, whereas 
Ivanchuk defeated Short and reduced my 
lead to the minimum. After this both lead­
ers, exhausted by the extreme Novgorod 
heat, each made two draws, and now every­
thing was decided by the last, ninth round. 
Ivanchuk was obviously aiming to repeat his 
success of the previous year, when he had 
caught me by winning at the finish, but on 
this occasion he lost to Topalov. I had to be 
satisfied with a draw against Timman, who

llth  move), and as a result I took first place, 
a point ahead of my nearest rivals.

Yuri Vasiliev: 'The leading role in the tour­
nament was played by the world champion.

Match with Anand
World Championship Match Kasparov -  
Anand (New York, 10 September - 10 Octo­
ber 1995): 10Vi-7Vi.
Initially it was planned that my match 
with the winner of the PCA cycle would be 
held in Germany - such an offer had been 
made to me during the 1994 Moscow Olym­
piad by the organisers of the Dortmund 
tournaments. The venue had already been 
selected and all the conditions agreed. 
However, the German Chess Union, who 
were one of the Federations unhappy with 
the outcome of the FIDE Congress in Moscow 
and the conditions of the proposed agree­
ment with the PCA, effectively announced a 
boycott of the match. Early in 1995 the 
Dortmund organisers suddenly made a 
reverse move - they held a press conference, 
at which they besmirched the PCA and 
announced their intention to hold a super- 
toumament in the summer with the partici­
pation of ‘the world champion Karpov’. An 
amusing detail: when in the autumn of 
2000 their favourite Kramnik became world 
champion, they immediately ‘forgot’ from 
whom he had taken the title...
But, despite the critical situation, all the 
same the match would have taken place, 
since the main sponsor of the PCA was 
interested in it. Then, in the June days of the 
second, New York stage of the Intel Rapid- 
play Grand Prix, the Mayor of New York, 
Rudolf Giuliani, suddenly displayed extraor­
dinary enthusiasm. The CTazy idea was 
conceived of staging the match on the 107th 
floor of the south tower of the World Trade 
Centre, which precisely in September was to 
be opened anew - after the infamous terror­
ist act of 1993. And we decided that it would 
be better to hold the match there, where 
they were eager for this event, rather than 
somewhere where they were ‘basically’ 
opposed to it.
The World Trade Centre took on the prepa­
ration of the playing hall (with seating for 
roughly two hundred) and the advertising of 
the match. It was a fortunate coincidence of 
interests: the Centre needed to again have 
the attention of the world community fo­
cused on it. Operating at the match were 
such mighty TV and radio companies as the 
CNN and the BBC. Chess players could not 
even dream of such publicity!
In July and August, like two years earlier, I 
again prepared intensively for the match on 
the Adriatic Sea, in blessed Croatia. It was a 
long time since I had felt so well, in the 
physical, as well as the chess and the psycho­
logical sense. I swam a great deal and went 
canoeing. I established my own personal 
record: I swam three and a half kilometres in 
the open sea in one hour, forty minutes. 
Almost every day I paddled up to seven 
kilometres in the canoe and at the chess 
board I spent two hundred and fifty hours.
Apart from the old-timer Alexander 
Shakarov, I was helped by Yuri Dokhoian and 
Yevgeny Pigusov (official seconds). And in 
the last week Vladimir Kramnik arrived; we 
played some rapid chess and looked at a few 
ideas. The inclusion in the team of a top- 
class grandmaster helped me to acquire the 
necessary confidence. In New York we were 
joined by Mikhail Khodarkovsky, my man­
ager and press attache.
Taking into account the experience of my
100

Short, Anand and Las Palmas
match with Short, I decided to expand my 
range of openings, and after 1 e4, apart from 
the usual 1...C5 2 
d6 3 d4 cxd4 4 £sxd4 
£sf6 5 £>c3 a6, I prepared a secret weapon:
5...g6 - the Dragon Variation! Noticing that 
Anand did not play so confidently against it 
as in other set-ups, we found several new 
ideas, and the Dragon justified itself 100%. In 
addition, for one game a rare line of the 
Rauzer Variation was planned - 5..£>c6 6 
jLg5 e6 7 
i.e7 8 0-0-0 0-0 9 f4 h6, etc. (cf.
Game N0.25, note to Black’s 8th move), but in 
the match things did not come to this.
Of course, much attention was devoted to 
the Najdorf Variation. But here we missed the 
mark: we analysed 6 .&e3 or 6 f3, and 6 JLg5, 
and 6 f4 - everything apart from the quiet 6 
jLe2. The only thing that we did not look at 
before the match was the Scheveningen: 
after all, before this, in contrast to me, Anand 
had no experience with it at all! However, it 
was in the Scheveningen that the main 
match battles developed, and with 6 JLe2 
Anand constantly created problems for me.
The 25-year-old challenger’s team com­
prised Ubilava, Yusupov (the official seconds), 
Speelman and Wolff. He was also helped by 
Dvoretsky, and a number of invisible volun­
teers, who were hoping for my defeat. During 
his preparation Anand sharply improved his 
theoretical erudition and made a thorough 
study of the 6 jLe2 variation in the Schevenin­
gen, the Open Variation of the Ruy Lopez, 
which he had played in his youth and in the 
candidates matches (Yusupov was an expert 
on it), a new, aggressive scheme of counter­
play in the Scotch (cf. Game N0.38, note to 
White’s 10th move), a variation of the Nimzo- 
Indian 
which 
had 
been 
revived 
by 
Romanishin, and which quelled my enthusi­
asm for 1 d4 (cf. Game N0.63 in Part II of Garry 
Kasparov on Garry Kasparov, note to Black’s 
5th move), etc.
My opponent arrived for the match fully 
armed. Vishy was indeed the most worthy 
contender to the crown and could well have 
won both qualifying cycles - not only of the 
PCA, but also FIDE. ‘The match will be difficult 
not because it is being played on the 107th 
floor, but because Anand is a very dynamic 
and rapidly improving player’, I declared at an 
interview before the start. 'But I think that my 
great experience should tell and, most impor­
tant, the form which I have managed to 
acquire during the 50 days of training.’
The schedule of the match, which was to 
be the best of 20 games (and not 24, as 
previously), was unusually rigorous, genu­
inely professional. We played four times a 
week - on Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays 
and Fridays, without time-outs and ad­
journments, with a seven-hour time control: 
two hours for 40 moves, an hour for 20, and 
half an hour to the end of the game. As was 
the case two years earlier, immediately after 
a game the players gave press conferences.
The drawing of lots was personally carried 
out by Giuliani. And the next day, 11 Sep­
tember (just think: exactly six years before 
the 2001 tragedy...), he made the move 1 c4 
for Anand and declared New York to be the 
capital of world chess!
'After all the photographers had snapped 
the beaming Rudolf and Garry and the faintly 
smiling Vishy, Anand took back his c-pawn 
and made his genuine first move - 1 e4l. The 
world champion promptly cast off his film 
actor’s mask and, after assessing the opponent 
with his unique and characteristic glance, 
replied 1...C5!’, writes the chess historian Isaak 
Linder, who recalls the amazing atmosphere 
of the match at the top of the sky-scraper:
'During the one minute of ascent on the 
rapid escalator your ears popped. Here pom  
the viewing platform there was a wonderful 
panorama of New York - pom  the Statue of
101

Carry Kasparov on Carry Kasparov: Part Three
Liberty to the Brooklyn Bridge... That which I 
saw staggered me. In a cubic glass ‘aquarium’ 
three people were sitting: the two world- 
famous grandmasters at the chess table, and 
at the back of the stage a small, frail woman, 
the chief arbiter Carol Jarecki. Directly in front 
of the cube was the auditorium with places for 
those closest to the 'camps of the warring 
sides’. Some seats were marked ‘Kasparov’ and 
others ‘Anand’. Fans could also sit here if they 
paid 75 dollars for a ticket. For the others, less 
fastidious, crowded into the foyer and listen­
ing to the commentary on ear-pieces (they sat 
on the floor, reinforced by beer and sand­
wiches), the tickets were 15 dollars. “Fischer's 
dream has come true: chess in the public 
view", I sadly reflected...’
The first eight games ended in draws - a 
record for world championship matches! 
And although the battle was very tenacious, 
only once did we make more than 30 moves. 
This occurred in the third game, which 
Anand nearly won.

Whereas in the first five odd-numbered 
games the arena of battle was the Schev- 
eningen, in the even-numbered games I 
varied my openings, probing for weak points 
in my opponent’s preparation and obtaining
new material for analysis. I tried 1 d4,1 £rf3, 
1 e4 e5 2 £rf3 £ic6 3 -&b5 and 3 d4. And after 
the eighth game at night in my sleep (!), I 
finally discovered a ‘hole’ in the Open Varia­
tion of the Ruy Lopez, which had brought 
Anand a draw in the seventh game. During 
the free days my trainers and I thoroughly 
checked the correctness of the pretty combi­
nation that had been found, with the sacri­
fice of a pawn and a rook. It was time to go 
on the attack! But ahead lay Monday and the 
“black’ ninth game...
Just before the start of the match the ex­
perienced grandmaster Leonid Shamkovich 
predicted that ‘Anand would take the lead, 
but then Kasparov would draw level and 
move ahead’. After the eight draws he re­
fined his prognosis: ‘Kasparov needs to shake 
himself up, and to play his kind of risky chess. 
Perhaps for this he needs to lose one game? 
This would be a good stimulus for him, he 
would then be given a powerful surge of 
adrenalin in his blood. He needs a stimulant, 
to wake up from the sleep in which he finds 
himself at the start of the match.’
Amazingly, that is what happened. Ex­
cited by my fantastic ‘Spanish’ discovery, I 
was so gripped by anticipation of the tenth 
game the following day, that I was unable to 
concentrate on the ninth and I suffered a 
defeat. For the first time a theoretical nov­
elty let me down even before I could employ 
it! Now it was doubly important that it 
should work the following day.

At the end of the game this was how I ex­
plained my opponent’s failure: ‘He was very 
well prepared personally against me. His 
trainers took into account all my habits, 
passions and characteristics, the openings 
that I play, and so on, but they did not take 
account of the individual characteristics of 
Anand himself. They imposed on Vishy a 
manner of play which was uncharacteristic 
of him, they squeezed him into a framework
where a pn'ori he was unable to demon­
strate what he was capable of through his 
talent. Anand as though forgot about his 
rich intuition, he completely excluded n'sk, 
he aimed to calculate everything to the end, 
and those variations in which this was not 
possible he simply rejected. This was not in 
accordance with his style, talent and vision 
of the game.’
This fourth win in five games increased 
my lead to 8y2-5y2. To retain my title I only 
needed to score another one and a half 
points.
The match was effectively decided, and I 
again fell into a slight doze. The outcome of 
this was four draws, of which only the 17th 
game was protracted. Vishy finally joined 
battle in a Dragon (cf. Came No.2l, note to 
White’s 12th move), and obtained a better 
endgame, but after mistakes by both sides 
towards the end of the fourth hour of play I 
managed to save the game.
The following day in the 18th game the 
exhausted fighters did not see any point in 
prolonging the torture: I offered a draw on 
the 15th move, and we shook hands 13 
minutes and 35 seconds after the start of 
play. ‘Congratulations’, Anand said quietly. 
The match concluded ahead of schedule: 
lO'/i-l'/*.
This was a really difficult duel, and for me 
especially from the third to the tenth game. 
For the first time I sensed an ambiguous 
attitude towards myself: whereas most 
chess fans were rooting for me, most profes­
sionals were openly wanting me to lose, so 
that the chess world should finally acquire a 
‘correct’ champion and rid itself of the ‘PCA 
diktat’.
And I myself was exhausted by the con­
stant organizational problems, but after my 
win in the match I was filled with optimism 
and I stated in an interview that soon the
115

Carry Kasparov on Carry Kasparov: Part Three
PCA would have a new two-year contract 
with the Intel Corporation (‘a good contract, 
the details of which are now being worked 
out’), and that in it they had already pledged 
one and a half million dollars for the unifica­
tion match, envisaged in the Moscow 
agreement with FIDE. Alas, in December, 
because of the torpedoing of this agreement 
and the constant attacks on the PCA in the 
press, Intel changed its mind about signing 
the contract and pulled out of chess.
To a question about the presence in my 
team of the potential contender foT the title 
VladimiT KTamnik (suppose you have to play 
a match against him?), I carelessly replied: ‘I 
don’t see any problem here. Volodya and I 
are on excellent terms. If we need to play a 
match, we will prepare, and devise some­
thing. He has learned a lot about me, and I 
have learned something about him’. These 
words were remembered five years later, in 
October 2000...
Despite my fatigue, ten days afteT the tam­
ing of the ‘Madras tigeT’ I had to compete in

Another ten days lateT, 9-12 November,

Grand Prix, smashing Morozevich, Kiril GeoT-

But on 25 November 1995, at a scandalous 
FIDE Congress in Paris, suddenly, in violation
of all the rules, traditions and juridical norms 
of FIDE activity, for the first time a completely 
new person was elected to the post of its 
President - a Russian citizen, the 33-yeaT-old 
millionaire and President of Kalmykia, Kirsan 
llyumzhinov. In his enthronement speech he 
said that he considered himself a friend of 
both Karpov and Kasparov - and that he 
could ‘bring them to peace’.
But at first it was unclear whether it 
would in fact be possible to overcome the 
stubborn resistance of those opposed to the 
immediate signing of the agreement with 
the PCA. Thus Makarov, President of the 
Russian Chess Federation, who played a 
prominent role in the unification process, 
stated immediately afteT the Congress: ‘The 
new FIDE President faces the very difficult 
task of unifying the world championship... 
The agreement between FIDE and the PCA, 
with excellent financial conditions for FIDE, 
where it is allotted funds for chess develop­
ment ($300,000 a yeaT - G.K.), has been 
prepared and signed by the PCA. Today it is 
up to FIDE to make the next move.'
Soon, on 21 December, the Russian Chess 
Federation Praesidium also expressed anxi­
ety: 'The Congress in Paris, which wrecked the 
agreement between FIDE and the PCA, effec­
tively violated grossly a decision of the Moscow 
Congress, which was unanimously approved in 
December 1994. In this way the split in chess 
has not only not been overcome, but has 
possibly been aggravated still further.’
However, already on 23 December a sensa­
tional Teport arrived from Singapore: the FIDE 
Presidential Board had approved a suggestion 
by llyumzhinov to contest the world champi­
onship in annual knock-out tournaments 
with the participation of 128 leading players 
and with an overall prize fund of $5 million, 
and that Kasparov and the winner of the 
forthcoming Karpov-Kamsky match would be
116

Short, Anand and Las Palmas
admitted directly into the semi-finals of the 
first such tournament.
But what about the planned unification 
match? My reply was expressed in a long 
interview, entitled ‘I am the world cham­
pion. Not of a particular version, but of 
chess!’ (a more complete text of it is given in 
Kasparov vs. Karpov 1988-2009):
‘Was the new FIDE project agreed with me 
beforehand? No, I was simply handed the 
facts... FIDE faced a dilemma - peace, or war 
with the PCA. I think that the ‘Singapore’ 
knock-out project may have been conceived 
before llyumzhinov and initiated by Karpov 
and his ally, the new FIDE first vice-president 
Kouatly, also a fervent opponent of the 
agreement with the PCA (Karpov: "These 
ideas, apart from the financial part, belong to 
Kouatly. I come to this conclusion, because 
earlier he discussed them with me." - G.K.). To 
llyumzhinpv this project certainly seems 
logical as a way of reassuring the chess 
world - but I will tTy to disclose its true sense 
and the latent threat.
‘Karpov understands perfectly well that in 
a match between the two world champions 
he will lose hopelessly, and in his heart he 
also recognises the fictitious nature of his 
‘appointed’ title. Something must be devised, 
some chance found! But money is needed, 
and quite a lot. But there is no money. And 
then, like a magician, Kirsan llyumzhinov 
appears. And somewhere behind the scenes a 
plan is conceived, which they will now try to 
put into effect: if it is not possible to fight for 
the title, it has to be eliminated! Or more 
precisely, devalued, reduced to a lottery, to a 
chance happening, to a transitory title, played 
for in some annual tournament, which will 
completely kill the old-age tradition. Typical 
profanation!
‘The implication of this entire operation is 
simple: if I agree to play in the tournament,
Karpov will have better chances than in a 
usual match, while if I refuse, they will effec­
tively isolate me and compel me to play a 
match dictated by their conditions... However, 
I am sure that they are seriously mistaken. I 
will not play in the new FIDE world champi­
onship, irrespective of the prize fund.’

21 March - 1 April 1996): 1-2. Topalov and 
Kasparov - &/i out of 9; 3-4. Short and 
Anand - 5; 5-6. Kramnik and Lautier - A'/v, 1. 
Seirawan - 4; 8. Gelfand - 3 VS; 9. Piket - 3; 
10. Timman - 2VS.
In January 1996 I gave a clock simul’ in Rio 
de Janeiro against the Brazilian team (5-1), 
and in February I played a match in Phila­
delphia with an IBM brainchild - the com­
puter Deep Blue (4-2). But in the absence of 
Linares (the only year when it did not take 
place; I missed 1995 because of the scandal 
in 1994), my first tournament appearance 
came in March at the Euwe Memorial in 
Amsterdam.
This category 18 super-toumament dif­
fered from Linares in that the number of 
participants was smaller, but they were no 
less strong: all the leading grandmasters 
arrived, with the exception of Ivanchuk, as 
well as Karpov and Kamsky - they faced a 
match for the title of FIDE champion (pre­
cisely at the time when, on not finding any 
decent sponsors, llyumzhinov came to an 
agreement with his ‘friend’ Saddam Hussein 
and announced that the venue would be 
Baghdad!).
‘For the first time after an interval of nearly 
six months Kasparov participated in a strong 
tournament’, wrote my second Yuri Dok- 
hoian. ‘After all, isolated games in simuls’ or 
team events cannot be compared with full-
117

Carry Kasparov on Carry Kasparov: Part Three
scale and serious encounters with such dan­
gerous opponents as Anand, Kramnik and 
Topalov... A match with a computer stands 
apart. Playing against it has its own specific 
nature and is rather unpleasant. The slightest 
inaccuracy, to say nothing of a mistake, 
practically deprives you of any subsequent 
chances. The machine’s iron logic is not subject 
to the psychological nuances of the struggle, 
and it is not possible to upset its equilibrium or 
confuse it in complications. The match with 
Deep Blue took a great deal of emotional and 
physical strength, but it did not have any 
definite significance in Kasparov’s prepara­
tions for a normal "human’ tournament. This 
isolation from competitions with humans told 
at the very start, but with each subsequent 
round his taste for the game gradually re­
turned.’
My start in Amsterdam was discouraging: I 
suffered an opening disaster in the Najdorf 
with 6 iLc4, playing Black against Topalov (it 
is amusing that in the third round Short took 
‘revenge’ on him, by improving my variation 
cf. Came No.3, note to White’s 9th move). 
Then I won an interesting King’s Indian with 
Black against Piket, gaining revenge for my 
loss the previous year in a Griinfeld, but 
Topalov created a new sensation: he also 
defeated the second participant in the recent 
world championship match - Anand!
Against the background of these events, 
my next game with Vishy Anand acquired 
particular importance.

After this round a leading quintet 
emerged: Topalov, Kasparov, Kramnik, Short 
and Lautier - 2 out of 3. The status quo was 
maintained in the fourth round, in which we 
all drew - I escaped with difficulty in an­
other Sicilian duel with Short (cf. Game No.5, 
note to White's 10th move).
In the fifth round the quintet split up, 
since only Topalov and I won. The game with 
Yasser Seirawan, played 'in Tal style’, also 
afforded me enormous pleasure.
