The leaders were now Kasparov and Topa­
lov - 3V2 out of 5, Kramnik - 3. In the sixth 
round I drew with difficulty in a King’s 
Indian battle with Timman, while Kramnik 
defeated Topalov and replaced him in the 
leading duo - we each had 4 out of 6.
In the seventh round I had White against 
the No.2 in the world rating list, Vladimir 
Kramnik, and, of course, I was in a fighting 
mood, taking into account not only the 
competitive importance of the game, but 
also the current score of our individual 
meetings in ‘classical’ play (+1-1=5).

2xe5! 1-0
‘A fantastic dash!’ (M.Gurevich).
Thanks to this important win, for the first 
time in the entire tournament I became the 
sole leader - 5 out of 7. But hot on my heels 
was Topalov, after beating Lautier.
In the eighth round I had Black against 
Lautier, an ‘awkward’ opponent for me. 
After ordering lunch in my room, Dokhoian 
and I were calmly concluding our prepara­
tions and preparing to take our traditional 
walk, when there was a sudden phone call 
from the organisers: ‘Where are you?’. I 
replied: ‘In my room.' And then I realised to 
my hoiror that we had forgotten to put our 
clocks forward by an hour! It was precisely 
on that Sunday 3lst March that Europe 
switched to summer time...
After sprinting to the venue I arrived half 
an hour late for the game and rapidly rattled 
out a King’s Indian Defence. Fortunately, the 
game followed a line I had analysed, I em­
ployed a novelty with a pawn sacrifice, and 
without particular anxiety I gained a draw.
In the meantime Topalov won a good 
King’s Indian with Black against Gelfand and 
caught up with me just before the finish. 
Kramnik would have tried to give chase, but 
against Anand he lost from an excellent 
position with White.
In the final round the burgeoning Topalov 
had White against Piket. I did not expect 
anything good to come of this game, and to 
avoid falling behind my rival I had to win ‘to 
order’ against Boris Gelfand. For this I again 
had to display exceptional resourcefulness.

Topalov also won, and we shared first 
place, one and a half points ahead of our 
nearest rivals. It was an uncommonly fight­
ing tournament: two-thirds of the games 
ended decisively.
Genna Sosonko: ‘This was a major success 
for the 21-year-old Bulgarian grandmaster, 
who is always impeccably dressed and ex­
tremely correct. His ability to sit and concen­
trate is amazing. Topalov is excellently pre­
pared, and he may improve still further, 
although he is already a grandmaster of very 
high class. Not without reason the Dutch 
press commented that in the tournament 
there were two brilliant winners... ’
‘I think that this was one of my best tour­
naments in recent years’, I stated soon 
afterwards. ‘I am very happy with my play, 
except, of course, the game with Topalov. 
But after it I scored ‘plus five’. I won all my 
games with White! There was the same kind 
of ‘roller’ as in my games of some ten years 
ago: all the white pieces advance, and 
against this hurricane Black cannot defend. 
Moreover, this had nothing to do with my 
widely advertised opening preparation: not 
once did I gain an overwhelming position 
from the opening, but all the wins were 
achieved in an exceptionally tense battle!
‘I often ended up in time-trouble, but I still 
continued to control the situation. I am 
happy that I have overcome something of a 
creative slump, which was observed both 
during the match with Anand, and in last 
year’s ‘classical’ events, when I noticed to my 
dismay that my play had become more sterile 
and the vivid colours had disappeared... Here I 
was fighting with young players, who have 
grown up with my games, demonstrating my 
approach to the struggle. So that I regard 
Amsterdam 1996 as a kind of progress report 
on my ten years as champion. For me it is very 
important that I myself have also not forgot­
ten how to play attacking, fighting chess.’
Difficult Opponent
International Tournament in Dos Hermanas 
(20 May - l  June 1996): 1-2. Kramnik and
139

Carry Kasparov on Carry Kasparov: Part Three
Topalov - 6 out of 9; 3-4. Anand and Kas­
parov - 5Vi; 5- Hlescas - 4'A; 6-7. Kamsky and 
Gelfand - 4; 8. Ivanchuk - 3V2; 9-10. Shirov 
andJ.Polgar- 3.
After Amsterdam I also took part in the 
April 'Kremlin Stars’ rapid-play knock-out 
tournament in the PCA Grand Prix series. Two 
years earlier I had lost in the quarter-final to 
Kramnik, and a year earlier to Anand in the 
semi-final, but on this occasion I reached the 
final, on the way defeating Gelfand (2-0) and 
Dreev (l-l; 1-0), and spectacularly crushing 
Anand (Game No.115). In the final Kramnik 
and I drew l-l, but then I played terribly in 
the blitz tie-break: I lost the first game with 
White, after avoiding a repetition of moves 
(although I had less time and an inferior 
position!), and in one move I threw away a 
win in the second. Apparently the Kremlin is 
not my territory...
It stands to reason that I again wanted to 
get even with Kramnik, and an opportunity 
presented itself at the end of May in the 
small Spanish town of Dos Hermanas. This 
categoiy 19 super-tournament assembled 
almost the entire chess elite, including even 
the FIDE challenger Kamsky, who within five 
days was due to start his long-suffering 
match with Karpov, which had after all been 
switched from Baghdad to Elista.
My first appearance in Dos Hermanas was 
also my last: the playing conditions were not 
veiy impressive. Compared with this hamlet, 
modest Linares looked like a world capital! 
The playing room was in a small, stuffy 
semi-basement, which resembled an air-raid 
shelter This, to put it mildly, did not pro­
mote creativity, and for me it was a difficult 
and not veiy successful tournament.
My starting duel with Gata Kamsky 
turned out to be tense and nervy. In a slow 
Ruy Lopez (cf. Game No.2, note to White’s 8th
move) by the 24th move I obtained an 
obvious positional advantage, but here I 
suddenly became stuck and I was unable to 
build on my success - draw. This game 
proved to be the last of our eight ‘classical’ 
tournament meetings (+4-1=3).
In the second round I had a short but veiy 
wild Sicilian draw with Anand (cf. Game 
No.37, note to White’s 6th move). Then in 
the third I won against Shirov, but in the 
fourth for the first time I was unable to beat 
lllescas with White - a warning signal! At 
this point the leading five looked like this: 
Anand - 3Vi out of 4, Gelfand - 3; Kasparov 
and Topalov - 2V2; Kramnik - 2.
In the fifth round those who were trailing 
gave chase: Topalov defeated Gelfand, and 
Kramnik, who had begun the tournament 
with four draws, ‘wore out’ Anand on the 
101st move. I gained a draw with Ivanchuk, 
after employing another novelty in the 
King’s Indian (cf. Game N0.36 in Kasparov vs. 
Karpov 1988-2009, note to White’s 8th 
move). The leading group became much 
more compact: Anand and Topalov - 3Vi out 
of 5; Kasparov, Kramnik and Gelfand - 3.
The next day I had White against my 
‘Kremlin conqueror’, Vladimir Kramnik. By 
his own admission, in this game he was 
ready to do everything to maintain his ‘plus 
one’, which had been gained with such 
difficulty. But I was eager to reach ‘plus two’.

Picking up the knight on d3. White re­
signed (O-l).
This was my only loss after 1 d4 in almost 
19 years, from the ill-starTed 18th game of 
the 1986 match (Game No.18 in Part II of 
Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov) to the 
end of my career in 2005! And it was no 
accident that I suffered it against Kramnik - 
my most awkward opponent since the mid- 
1990s. The vexation and bitterness of this 
painful reverse took a long time to pass: 
after all, if I had won this game, I would 
probably also have won the tournament.
In the meantime Topalov snatched a win 
against Kamsky, who on the 45th move 
committed ‘hara-kiri’ in an equal position, 
and became the sole leader - 4Vi out of 6. 
Despite my soiry state, I managed to compose 
myself and make a reasonable finish. True, in
my game with Judit Polgar played after the 
free day I was a little lucky. After obtaining an 
easily won ending, I suddenly made a ‘bril­
liant’ move - 32...£>e4? and threw away the 
greater part of my advantage. But then I 
nevertheless contrived to win a textbook 
endgame with rook and knight against rook.

Anand, who lost out in the "battle of the chal­
lengers’ to the aggressively inclined Kamsky, so 
that Vishy and I finished half a point behind 
the winning pair - Kramnik and Topalov.
Emerging from a ‘Groggy’ State
32nd World Chess Olympiad (Yerevan, 15 
September - 2 October 1996): 1. Russia - 
38V2 out of 56; 2. Ukraine - 35: 3. USA and 4. 
England - 34; 5-7. Armenia-1, Spain, and 
Bosnia and Herzegovina - 33V2; 8-12. Geor­
gia, Bulgaria, Germany, Sweden and Iceland 
- 33, etc. (altogether - 114 teams). The 
winning team comprised Kasparov (7 out of 
9), Kramnik (41/2 out of 9), Dreev (5 out of 8), 
Svidler (8yi out of ll), reserves Bareev (7'A 
out of 10) and Rublevsky (6 out of 9).
In the summer before the 1996 Yerevan 
Olympiad, while I was relaxing and prepar­
ing for the new season, the match for the 
title of FIDE champion finally took place in 
Elista, and Karpov defeated Kamsky (lOW 
7V2). Immediately after the closing cere­
mony, at a press conference on 14 July 1996,
145

Carry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
the FIDE President llyumzhinov stated: 'I am 
not giving up my plans to stage a world 
championship with the participation of the 
100 best players in the world and with a 
prize fund of five million dollars. In addition, 
in 1997 a Kaspamv-Karpov match ‘foT the 
absolute championship’ will be held. The 
agreement in principle of the contestants 
has been obtained. The prize fund will be 
not less than two million dollars.’
In view of FIDE's rejection of the traditional 
world championship system, my match with 
Karpov was no longer a unifying event, but a 
purely historic and competitive one: the world 
champion was due to meet a worthy oppo­
nent, who had gone through the FIDE qualify­
ing system. And whereas earlier, after my 
match with Anand, I put forward the usual 
condition - ‘with a 10-10 score the world 
champion retains his title’, now, to avoid 
losing my opponent, I decided to make a 
compromise. But Karpov too had to make a 
compromise in return, as otherwise we would 
have been unable to come to an agreement.
On the joint initiative of llyumzhinov and 
Makarov, Karpov and I met on 23 August 
1996 in the Kalmykia agency in Moscow. 
Almost immediately the two of us were left 
alone, and our face-to-face and later corre­
spondence discussions led within three weeks 
to the production of a very important (at that 
moment) unofficial agreement to a match, 
signed on 14 September by both contestants.
In it, among other things, it was stated that 
‘the match will be played for the title of world 
champion’, that ‘the match will be played 
outside the currently existing official organi­
sations, FIDE or PCA’, that ‘the status of the 
participants in the match are world cham­
pion and FIDE world champion’, and that ‘in 
the event of a drawn match, additional rapid 
games are to be played (4 games in 2 days); if 
they too result in a draw, two additional rapid

146

Short, Anand and Las Palmas
In the first two rounds, while Kramnik 
and I were being treated for colds, the Rus­
sian team crushed Finland and Bangladesh 
(both 3V2-V2). In the third round I turned out 
for a ‘white’ game with Lautier, still unwell 
and in a ‘groggy’ state after the shock in 
Geneva. In this condition the heightened 
attention of the fans was an added stress: I 
had not been in Yerevan since 1976 and I 
was there for the first time as world cham­
pion. After playing the opening badly (cf. 
Game No.22 in Kasparov vs. Karpov 1975- 
1985, note to Black’s 12th move), I had to 
fight for a draw. But nevertheless Russia 
overcame France: Vh-Vh.
In the fourth round we confidently beat 
Germany 3-1, although I had another diffi­
cult draw - with Yusupov (cf. Game No.77 in 
Part II of Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov, 
note to Black’s 13th move). Then Russia 
defeated China and Armenia (both 2'h-V/i), 
but I, after a day’s rest, was unable to win 
against Akopian and I flamboyantly forced a 
draw by perpetual check (cf. Game No.98, 
note to White’s 14th move). The local specta­
tors applauded, thinking that this was a 
mark of respect for the Armenian commu­
nity, but in fact it was a forced measure.
In the seventh round I was finally able to 
concentrate and open my score with a win. 
My opponent was the 26-year-old Czech 
Grandmaster Zbynek Flracek.

In the ninth round I had another sharp 
Sicilian duel with Topalov, who, playing 
White, did not make any obvious mistakes, 
but he acted not altogether certainly (cf. 
Game No.37, note to White’s 13th move), 
and it all concluded, as the press wrote, with 
a ‘Kasparov-style vendetta’.

team (3V2-V2) essentially decided the destiny 
of the gold medals, and we drew our next 
two matches, with Bosnia and Herzegovina 
(in a Scotch I overwhelmed Ivan Sokolov - cf. 
Game N0.38, note to White’s 9th move), and 
Ukraine.

Thanks to this win we defeated Israel, and

At the finish Russian beat Iceland by the

The best results on board l  were posted by 
A1 Modiahki (8 out of 10), Kasparov (7 out of 
9) and Ivanchuk (8V2 out of 11). I commented 
as follows on this paradoxical picture: ‘In 
announcing the best results on individual 
boards, very strange things occur. In a diffi­
cult battle I can defeat Ivanchuk, but I am 
quite unable to beat a player from Qatar, who 
plays in the region of the 80th board with 
opponents who are not even of simultaneous 
standard for me or Ivanchuk. And in the end 
the winner of this ‘tournament’ is declared 
the prize-winner on board l! This is some 
kind of naive joke with respect to the top- 
class grandmasters fighting one another.'
At the FIDE Congress taking place at the 
same time, llyumzhinov consolidated his hold 
on the Presidential post. It was then that his
156

Short, Anand and Las Palmas
coalition with Kouatly and Karpov broke up, 
after which llyumzhinov finally decided that 
he had no need to organise a unification 
match, and that it was better to get rid of the 
‘champion’s diktat’ by means of the knock­
out world championship. But for the moment 
this did not greatly concern me, since an 
‘unscheduled’ match with Karpov was al­
ready taking shape: for our sixth duel some 
excellent sponsors had been found - the 
organisers of the December super-tourna­
ment in Las Palmas, who in the autumn of 
1997 were also proposing to hold there a 
match ‘for the absolute championship’.
Soon Karpov stated in an interview: 'Of 
course, the match is necessary - it is awaited 
by millions of chess fans, and it should also 
settle all of the accounts in my chess relations 
with Garry. Therefore, when I won against 
Kamsky and once again became the legiti­
mate world champion, I immediately made 
contact and entered into discussions with my 
old opponent.’
I also commented on this topic: ‘Whether 
Karpov likes it or not, a match without 
Kasparov cannot be considered a match for 
the title of world champion. Today, whether I 
like it or not, before any qualifying cycle is 
organised I have to finalise the negotiations 
with Karpov, because in the eyes of the 
public he is regarded as my obvious oppo­
nent in a match for the chess title. In my 
view, FIDE has forfeited the moral and 
financial right to the world championship, 
since it has simply opted out of staging it.’
Towards the end of the Olympiad I again 
sensed my former chess strength, and this 
heralded a surge in Las Palmas and Linares. 
By that time order had been restored to my 
chaotic, crazy life of the early 1990s, when I 
was battling on several fronts - FIDE, the 
Russian Chess Federation, and a protracted 
divorce process. Finally, calm was restored
and my every-day life was stabilised. Back in 
the spring of 1995, at the concluding ban­
quet of the Tal Memorial Tournament, I met 
Riga student Yulia Volk. In 1996 she moved 
to my place in Moscow, and on 28 October 
our son Vadim was bom.

Double-Round Super-Tournament in Las 
Palmas (8-21 December 1996): 1. Kasparov - 
6V2 out of 10; 2. Anand - 5V2; 3-4. Topalov and 
Kramnik - 5; 5-6. Ivanchuk and Karpov - 4.
Las Palmas 1996 was undoubtedly an his­
toric chess event, comparable with a ‘su­
preme court’ and strongly resembling the 
epochal AVRO Tournament (1938), where 
Alekhine and Capablanca were opposed by 
six young pretenders to the title. True, the 
modem organisers, aiming to achieve the 
highest, unprecedented 2lst category for 
the tournament, did not invite eight, but 
only six of the top-rated players in the world 
- Kasparov, Karpov, Kramnik, Anand, Topa­
lov and Ivanchuk, whereas for a ‘full com­
plement’ it was lacking Kamsky (after losing 
his match to Karpov, he left the chess scene 
for a long time), Gelfand and Shirov.
‘With them we could indeed have had a 
review of all the real challengers compared 
with the ‘old champions", wrote the Russian 
journalist Yuri Vasiliev. ‘However, in contrast 
to their prototypes, the ‘upgraded Alekhine’ 
and the 'upgraded Capablanca' are intending 
soon to play a match against each other. To 
avoid possible false rumours, Kasparov said 
at a press conference before the start that a 
comparison of this “tournament of six" with 
the world championship was unfair, since by 
tradition the chess title can be won only in a 
match.’
But the importance of victory in such a 
tournament was exceptionally high, and the
157

Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
players felt the weight of responsibility. But, 
of course, the experts and the fans were 
intrigued by the performance of the two ‘Ks’, 
especially in the light of our negotiations 
with the Spanish organisers about our 
forthcoming match, which were conducted 
through our lawyers at the start of the event.
In this ridiculously nervy atmosphere I 
was fortunate to start well - with Black I 
outplayed Topalov, who surprised me with 1 
d4. A closed Catalan led to an equal position. 
On the 25th move Veselin went wrong, but 
with my 28th move I lost my advantage and 
got into severe time-trouble. Nevertheless 
my opponent did not play accurately 
enough to extinguish the activity of my 
pieces in an interesting rook ending.
In the second round I again had Black and 
I easily gained a draw with Ivanchuk. In the 
third round KTamnik surprised me with a 
King’s Indian Defence, which he had pre­
pared for the tournament, and he also easily 
gained a draw. That day Anand beat Ivan­
chuk, after which he was sharing the lead 
with me - we each had 2 out of 3.
And then came the fourth round, and a 
crucial encounter with Vishy Anand, my 
‘Geneva conqueror' (to avoid anyone playing 
three successive games with the same colour, 
the fourth and fifth rounds weTe inter­
changed). Makarychev: 'The game of last 
year’s opponents in the match for the world 
championship was the focus of attention. 
Garry played the opening simply splendidly.’

A mind-boggling game!
It was a pity that I did not manage to cre­
ate a ‘canvas’ and crush a direct rival, but 
there was no time for me to grieve: at the 
very finish of the first cycle I had to play 
Karpov with Black. At that moment nearly all 
the contestants still retained chances of 
overall victory: Anand and I had 2'/i out of 4, 
with Karpov, Kramnik and Ivanchuk on 2.
Our game was preceded by two free days, 
and here Karpov allowed himself to be 
unjustifiably diverted. With the tournament 
in full swing he flew to Paris for the opening 
of a junior tournament! From the competi­
tive point of view this was a suicidal step, 
comparable perhaps with Capablanca’s trip 
to Leningrad during the 1925 Moscow 
International Tournament - it will be re­
membered that the Cuban gave a difficult 
simultaneous display in the city on the Neva, 
and on his return he suffered a defeat. 
Miraculously, Karpov did not lose to me, but 
he came a cropper in the second half of the 
tournament...

Meanwhile, at the time when we were

officially declared that the new-formula

time, its prize fund would be 5 million 
dollars, and the main sponsor would be

again been deferred - now from spring 1997 
to December, evidently in order to allow 
Karpov and Kasparov to decide on their

are avoided very simply by the professional 
diplomat llyumzhinov: "/ am the President of 
FIDE and I answer only for my organisation".’
In the meantime Anand had also drawn, 
and we were caught by Ivanchuk, who 
defeated Kramnik. The leading trio was on 3 
out of 5.
The next day the second half of the tour­
nament began, and Anand lost to Kramnik, 
Ivanchuk drew with Karpov, as did I, to my 
vexation, with Topalov, who answered 1 e4

competitively important was my next en­
counter with Vassily Ivanchuk, against 
whom I had not won in ‘classical’ play for 
nearly three years.

pressure.’

A very important win, which eliminated a 
dangerous rival: after this Ivanchuk was as 
though substituted and he scored only one 
more half-point. In this blood-thirsty round 
there were no draws: Anand crushed Karpov 
in spectacular style, while Kramnik lost to 
the resurgent Topalov. A decisive separation 
of the leading group occurred: Kasparov - 
4V2 out of 7; Anand - 4; Ivanchuk - 3Vr; 
Topalov, Kramnik and Karpov - 3.
Then, after a free day, all the games ended 
in draws. Against Kramnik I ‘sounded the 
retreat’ in the Lasker Defence to the Queen’s 
Gambit, but in the end I saved the game 
literally by a miracle. My ‘white’ duel with 
Karpov in the ninth round also took a very 
difficult, nervy and uneven course.
Roshal: ‘An interesting intrigue developed 
around virtually the main game of the entire 
tournament. The sceptics asserted: Kasparov 
will not risk his sole leadership, while Karpov 
(especially with Black) will be inhibited by the 
risk of damaging the prestige of the future 
match between them. The meticulous Kas­
parov appeared in his full regalia, whereas 
without a tie Karpov looked imposing and 
even complacent... The game proved unfor­
gettable, especially its finish, which took place 
in a fearful time scramble.’
Game 36
G.Kasparov-A.Karpov

Roshal: 'The nine culminating moves in 
this game literally shook the chess world, 
divided into supporters of the two contest­
ants. Right to the end of the tournament in 
the press centre, and much later elsewhere, 
these time-trouble moves were repeated. It is 
simply pointless to talk here about good or 
bad luck: Karpov was indeed in poor form.’
Makarychev: ‘Yes, to play as well at the age 
of 45 as one did at 25 is practically impossi­
ble.’
A round before the finish I had moved a 
point ahead of Anand and was assured, at 
the least, of a share of first place. And on the 
last day I had Black against Vishy and I quite 
confidently gained a draw in a sharp branch 
of the Scheveningen (cf. Game No.37, note to 
White's 13th move).
Thus the world champion took his ‘lawful’ 
first place, while the FIDE champion shared 
last place, being the only player not to score 
a single win. As a result the Kasparov-Karpov 
match was sharply devalued: the sponsors 
were unwilling to invest several million 
dollars on the clash between the winner of 
the tournament and an outsider.
This veritable supreme court led to a re­
alignment at the top of world chess and 
drew the line under the ‘two Ks’ era. The era 
of my confrontation with the young began.
170

Chapter Two
Second Peak
Battle for Prestige
International Tournament in Linares (3-16 
February 1997): 1. Kasparov - 8'/2 out of 11; 
2. Kramnik - 7V2; 3-4. Adams and Topalov -
6V2; 5. J.Polgar - 6; 6. Anand - 5V2; 7-8. 
Ivanchuk and Gelfand - 5; 9. Nikolic - 4Vr, 
10. Dreev - 4; 11-12. Sbirov and Piket - y /2.
Despite the dramatic outcome in Las Pal­
mas, the chess world entered 1997 still 
expecting a sixth Kasparov-Karpov match.
‘After Karpov's failure the number of 
those wishing to stage our match has dimin­
ished: perhaps this will also affect the prize 
fund’, I stated soon afterwards. ‘But even so, 
a match is the only possible way of contest­
ing the champion’s title, and at the moment 
there is no more lawful challenger than 
Karpov. He has to his credit successes which 
today no one can match: from Linares 1994 
to the match with Kamsky. I hope that our 
match will take place in the autumn of 1997 
and that by the end of Feburary, after the 
super-tournament in Linares, we will decide 
on the venue and the final conditions.’
But the attitude of potential sponsors to 
this match was also influenced by the next 
‘chess Wimbledon’, which was revived after 
a year’s break (in honour of this a super­
prize for the winner was even wheeled into 
the hall of the Anibal Hotel - a Sukuzi jeep).
All the Las Palmas contestants arrived in 
Linares, apart from Karpov, who totally 
ignored numerous invitations, which of­
fended the Spanish organisers. In an open 
letter to the FIDE champion, Senor Rentero 
stated: ‘You are hiding... But it is interesting 
for me to see how you intend to sell your 
match with Kasparov for 400 million pesetas. 
After all, all the sponsors were awaiting your 
appearance in Linares. The fact that you are 
not playing in Linares is bound to have 
consequences: thus Cadilso Insular (the 
government of the Canary Islands - G.K.) will 
not sponsor you.’
For Vishy Anand and me the start in 
Linares was a continuation of the finish in 
Las Palmas: we again played with the same 
colours - and again it was a tense duel in a 
Scheveningen!

This is the point! ‘The strongest and most

of the game, White has been left with typical 
Sicilian weaknesses (the pawns on c2 and 
e4). Strategically the game is decided: White 
has no way of opposing the inexorable 
strengthening of Black’s attack’ (Dokhoian).
At this point we each had about 10 min­
utes left. Glancing at my opponent, I saw his 
face suddenly change. All was clear to An­
and! And since the time of our match I knew 
that after a sharp change of scene he would 
no longer be able to play at full strength...

A knock-out: 42 £ig3 £ixg3+ or 42 f6 JLd8, 
etc. ‘A brilliant finish, and quite a good claim 
by Kasparov for victory in the tournament!’ 
(MakaTychev).
This loss sapped Anand’s energy, and he 
emerged from a minus score only at the very 
finish. As for me, such a striking win should 
have been inspiring, but I suddenly came to 
a halt - I made three draws. In the second
round, again playing Black, I escaped with 
difficulty against Dreev, in the third I failed 
to finish off Gelfand, and in the fourth I 
almost lost to Piket, who in a King’s Indian 
employed a novelty with a pawn sacrifice (cf. 
Game No.77 in Part II of Garry Kasparov on 
Garry Kasparov, note to White’s 13th move).
By the free day after four rounds I had just 
'plus one’ and was half a point behind the 
leaders - Kramnik, Adams and Polgar. My 
play was unimpressive, and I urgently 
needed to break the sequence. The basis of 
my winning run was laid by the game with 
Predrag Nikolic.

After six rounds the leading group com­
prised Kasparov, Kramnik and Polgar - 41/2; 
Adams - 4. But the ‘crunch’ seventh round 
finally determined the two leading contend­
ers for first place: Kramnik beat Polgar, and I 
won against Adams, who, like Ivanchuk in 
Las Palmas, risked employing the Alekhine 
Defence (cf. Game No.35, note to Black’s 4th 
move).
After scoring three wins in a row I was 
also eager for ‘blood’ in the eighth round, 
playing Black against Ivanchuk, who was on 
‘minus three’. And I achieved an excellent 
position, but in a time scramble I over­
stepped the mark and allowed a very strong 
tactical stroke. Yuri Vasiliev: ‘Kasparov was 
crushed and dismayed. He lost on time in
183

Carry Kasparov on Carry Kasparov: Part Three
what was now a completely hopeless posi­
tion. In an impotent rage Garry clenched his 
fists, shook his head, as though wanting to 
cast off a delusion, and again and again 
cursed himself under his breath.'
Meanwhile Kramnik made a draw and 
moved half a point ahead. The following day 
I cleanly outplayed Judit Polgar, but my rival 
defeated Dreev and maintained the status 
quo. Two rounds before the finish Kramnik 
had 7 out of 9, with me on 6'A.
In the tenth round my opponent was 
Alexey Shirov - by general opinion a highly 
inventive and brilliant player, but also 
uncompromising, who sometimes allowed 
himself to be caught by a counterattack. I 
remember having a terrible night before the 
game: in a local restaurant there was an 
incredibly noisy wedding, and it was quite 
impossible to sleep. That, however, did not 
affect my fighting mood.

Mikhail Gurevich: ‘The last round became
186

Second Peak
the culmination of Linares 1997. The fate of 
the first two places in this exceptionally

money was not the main thing at stake in 
this game: it was not the Suzuki jeep or the 
$10,000 difference in the prizes that the 
players were thinking about before the start. 
Above all it was a battle for prestige!’
In the event of a draw and a share of first 
place, the tournament winner was to be 
decided not by the Berger coefficient, but 
simply by discarding the results against the 
player who finished last. Before the 11th 
round this player was Shirov, who had lost to 
me and drawn with Kramik. Therefore in his 
game with me it seemed that Kramnik 
should be satisfied with a draw (in the 
course of the round, however, everything 
was turned on its head: Shirov was caught 
by Piket, and now it was I who could be 
satisfied with a draw), but I was aiming to 
win ‘to order’ against this difficult opponent, 
against whom I had an equal score in ‘classi­
cal’ play: 2-2 with seven draws.

In the preceding rounds I played only l  e4,

I...£sf6 2 c4 e6
A surprise! Of course, Dokhoian and I had 
prepared for Kramnik’s usual openings - the 
Meran (Came No.27) and the King’s Indian
which occurred in Las Palmas 1996. But the 
Nimzo-lndian had not previously occurred in 
his games. It is probable that my opponent’s 
second, Sergey Dolmatov, had this flexible 
defence in mind when before the game he 
expressed his confidence: ‘Volodya will make 
a draw’.
Incidentally, from his youth Kramnik was 
a splendid psychologist and he always 
keenly sensed his opponent’s state of mind. 
Thus here, feeling that I was bursting with 
energy, instead of sharp variations he delib­
erately chose an opening of which he even 
had less knowledge, merely in order to avoid 
a direct confrontation and not allow me a 
clear initiative.

1-0
This victory enabled me not only to win 
the tournament with a ‘plus five’ result and
increase my rating to 2820, but also to 
repeat my finishing spurt at Belfort 1988 (6 
out of 7, without draws) and establish an 
unusual record - 5 out of 5 against the 
players occupying 2nd-6th places!
Linares 1997 was an important landmark 
in my chess career: I was able to demon­
strate my superiority over the stars of the 
young wave. In an interview soon after­
wards I said:
‘For the first time in many years I have bro­
ken away from the main elite group in terms 
of my contribution to chess. After Las Palmas I 
already had the feeling that with the opening 
and general chess preparation accumulated 
over a year I could make a new surge. Now 
the collection of ideas has become so great 
that I have moved ahead in many directions. 
And here this showed itself! This was how it 
was in the late 1980s, when between me and 
the rest of the elite there was a gulf in the 
understanding of chess, and in work. But this 
disappeared in the early 1990s, when I did 
little work on chess.
‘In order to restore this lead, I needed a 
year of work. Yuri Dokhoian, Alexander 
Shakrov and myself - this is our small but 
united team, plus three computers. From 
sometime early in 1995 we built up a new 
chess base, and in Las Palmas I knew that it 
was ready. At that time I was not yet able to 
play at full strength, but the regeneration 
was in progress. And in Linares it occurred!'
To the question, who is now the No.2 
player in the world - Anand, Kramnik or 
Topalov - I replied: ‘To all appearances, 
Kramnik, although on sum of successes any 
of the three could claim to be considered 
No.2. But this does not mean that each of 
them would be able to win a match against 
Karpov, because match play is a quite differ­
ent matter.’
I also touched on the forthcoming match
192

Second Peak
with Karpov: ‘Here everything rests on my 
own moral obligations: I think that the world 
champion should defend his title every two 
years. Who should I now play against? For the 
public today I simply have no other opponent 
than Karpov: after all, he is the FIDE world 
champion, having won a certain parallel 
cycle. But now, after missing Linares, he is 
simply obliged to win the very strong tour­
nament in Dos Hermanas...’
However the Dos Hermanas tournament 
in April 1997 produced a different outcome: 
1-2. Anand and Kramnik - 6 out of 9; 3-5. 
Salov, Karpov and Topalov - 5, etc. It is note­
worthy that after Karpov lost to Kramnik in 
the third round, I received from Las Palmas a 
completely new proposal - to play a match 
with the winner of a match-toumament of 
four or six leading grandmasters!
Of course, I supported this idea: who 
would dispute the legitimacy of such a chal­
lenger? And at the end of Dos Hermanas, 
senor Rentero, the ‘father’ of Linares, also 
made a suggestion: instead of the usual 
tournament, the following year he proposed 
staging a four-cycle match-toumament of 
the four leading grandmasters in the world, 
and he named me, Kramnik, Anand and 
Topalov, i.e. the top four on rating.
Nevertheless, the hope of organizing a 
match of the ‘two Ks’ remained until mid­
summer.
Quality Control of the Champion
Double-Round Super-Tournament in Nov­
gorod (10-23 June 1997): l. Kasparov -  6V2 
out of 10; 2. Kramnik - 6; 3. Short - 5; 4. 
Bareev - 4V2; 5-6. Topalov and Gelfand - 4.
The Novgorod ‘tournament of six’, which 
reached category 20, a record for Russia, 
provoked a particular stir, since before it I 
suffered an absurd and highly painful defeat
in my second match with the computer Deep 
Blue - 2V2SV2 (New York, 3-11 May 1997). 
The colossus was shaken! And no wonder: 
throughout the spring I had been engaged 
not in chess, but in politics - I was helping 
general Alexander Lebed; we even created 
the ‘Third Force' coalition...
Yuri Vasiliev: 'As one well-known grand­
master joked, the match with Deep Blue 
slightly spoiled the champion’s brand. The 
sporting world is so arranged, that previous 
successes, even the most prestigious, are 
instantly forgotten, if you stumble even only 
once. A 'document verification’ of the world 
champion was expected, or more precisely - a 
verification of his ‘human face’: had not his 
creative face been changed beyond recogni­
tion by the skirmish with the monstrous force 
from the other world? Was this the same 
person as in Las Palmas and Linares?
‘Whereas in New York, Kasparov was tested 
by Deep Blue, in Novgorod the challengers 
were intending to arrange a quality control 
of the champion. Would he pass it? Garry did. 
Descending on to the stage of the ‘Lord 
Novgorod the Great’ from the unearthly, 
dizzying heights of the battle with the elec­
tronic monster (there it was a completely 
different nervous tension and a completely 
different game), the champion as though 
infected his opponents with some kind of 
unknown virus: it is probable that none of the 
participants will remember such a parade of 
mistakes and crazy oversights! Initially the 
number of decisive games was simply fright­
ening! White was rampant: after the first 
cycle he was leading lO-ll’
Again, as four months earlier in Linares, 
my main rival was Vladimir Kramnik. At the 
start he suffocated his contemporary Topa­
lov in the style of the young Karpov, while I 
won an instructive game against Boris 
Gelfand.

However, the remainder of the tourna­
ment brought me a mass of disappoint­
ments. With White I was unable to beat 
Topalov, and with Black, after overstepping 
the mark, I only just gained a draw with 
Bareev. But the main unpleasantness oc­

before which I unexpectedly became the sole

Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
leader, since the day before Kramnik had lost

Playing White against Vladimir Kramnik, I 
was eager to gain revenge for my loss in the 
first cycle, in order to win the tournament by 
a convincing margin and at the same time 
again move ahead in the score of our ‘classi­
cal’ games (which at that time was +3-3=7). 
After l  e4 c5 we played a variation of the 
Rauzer Attack, known from the game Shirov- 
Kramnik (Linares 1997), and after employing 
a powerful novelty (18 c3! and 19 Ji.c2!) I 
gained an enormous lead on the clock and a 
completely winning position. But then I did 
something terrible.

202

Second Peak
And so, in Novgorod 1997 Kramnik once 
again confirmed his reputation as a difficult 
opponent! In the last round he tried for 
seven hours to breach Gelfand’s defences, 
but on the 66th move he missed chances of 
winning. And I, after drawing with Short, 
nevertheless took sole first place and won 
my third ‘super’ in six months.
‘I do not have the right to play as badly as 
on this occasion in Novgorod’, I said after the 
tournament. 'There were only isolated 
episodes and two whole games where I 
played well. I under-performed. But even in 
the terrible state in which I was after the 
match with Deep Blue, all the same I am 
superior to everyone else as regards store of 
ideas. Incidentally, I also played to my rating 
-2820!
‘I see missed opportunities and, what is 
important, I see my opponents’ play. A 
match with a computer gives a very distinct 
feeling: the absence of the right to make a 
mistake. My calculation of variations is now 
veTy good, and in long variations I did not 
make mistakes. My mistakes were elemen­
tary oversights. Simply some nervous de­
rangement due to a lack of mental 
strength... Now I will rest, hold my tradi­
tional training session by the sea - and with 
new strength I will aim for the 2850 mark!’
Meanwhile, having enlisted the support 
of the International Olympic Committee, 
FIDE was preparing for its first knock-out 
championship with 128 participants and the 
unprecedented prize fund of five million 
dollars. As tempting compensation for the 
wrecked unification match, llyumzhinov 
invited Karpov and me directly into the 
semi-finals! Just think: the two losers of the 
semi-final matches of four (!) games were 
each due $384,000, and the finalists in the 
match of six (!) games - $768,000 (to the 
loser) and $1.37 million (to the winner).
On returning from Novgorod to Moscow, 
on 27 June I sent the International Olympic 
Committee President, Juan Antonio Sama­
ranch, my official refusal to play in the FIDE 
knock-out championship: ‘The proposed 
formula breaks with tradition and, unfortu­
nately, devalues the title of world cham­
pion... I have already stated publicly, un- 
equivocably and unambigously, that under 
no circumstances will I take part in this 
event.’ Ilyumzhinov’s FIDE needed ten whole 
years to admit that the world title can be 
contested only in long matches!
During the Novgorod tournament I said 
that ‘the idea of the match with Karpov was 
not yet dead’, and I promised within a 
month to reply more precisely. But on 21 
July, a week after Dortmund 1997 (l. Kram­
nik - 6V2 out of 9; 2. Anand - 5V2; 3-4. Topa­
lov and Ivanchuk - 5; 5. J.Polgar - 4Vz; 6-8. 
Gelfand, Karpov and Short - 4), I was forced 
to declare: ‘The match with Karpov, unfor­
tunately, will not happen. I did not expect 
this and to the last moment I thought that 
everything was normal. Before the tourna­
ment in Dortmund, Karpov and I even 
rewrote our agreement... As never before in 
my life, I was rooting for Karpov, but his 
result had an adverse effect on our sponsors’ 
frame of mind.’
34-year-old ‘Veteran’
International Tournament in Tilburg (26 
September - 9 October 1997): 1-3. Svidler, 
Kasparov and Kramnik - 8 out of 11; 4-5. 
Adams and Leko - 7; 6. J.Polgar - 6; 7. Shirov - 
5; 8-9. Lautier and van Wely - 4V2; 10. Onis- 
chuk - 4; 11. Piket - 2'A; 12. Shaked - IV2.
After completing a summer training ses­
sion in Croatia, where after staying on Red 
Island for four years we moved to the de­
lightful seaside town of Makarska, I flew to
203

Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
distant Buenos Aires and on 6-7 September I 
gave a double-round clock simultaneous 
against the Argentinian team (8V2-3V2). And 
at the end of September Dohoian and I set 
off to the Dutch town of Tilburg, where I had 
not been for six years.
Yuri Vasiliev: 'Before the start of the tradi­
tional tournament in Tilburg everyone was 
asking: who will win this time - Kasparov or 
Kramnik? Before this Garry had finished 
ahead of Vladimir in the spring in Linares, 
and in the summer in Novgorod. What would 
happen in the autumn? Kasparov was in the 
unaccustomed role of tournament veteran - 
as the organisers repeated several times, he 
was invited in the role of 'professor', setting 
examinations (autumn term?) for the tal­
ented young players.’
Sergey Makarychev: ‘This Tilburg looked 
rather more modest than the hugely strong 
super-toumaments of recent times, but it had 
an intriguing aspect: the 34-year-old ‘vet­
eran’ Garry Kasparov was testing the young. 
True, two of these young players - Vladimir 
Kramnik and Peter Svidler - are already so 
strong, that they themselves are capable of 
testing anyone. Together with Kasparov they 
comprised a truly Herculean trio, scoring 50% 
of all the wins in the tournament!’
For me this tournament proved difficult 
not even due to its youthful nature, but 
rather because of the uneven line-up. Thus 
the world junior champion, the American Tal 
Shaked (who was admitted instead of Topa­
lov) suffered eight defeats with three draws. 
After easily beating him in the first round, 
Kramnik joked: 'For me the expression 'to 
play in Tal style' has taken on a new mean­
ing.’ It was clear that in Tilburg the player to 
succeed would be the one of the favourites 
who dealt most severely with the outsiders.
The start went very well - 3 out of 3! With 
Black I struck van Wely’s position a decisive
blow as early as the 15th move, and with 
White I confidently outplayed Judit Polgar. 
As her second Lev Psakhis admitted, ‘when 
you are preparing for the ‘white’ Kasparov, 
you want to metamorphose into a tiny little 
insect, as in Franz Kafka’s novel, and hide 
somewhere far away...’ Then in 20 moves I 
disposed of Shaked, after employing a 
valuable novelty in a Grunfeld (cf. Game 
N0.16 in Kasparov vs. Karpov 1988-2009, 
note to White’s 8th move). I decided to 
return to this ‘well-forgotten’ defence after 
Novgorod, having become disillusioned with 
the King's Indian, and at a summer training 
session I began analyzing the topical varia­
tions with my trainers.
In the fourth round I had a complicated 
game against the young Ukrainian (later - 
American) Onischuk. I obtained a favourable 
bishop endgame, but I missed some winning 
chances and Black saved himself. All my 
rivals also drew, so that the status quo was 
maintained: Kasparov - 3'/i out of 4; Kram­
nik - 3; Svidler, Adams and Leko - 21/2.
After a free day came the fifth round, in 
which I had Black against Alexey Shirov. We 
always had uncompromising duels, most 
often in the Sicilian Najdorf. And on this 
occasion too we played a game which, 
although by no means error-free, was very 
interesting.

213

Carry Kasparov on Carry Kasparov: Part Three
would have been best for Svidler. At that time 
Peter was playing very freshly and resource­
fully - and was steadily rising. His finest hour 
could have been the FIDE knock-out champi­
onship in that December, but in the quarter­
final he suffered a very painful defeat against 
Adams. After this Svidler somehow drooped, 
and although he continued to post good 
results, he didn’t quite reach the leading roles 
on the world stage.
As for Karpov, after the collapse of our 
match the only thing left for him was to 
defend his title of FIDE champion. Especially 
since at the end of the year he received from 
FIDE another fantastic ‘present’: with 128 
participants, in view of my non-participation, 
he was allowed directly into the super-final! 
And this despite the protests of many well- 
known grandmasters - Kramnik even refused 
to take part.
The main part of the first FIDE world 
championship on the knock-out system took 
place from 9-30 December 1997 in Groningen 
and produced a deserved triumph for Vishy 
Anand, who in mini-matches defeated Niko- 
lic, Khalifman, Almasi, Shirov, Gelfand and 
Adams. And already on 1 January 1998 - just 
imagine! - in Lausanne his super-final match 
began with Karpov, who had flown in there 
from the Canary Islands.
And so the chess world witnessed FIDE’s 
unprecedented ‘Lausanne experiment’ - a 
battle between the freshly rested 46-year-old 
Karpov and the 28-year-old Anand, worn out 
by three weeks of play. Vishy drew on his last 
reserves and, by winning the sixth game, 
levelled the score: 3-3. But for the tie-break he 
no longer had any strength: Karpov won both 
rapid games and retained the title of FIDE 
champion, which, however, provoked a mixed 
reaction in the chess world.
‘A colossal and undeserved handicap!’, wrote 
the well-known trainer Mark Dvoretsky. ‘At
present, and this is not only my view, Anand is 
far stronger than Karpov and he would surely 
have been successful if the play had been on 
equal terms (with both players equally fresh or 
equally tired). Karpov has legally become world 
champion, but in the eyes of almost all chess 
players he effectively isn’t.’
This last statement was confirmed very 
quickly by the results of Wijk aan Zee, Janu­
ary 1998: 1-2. Kramnik and Anand - 8V2 out 
of 13; 3-5. Shirov, Timman and Adams - 7V2; 
6-10. Karpov, J.Polgar, Gelfand, Topalov and 
Piket - 6V2, etc. Nevertheless llyumzhinov 
declared: ‘The title 'world champion’ is 
registered legally and belongs to FIDE. The 
world champion is the player who has won 
the world championship, and it has been won 
by Karpov. Although there are players with a 
higher rating.’ I should remind you of the top 
of the rating list at that moment: Kasparov - 
2825, Kramnik - 2790, Anand - 2770, Ivan­
chuk and Topalov - 2740, Karpov - 2735.
Crisis Point
Double-Round Super-Tournament in Linares 
(21 February - 10 March 1998): 1. Anand - 
7V2 out of 12; 2. Shirov - 7; 3-4. Kasparov 
and Kramnik - 6V2; 5. Svidler - 5V2; 6. Ivan­
chuk - 5; 7. Topalov - 4.
After losing my opponent in a match for 
the world championship, I also lost my 
mental equilibrium. After a series of tour­
nament triumphs it suddenly became 
unclear what to do next. Through lack of 
funds the PCA had ceased to function back 
in 1997. But I was far more depressed by the 
fact that FIDE had dared to break an age-old 
tradition, by replacing matches with the 
lottery of the ‘tournament of a hundred’.
Many realised that the knock-out system 
was unsuitable for determining the strong­
est player in the world (after five such

championships this was also realised by 
FIDE), but the enormous prize fund, cleverly 
called a ‘distribution of monetary aid’, 
pushed all sensible arguments into the 
background. In the absence of an opponent 
and a qualifying cycle my title was as though 
hanging in mid-air, and I felt isolated.
But here after Lausanne Karpov still de­
clared himself the sole champion! When the 
Sport Express correspondent reminded him 
about the memorandum we had signed, 
where he had ‘acknowledged Kasparov to be 
the world champion, and himself to be FIDE 
world champion’, Karpov said: 'That memo­
randum was private... Kasparov was the world 
champion, but he lost his title when he refused 
to defend it. Today I am the world champion, 
and he is an impostor, even with his rating of 
2825. Well, so what? He does not play in the 
official FIDE championships. As soon as Fischer 
stopped playing in the FIDE system, he lost his 
title. The only difference between them is that 
Fischer has not played for 25 years, whereas 
with Kasparov it is only five.’
Soon, on 30 January 1998,1 replied to him 
in an interview in the same newspaper: 
‘Now, at the finish of Wijk aan Zee, it has 
finally become clear to everyone how Karpov 
is now playing... Some are now calling me an 
“impostor"? Well, it is time I played a match 
for the world championship. The question is 
how this match should be regarded: as a 
political or a chess event? If the former, I can 
again play against Karpov. But it is unlikely 
that money would be found for such a 
match: Karpov’s play is now too weak. And, 
secondly, I would like to regard a match for 
the crown as a chess event, not a political 
one. Therfore I will play against the strong­
est challenger. The circle of players from 
which he will be determined is very limited. 
Soon all will be revealed - wait for the start 
of the tournament in Linares.’
It appeared that I had managed to find a 
solution: on 21 February, at a press confer­
ence in Linares, Luis Rentero and I an­
nounced the creation of the WCC - the 
World Chess Council (headed by Rentero), 
aimed at arranging the playing of the world 
championship. In the first cycle, shortened 
because of present circumstances, the 
second and third players in the world - 
Vladimir Kramnik and Vishy Anand - were 
to be invited to play a challenger’s match of 
10 games early in the summer, with the 
winner to play me in a match of 18 games in 
the autumn (Rentero named the Andalucian 
government as its organiser and sponsor). In 
the event of one of the candidates declining, 
he would be replaced by the participant in 
the imminent ‘tournament of seven’ who 
made the best result.
Linares 1998 was the second super- 
toumament in history, after Las Palmas 
1996, of the highest, 2lst category. Unfortu­
nately, I did not prepare for it in the best 
way, but more importantly, I was quite 
unable to concentrate on the play. The 
uncertain situation with the matches, the 
constant problems and negotiations - all 
this preyed on my nerves (true, not only on 
mine). To cap it all, I immediately went down 
with flu and for a long time felt unwell, 
periodically running a high temperature.
Nevertheless, things began quite well. 
With Black in the first round I with difficulty 
repelled Svidler’s attack in a Scheveningen 
(cf. Game No.37, note to White’s 13th move) 
and at the end I even seized the initiative, 
but lacked the energy to develop it. I was 
free in the second round, and in the third I 
had White against Vishy Anand, who before 
this had won against Shirov and Svidler.
MakaTychev: ‘So, Anand was on 2 out of 2! 
It need hardly be said that Garry arrived for 
the game, aiming only for a win. For the flu-

was most opportune. As the press wrote, Kas­

temperature and absolutely starving, was still 
the same Kasparov - a merciless lion!’

Strangely enough, this was my only win in 
the tournament: after it I assumed the 
unaccustomed role of ‘drawing king’, all my 
remaining ten games concluding peacefully! 
And after this loss, which was also Vishy’s 
only one, for a long time he was unable to 
Tegain his composure and he lost the lead.
Three rounds before the finish, the lead­
ing trio looked like this: Shirov - 6V2 out of 
10; Anand and Kasparov - 5 out of 9. But 
then Shirov lost to Svidler, while Anand 
competently picked off the badly performing 
Ivanchuk and Topalov. Fighting draws in the 
last Tound games Kramnik-Anand and 
Shirov-Kasparov produced the final results:
Anand - ‘plus three’, Shimv - ‘plus two’, 
KTamnik and Kaspamv - ‘plus one’.
Kramnik’s second, gTandmasteT Sergey 
Dolmatov: ‘This was how the tournament 
went for Kasparov. Against him all the par­
ticipants played with particular accuracy. 
With Black they kept away from lines deeply 
studied by Garry and avoided dangerous 
positions. And with White they often did not 
even try to initiate a serious fight, but above 
all preferred safety. Therefore with Black 
Kasparov effectively did not have any win­
ning chances in even a single game.
'A typical example was the last round 
game with Shirov. Kasparov employed a 
novelty (cf. Game No.37, note to White’s 6th 
move - G.K.) and equalised - a normal 
occurrence. Playing White, Shirov avoided 
any risk and, guided by tournament consid­
erations, forced a draw... Previously Garry 
often won with Black thanks to his splendid 
opening preparation. But even then I thought 
that sooner or later the ‘Day cf Judgement’ 
would arrive. And here in Linares the oppo­
nents skilfully neutralised one of the impor­
tant components of Kasparov’s succcesses.’
HoweveT, the next year in Linares directly 
the opposite picture was observed. Therefore 
my comparative failure in March 1998 was 
by no means a ‘Day of Judgement’, but the 
consequence of my illness and a short-term 
creative crisis.
Signs of a Tetum to form were aheady 
seen in May, when in Sophia I white-washed 
Topalov in a rapidplay match (4-0), and in 
Tel Aviv I crushed the Israeli team in a dou­
ble-round clock simultaneous (7-l). But in 
the middle of June I slumped: in Leon in an 
‘advanced chess’ match with Topalov I won 
only 'on penalties’ (3-3; blitz: 2V2-1V2), and in 
a rapidplay tournament in Frankfurt I fin­

escape from the crisis, intensive and con­

In the meantime Anand declined to take

Thus in the summer of 1998 I spent a 
month and a half intensively preparing for 
my next match for the world championship. I 
was helped by Dokhoian and Shakarov, and 
towards the end we were joined by Boris 
Gelfand (who, incidentally, then won the 
August tournament in Polanica ZdToj, ahead 
of Shirov, Ivanchuk and Karpov). By the 
autumn I had calmed down and become 
stronger physically, and I had significantly 
renewed my store of opening ideas.
But Rentero reneged on his obligations. 
Already in Cazoria he experienced obvious 
problems in paying the prizes: Kramnik 
received only a third of the promised sum, 
while Shirov, who was due part of the two 
million prize fund of the main match, was left 
altogether without a cent. My losses were 
also considerable. As it transpired, the WCC 
project collapsed due to the retirement of an 
important official in the Andalucian govern­
ment, on the support of whom Rentero was 
counting. An attempt to negotiate with the 
Catalonian government also achieved noth­
ing. AfteT this sad story I realised that global 
plans cannot be lowered to a municipal level!
Feeling a moral obligation to play the
match with Shirov, with the help of my 
manager Owen Williams I began seeking new 
sponsors. The task was complicated by the 
fact that my opponent had a terrible score 
against me (-7=6), was rated a hundred 
points loweT, and had also finished last at 
Dortmund in July 1998.
Nevertheless a serious offer arrived from 
Los Angeles to stage the match in November 
with a prize fund of one million dollars - 
$650,000 to the winner and $350,000 to the 
loser. This was far better than nothing. But 
Shirov initially stated that he would not play 
for less than $400,000 in the event of defeat, 
and then he demanded immediate bank 
guarantees. My lawyer worked flat out and 
quickly prepared a contract, and the organis­
ers agreed to transfer the money to a bank 
account in installments over a period of 30 
days. But Shirov obstinately said: ‘No!’ - and 
out match collapsed.
While hope still lingered I played a training 
match of six games with Jan Timman (Pra­
gue, 5-13 September 1998). The hall with 
seating foT 700 was full every day, and foT the 
last two games it was unable to accommo­
date all those interested. The final score 4-2 
was exactly the same as in our first match in 
1985. At the closing ceremony I commented: 
‘It would appear that since that time the 
relative strengths of the two players have not 
changed’. The organiser of the Prague match, 
the indefatigable former GMA President 
Bessel Kok, told me that he wanted to organ­
ise a match foT the world championship. 
However, not the duel with Shirov, but one in 
the future, aimed at 'changing the current 
abnormal situation, involving the possession 
of the champion's title'.
At the end of September Kok approached 
FIDE and me with a sensational offeT to stage 
a ‘1999 match for the world championship’ 
with a prize fund of three million dollars

Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
between the ‘generally acknowledged world 
champion Garry Kasparov’ and the winner of 
the forthcoming FIDE knock-out champion­

to me, but first I was nevertheless intending

Thanks to Rentero I was left without any 
tournaments: the vacancies at Tilburg in 
October and Wijk aan Zee in January had 
already been filled. I was obliged to restrict 
myself to analytical work with my trainers 
and blitz games with grandmaster Sergey

My only appearance at the end of the year 
was a colourful blitz match of 24 games with 
Vladimir Kramnik (Moscow, 27-28 November 
1998). At the start I took the lead - 3-1, but 
then I suddenly ‘floundered’ and in the end I 
equalised the score only with difficulty: 12- 
12! The match did not earn me any laurels in 
this confrontation with a difficult opponent: 
Kramnik once again ascertained that he 
could fight against me. But on the whole I 
was content, since I felt that I was gaining 
momentum.
In addition, a long-standing dream of mine 
had been realised: to see how interesting 
such a match could be for internet users. For 
the first time all the games were broadcast in 
real time throughout the world! I intended to 
make use of this experience in the work of my 
recently founded chess site ‘Kasparov Club’. 
At that time my interest in Russian politics 
had cooled and I was seriously carried away 
with promoting chess via the internet.
Record Winning Series
International Tournament in Wijk aan Zee 
(15-31 January 1999): 1. Kasparov - 10 out of

I played in Wijk aan Zee 1999 only by 
chance: the tournament line-up was already 
decided. The organisers turned down a 
suggestion by my manager to include me as 
a 15th participant, with a reduced appear­
ance fee. But, fortunately, at the last minute 
Short withdrew (his wife had given birth), 
and I took the free place.
Towards the end of the 20th century the 
traditional festivals in Northern Holland 
became an annual gathering of the world 
chess elite, although since the 1960s the 
likes of Botvinnik, Keres, Bronstein, Geller, 
Spassky, Korchnoi, Tal, Portisch and Po- 
lugaevsky had all played here. For many 
years the venue was in Beverwijk - a small 
town with a population of about 40,000, and 
from 1968 it was moved to its suburb Wijk 
aan Zee - a district with two or three thou­
sand inhabitants. The sponsor has invariably 
been the local steel works, the owner of 
which was the Hoogovens company, from 
2000 - Corns, and now Tata Steel.
Previously I had not played in Wijk aan 
Zee for two reasons. First, because of the 
tournament’s insufficiently high category (it 
rose during the 1990s). Second, although I 
was a hardened Olympiad fighter, the ‘big 
bazaar’ atmosphere seemed inconducive to 
creative play. It is hard to concentrate when 
in one enormous hall five tournaments are 
taking place simultaneously: A, B, C and 
mass opens. But gradually I became accus­
tomed to this gigantic ant-hill and in the 
press I even expressed my admiration: ‘In 
the hall there are 500 people - a grandiose 
spectacle! The spirit of chess amateurishness 
reigns. The Dutch manage this brilliantly.’
The key intrigue of the tournament was
2 2 2

Second Peak
said to be my first meeting in 11 months 
with Vishy Anand, who in the previous year 
had gained a series of brilliant victories and 
was regarded as ‘the main opponent of the 
13th world champion’. Of a thousand chess 
fans questioned on the Internet, almost 50% 
predicted first place for Anand, half less for 
me, and a further half less for Shirov and 
Kramnik.
Of course, before the start I experienced 
both tension and excitement, but even more
- a severe tournament hunger! I was in an 
excellent mood, since I felt I had a great 
reserve of strength and fresh ideas. Also 
reassuring was the No.l which I selected at 
the drawing of lots.
True, in the first round I had a quiet draw 
with Ivanchuk: Black gradually equalised in 
a ‘Karlsbad’. But in the second round I was 
able to crush the Sveshnikov Variation as 
performed by the 26-year-old Loek van Wely, 
who in the future was to win the Dutch 
Championship many times.

A good start - l'/i out of 2, but Anand be­

The following day, 18 January, was free, 
and in the A group the organisers arranged 
a blitz tournament (only Shirov, who had to
see a dentist, was replaced by the local 
master Bosboom). Many were expecting 
Anand to win, but I started with 7 out of 7, 
and after a draw with Kramnik I again won - 
8V2 out of 9! And although I then contrived 
to lose with White to Bosboom, in the end I 
scored 101/2 out of 13 and took first place by 
a margin of one and a half points ahead of 
Anand and Ivanchuk, whom I beat in our 
individual games (from the year 2000, for 
some reason, such blitz tournaments were 
no longer held).
After such a powerful stimulus I felt very 
much on form. In the third round I beat 
Yermolinsky with Black, after castling queen- 
side in the Griinfeld - a very rare occurrence 
(cf. Game No.67, note to White’s 10th move), 
and I caught the leader - Anand. Topalov 
and Kramnik were half a point behind.
In the fourth round came an unforgetta­
ble duel with Veselin Topalov, the fantastic 
finish to which was published in all the 
world's chess magazines. Hans Ree: 'Those 
who were fortunate enough to be present at 
this game will talk about it to their children 
and grandchildren, and these stories will 
continue as long as chess is alive!’

isers announced that this game could al­
ready be called the most brilliant in the
tournament, while the local correspondents 
christened it a ‘diamond’ and suggested that 
it would be the best game in 1999, even 
though the year had just begun. Later the 
experts deemed it to be the best in the 74th 
volume of Informator.
That day Anand also won, and we both 
reached 3V2 out of 4. In the fifth round I 
outplayed Reinderman in a tense battle and 
finally took the sole lead. Then I won a 
slightly better ending against Piket, who got 
into very severe time-trouble, and I in­
creased the gap: Kasparov - 5V2 out of 6; 
Anand - 4V2; Kramnik -  4.
The seventh round battle with the WCC 
challenger Alexey Shirov was ultra-crucial, in 
view of our wrecked match. Shirov blamed 
me, although in the episode involving the 
WCC I had suffered no less than him and in 
return I had ‘unearthed’ the match in Los 
Angeles, which was rejected by my oppo­
nent. And when Kok suggested I play a six- 
game match with Judit Polgar in the sum­
mer with a prize fund of $200,000,1 declined 
in favour of Alexey...
From the press: ‘The game created height­
ened interest with the exacting public, who 
crowded round the barrier separating the 
masses from the elite of the grandiose festi­
val. The importance of the occasion was 
recognised by the numerous journalists, the 
participants in the super-tournament, and 
above all by the players themselves: they were 
extremely tense and composed.’

0-1
‘A battle on a grand scale!’ (Makarychev).
By winning against Shirov I set a personal 
record - for the first time I overcame my 
‘curse of five wins’. Usually after them there 
followed either a loss, or bad play, but here - 
a sixth successive win! And after it came a 
seventh, against the future FIDE knock-out 
champion Kasimdzhanov (at that time no 
one yet had any suspicion of his grandeur: 
he had qualified for the main tournament 
from group B).
And so, this longest winning series, not 
counting the incidental first place in the 
blitz tournament, produced the best start in 
my career - 7'A out of 8 (my ‘tournament 
rating’ crossed the 3000 mark!). Anand was 
points behind, and Kramnik 2V2.
However, I was extremely tired and I felt 
that the storm clouds were gathering over 
me. The tension grew from game to game, 
and in the ninth round the thunder charges 
reached the absolute maximum. In my game 
with the ‘new Dutchman' Ivan Sokolov I 
suffered a temporary fogging of the mind, a 
kind of ‘short circuit’.

A terrible rout! Although I was still lead­

which we played each other, was after a free

In the 11th round I had Black against 
Timman, who had analysed my seventh 
round game with Shirov and had prepared a 
surprise - 13 Sell (cf. Game N0.51, note to 
White’s 13th move). But after 6 ,&e3 I devi­

White’s 6th move). From the press: ‘Appar­
ently Timman derived great pleasure from 
this joke game, since later all evening he 
drank beer in the press centre and laughed 
about how he had fooled Kasparov.'
In the meantime Anand beat van Wely, 
and two rounds before the finish the situa­
tion became much sharper: Vishy was only 
half a point behind me, and I still had to play 
Svidler and Kramnik. In the 12th round 
Anand equalised with Black against Yer- 
molinsky - a draw on the 20th move. And I 
had White against Peter Svidler, who, I will 
remind you, in Tilburg 1997 inflicted on me 
my only defeat, thus depriving me of sole first 
place. It was time for the debt to be repaid.

2 4 2

Second Peak
The last round began in the morning, 
which was not very good for me, but even 
worse for my opponent, Kramnik, who in 
addition was suffering from flu. We contin­
ued our duel in the Meran, begun in our 
blitz match, and strictly in accordance with 
analysis I confidently secured a draw.
Meanwhile, in a stem fight Anand won 
with White against Topalov and ended up 
on ‘plus five’, without any losses! He played 
very creatively in the tournament and 
posted virtually the best result in his career - 
but he only finished second. I think that this 
demoralised Vishy before Linares.
After Wijk aan Zee there again began to 
be talk about organising a match between 
us. At the closing ceremony the tournament 
director stated: ‘We are proud that our 
tournament has opened the way to a genu­
ine match for the world championship.’ And 
the press wrote: ‘Now, when Kasparov and 
Anand have demonstrated such superiority, 
the idea of staging a world championship 
with the participation of one hundred players 
looks completely pointless.’
Not surprisingly, around that time Bessel 
Kok modified his plans. Earlier he had been 
proposing to stage a match between me and 
the winner of the forthcoming FIDE knock­
out championship. Now Kok decided to 
arrange in the autumn of 1999 a match 
simply between player No.l and player No.2.
My Stellar Linares
Double-Round Super-Tournament in Linares 
(20 February -10 March 1999): 1. Kasparov -  
101/2 out of 14; 2-3. Kramnik and Anand - 8; 
4. Leko - 6V2; 5-6. Topalov and Ivanchuk - 6; 
7-8. Svidler and Adams - 5V2.
Just three weeks after Wijk aan Zee my 
rivalry with Anand continued in Linares, 
which as usual assembled a brilliant, even
line-up. This category 20 super-tournament 
included all the previous year's ‘2700s’, apart 
from Shirov (who held a grudge against 
senor Rentero, although the latter was no 
longer involved, having been seriously 
injured in a car crash), plus Adams and the 
burgeoning 19-year-old Leko.
Two cycles, 14 rounds - by today’s stan­
dards, a marathon distance! Before the start 
I was planning to score ‘plus four’, which 
was the limit of my self-esteem: this should 
have sufficed for first place, for which I was 
hoping after Wijk aan Zee. And almost to the 
middle of the tournament everything fol­
lowed the planned schedule - nothing 
heralded the final super-result.
In the first round I had White against 
Svidler and I decided not play 1 d4 (as in 
Wijk aan Zee), but after 1 e41 did not achieve 
anything in a Ruy Lopez - a draw on the 
32nd move. But in the second round unex­
pectedly quickly I seized the initiative with 
Black in my game with Vassily Ivanchuk.

It was a pity that the gradiose idea 13 b4 
did not produce a win, but I sensed that I was 
on a creative upsurge. Silvio Danialov: 'Every­
one had the very strong impression: both had 
demonstrated chess of the highest level! After 
the game Kasparov was very sullen and angry, 
and he left quickly. Vishy was beaming with 
delight, he was very happy!’
In the fourth round I had White against 
Kramnik and after l  d4 £if6 2 c4 e6 3 £>c3 
iLb4 4 Wc2 I was unable to breach the ultra­
solid set-up 4-d5 5 cxd5 Wxd5 - a draw as 
early as the 2lst move. But the next day with 
Black I defeated the leader, Adams, outplay­
ing him in a difficult, nervy battle in the 
Closed Variation of the Sicilian, and at last I 
was leading the race: Kasparov - 3Vi out of 
5; Svidler and Adams - 3; Anand, Kramnik 
and Topalov - 2yi.
In the sixth round Leko held out against 
me in a slightly inferior endgame. In addi­
tion, the chasing pair changed: Anand won 
against Svidler, and Kramnik against Adams.
At the finish of the first cycle I had Black 
against an aggressively inclined Veselin 
Topalov, who unusually had scored six 
draws. With this game, which took place 
after a free day, there began one of the most 
brilliant winning series in my career.

After making a complicated by-passing

own queen from giving checks. I did not yet 
see a mating construction, but I sensed that 
the end was close and I became nervous.
From the press: ‘At this point Garry did

This impressive win put me in an excel­
lent mood and left me confidently leading 
after the first cycle: Kasparov - 5 out of 7; 
Kramnik and Anand - 4.
In the next round, without any respite, I 
won quite well with Black against Svidler in 
a Sicilian with 4 #xd4. Four wins in eight 
games, and all with the black pieces - this 
had never happened to me before! The lead 
over my pursuers grew to one and a half 
points.
The following day I met Vassily Ivanchuk, 
who was Black for the third game in a row. 
This was a rare instance when in a double­
cycle tournament they did not change the 
order of the rounds at the end of the first 
cycle, to avoid such a situation: Ivanchuk 
said that he was prepared to play three 
games in a row with the same colour! And in

the seventh round he beat Svidler, but in the 
eighth he missed a win against Anand, 
which seriously upset him. But I, irrespective 
of my opponent’s mental state, very much 
wanted at last to open my account with the 
white pieces.

This was my last win in ‘classical’ play 
against Ivanchuk (four draws in 2001-2003 
led to this final score in our individual meet­
ings: +10-4=19). It is amusing that immedi­
ately after the game Vassily said to his second 
that now he had to prepare properly for his 
game with the ‘tournament leader’ Kramnik. 
‘But what about Kasparov?’, some bystanders 
asked in surprise. ‘Here Kasparov is playing 
hors concours!’, explained Ivanchuk, having in 
mind the leading positions: Kasparov - 7 out 
of 9; Kramnik - 5V2; Anand - 5.
Before the tenth round there was a free 
day. I had to play Vishy Anand, and we both 
prepared thoroughly for this critical encoun­
ter, which took place on the background of 
the discussions begun with Kok about our 
match for the world title in the autumn.
Yuri Vasiliev: ‘Vishy’s camp was reinforced 
by new volunteers: grandmaster San Segundo 
arrived, and together with Elizbar Ubilava 
they spent 15 hours studying a critical posi­
tion in a topical variation of the Sicilian. But 
Kasparov and Dokhoian were also looking at 
this precise variation...’
Sergey Shipov: ‘The key moment of the sec­
ond half of the tournament. Whoever finished 
first in the final table, the individual meeting 
of the two leading players in the world was of 
great psychological and even political impor­
tance. The world champion’s lead over his 
rivals was great, but if he had lost this game, 
even first place in the tournament would not 
have quelled the fashionable discussions about 
power sharing at the chess summit.'

Razuvaev: ‘The main game of the entire 
tournament. Recently Kasparov admitted 
that stored on his computer are 3,920 origi­
nal analyses, and he added: “My preparation 
is not from variation to variation, but con­
ceptual - significantly higher than with the 
others." Therefore it should not surprise us 
that by the 27th move Anand ended up in a 
lost position.’
It was not without reason that after this 
game Alexander Roshal gave his report on 
the round the heading ‘Engineer Garry’s 
hyperboloid’. For the first time in tourna­
ment play a complicated computer analysis 
worked out at home was demonstrated at 
such depth - l6...'Brb6, lg.-.WaS and 22.. Jk,g7 
(remember also 20...1Sre7 in the game with 
Topalov). Black’s risky plan ended in com­
plete triumph, but this could hardly have 
occurred in the pre-computer era. To a 
human such counterplay seems extremely 
dubious and dangerous, but impassive 
machine calculation enabled it to be estab­
lished that White’s attack was not deadly, 
and that Black’s threats were very real.
As a result I achieved a unique result, by 
scoring five successive wins with Black, and 
all in the Sicilian Defence, which Alekhine 
once called ‘a gangster shoot-out in a dark 
room’. From the press: ‘Never before has 
there been such an instance in a tournament 
of ‘2700s’ of someone winning all their 
games with Black!’
The position in the race was now: Kas­
parov - 8 out of 10; Kramnik - 6; Anand - 5. 
In Shipov’s opinion, ‘only in the llth  round 
did the wise Kramnik make the correct move 
against the champion - 1 d4l. The outcome 
was another Griinfeld (cf. Game N0.36 in 
Kasparov vs. Karpov 1986-87, note to Black’s 
15th move), and a forced draw with a cas­
cade of sacrifices, which effectively settled 
the question of the tournament winner.
A natural slump set in, and in the 12th 
round my ‘white’ game with Adams took a 
very difficult course. After my .poor 25th 
move I lost a pawn without any particular 
compensation. But Adams could not decide 
whether to be satisfied with a draw or fry to 
win. Because of this he got into time-trouble, 
became nervous (which rarely occurred with 
him), and somehow unexpectedly lost. My 
lead over Kramnik thus increased to V/2 
points.
There were two rounds remaining, and if I 
had scored 1V2 out of 2, I would have sur­
passed the performance (greater than 3000) 
of Karpov in Linares 1994. I had hardly any 
strength left to play, but nevertheless in the 
13th round I played a fighting Sicilian draw 
with Leko (cf. Game No.93, note to White’s 
9th move), and in the 14th I almost broke the 
resistance of Veselin Toplaov, although after 
1 
3 I did not have anything from the
opening and I gained the initiative only at 
the start of the second time control.

only the strongest were playing. My rating 
shot up, far beyond the 2800 mark. I was 
also inspired by the quality of the games. I 
think that this was my most stellar Linares. 
This is what I had to say immediately after­
wards:
‘By the middle of the tournament I had 
warmed up. And I made more moves than 
anyone, i.e. I fought to the last pawn! And 
yet here 1 am the oldest player. But in fight­
ing spirit and energy reserve I am superior to 
the young! The explanation for my wins

Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
with Black is fairly simple: in recent times I 
have been exclusively reinforcing black 
openings. And the Najdorf Sicilian is a 
minefield, where you can only make one 
mistake. In my preparations for the match 
with Shirov I analysed this opening a great 
deal, because in it Shirov plays the sharpest 
lines. But the match did not take place, and 
my entire ‘black ammunition’ came into 
action in Linares and Wijk aan Zee!'
As the press wrote, the world champion’s 
winning margin provoked memories of 
Nimzowitsch’s words, which he once ex­
pressed about Alekhine: ‘He deals with us like 
inexperienced fledglings!’ However, it is 
important to note that the mini-match with 
Kramnik ended in a draw: Vladimir held his 
own even in my best tournaments!
Historic Rating
International Tournament in Sarajevo (16-26 
May 1999): 1. Kasparov - 7 out of 9; 2-3. 
Bareev and Shirov - 6; 4. Morozevich - S'A; 5. 
Adams - 5; 6. Leko - A'/r, 7. Topalov - 4; 8. 
Short - 3; 9.1.Sokolov - 2V2; 10. Timman - lV2.
The category 19 super-tournament in Sa­
rajevo was a difficult one for me for many 
reasons. Playing after triumphs such as Wijk 
aan Zee and Linares is a real test: everyone is 
expecting new resounding victories of you! 
But here it was also a short tournament with 
an uneven line-up. In addition, in Bosnia, 
where I had been in 1994 during the bomb­
ing, I had a whole army of fans, and such 
psychological pressure also cuts both ways.
In the absence of Anand and Kramnik my 
main rivals were Shirov, Bareev and the 
rapidly improving Morozevich. On this 
occasion there was no starting spurt. In the 
first round Bareev acted ultra-safely against 
the Griinfeld Defence - a draw on the 22nd 
move. In the second round I again had Black
and I obtained some advantage against 
Shirov (cf. Game N0.51, note to Black’s 12th 
move), but I was unable to squeeze out more 
than a draw.
Before the third round the leaders were 
Topalov - 2 out of 2; Morozevich and Shirov
- lV2. It was time to begin accelerating, 
seeing that against my next opponent - 
Nigel Short - things usually went well.

#h7+ 1-0
‘Despite the result, mention should be 
made of the boldness and coolness displayed 
by Short, who resolved to (and did!) go in for 
a grand battle with Kasparov. His reward 
was a winning position, but in time-trouble 
it was once again the stronger player who 
was lucky.’ (Shipov).
An uneven, but fascinating game. This 
was my last ‘classical’ win against Short - 
two draws in 2000 established the final 
score in our games: +21-2=27.
That same day Bareev crushed Topalov, 
Morozevich did the same to Shirov, and the 
leading group now looked like this: Moro- 
zevich - 2'A out of 3; Kasparov, Bareev, 
Topalov and Adams - 2. In the fourth round 
all the games were drawn (mine in a Griin- 
feld with Topalov), in the fifth I outplayed 
Ivan Sokolov in a very tense struggle, gaining 
revenge on him for Wijk aan Zee, and in the 
sixth I drew in a Najdorf with Leko.
Three rounds before the finish the out­
come of the tournament still looked com­
pletely unclear: Kasparov, Shirov, Bareev and 
Adams - 4 out of 6; Morozevich - 3'A- The 
time for decisive battles had arrived.
In the seventh round came my first ‘clas­
sical’ meeting with Alexander Morozevich. 
After achieving nothing with White from the 
opening, I gradually assumed the initiative 
and for a long time the game balanced 
between a win and a draw, but in the end I 
won the endgame. And, finally, I felt com­
pletely liberated - the next day I confidently
beat Timman in a Griinfeld, after sacrificing 
the exchange (cf. Game N0.19 in Kasparov vs. 
Karpov 1986-87, note to White’s 12th move).
This was the position of the leaders before 
the last round: Kasparov - 6 out of 8; Bareev 
and Shirov - s'A- Since at the finish my rivals 
were playing each other, in my game with 
Michael Adams a draw would have been 
quite satisfactory. But I wanted to conclude 
the tournament on a high note, for which I 
chose the newly-fashionable Scotch.
