Thanks to this third successive win I in­
creased my lead over my pursuers, scored 
‘plus five’ and reached a new historic rating 
mark - 2851. Despite rating inflation, this 
record stood for 13 years (!), until at the end 
of 2012 it was broken by the phenomenal 
Norwegian Magnus Carlsen.
The tournament in Sarajevo was an un­
commonly fighting one (the number of
decisive games exceeded 50%!), but I didn’t 
display the same boldness as in Wijk aan Zee 
and Linares. Evgeny Bareev: ‘The participants 
had the feeling that Kasparov was playing at 
roughly 25% of his desire. When it was 
needed, he would develop additional mo­
mentum. Eye-witnesses reckon that his mood 
here was very different from that in Linares 
and Wijk aan Zee. There he was an angry, 
hungry wolf, whereas here the wolf was 
good-natured, as in a cartoon film. But even 
so the good-natured wolf devoured quite a 
number of sheep.’
A month later I took part in a four-cycle 
rapidplay match-toumament (Frankfurt am 
Main, 29 June - 2 July 1999), staged as part of 
a grandiose festival to mark the 75th anniver­
sary of the Frankfurt West Chess Club. As is 
now clear, this tournament with its proud 
title Siemens Giants was unique in its way: in 
it participated only the classical world cham­
pions - Karpov (12th), Kasparov (13th), Kram­
nik (14th) and Anand (15th). At the time the 
last two were still called ‘crown princes’.
The organisers did indeed regard this 
‘battle of the giants’ as the unofficial rapid- 
play world championship. The reference 
material published beforehand contained 
information about the relative scores of the 
participants in all forms of chess. I had the 
best overall percentage - 54, Kramnik was 
on 51, Anand - 47 (because of his poor score 
with me), and Karpov - also 47 (but he had a 
worse score against all three).
We played one cycle a day for four days, 
i.e. three games with a 25-minute time 
control each day. I went through the whole 
event undefeated; in the first cycle I unex­
pectedly easily beat Anand with Black (cf. 
Game No.42 in Kasparov vs. Karpov 1986-87, 
note to Black’s 12th move), in the third cycle 
I defeated Kramnik (Game No.l2l), and in 
the fourth cycle - Karpov (Game No.45 in
280

Second Peak
Kasparov vs. Karpov 1988-2009). A win in all 
the mini-matches with a score of 2Vi-l'/i 
brought me overall success: 1. Kasparov -  
7'/i out of 12; 2-3. Anand and Kramnik - 6; 4 
Karpov - 4'/j. Of course, I was satisfied with 
the result, but 1 did not harbour any illusions 
regarding the quality of my play, and so I 
said: ‘This victory should not be put down as 
one of my main achievements of the year.’ 
Indeed, 1999 was one of the stellar years 
in my career: 1 won three major tourna­
ments in succession and a blitz tournament 
in Wijk aan Zee. The extreme tension of 
playing against the leading grandmasters in 
the world did not allow me to conduct all my 
games at an identically high level, but even 
while making mistakes I continued acting 
confidently and I did not lose my composure 
in unexpected and difficult situations. As a 
result, at the closing ceremony of the Frank­
furt 
Festival, 
its 
director 
Hans-Walter 
Schmitt remarked: ‘Kasparov has shown that 
he is world champion in all forms of chess - 
classical, blitz and rapid.’
In Frankfurt we all made mistakes. The 
reason was the enormous stress: they may 
have been ‘rapid’, but three games a day, 
and against such opponents! True, I was able 
to retain a big reserve of energy. The secret is 
simple. Usually my competitive year would 
begin in September, after a lengthy training 
session, and by the following summer 
fatigue would set in and a crisis would 
ensue (as, for example, in Novgorod 1997 or 
Frankfurt 1998). But the 1998/99 season 
began late for me - in January, and by the 
summer I was not yet empty in either the 
chess sense, or psychologically, or physically. 
That was the basis of my victory.
That same summer, on 21 June, there be­
gan a unique internet game ‘Kasparov 
against the world’, organised by the Micro­
soft Corporation. Yuri Dokhoian, Boris Al-
terman, the program Deep Junior and I had 
twelve hours per move, while our numerous 
opponents, taking into account discussion 
and voting, had 36 hours. And on 25 October 
1 won on the 62nd move, deep into a queen 
endgame (where Deep Junior was especially 
active). Over the 124 days of uncompromi­
sing struggle, the specially created site was 
visited by more than three million people 
from 75 of the world’s countries - unprece­
dented interest in a chess event!
I was convinced that the ‘worldwide web’ 
would open completely new opportunities 
for chess. And on the wave of the world 
boom in internet business, together with 
financial partners from Israel I set up the 
‘Kasparov Chess Online’ company, the core 
of which became the English language site 
KasparovChess.com, which greatly expanded 
the audience and content of the Russian 
language ‘Kasparov Club’.
In August of that memorable year a new 
FIDE champion emerged - the winner of the 
second knock-out championship Alexander 
Khalifman, but, alas, because of financial 
problems 
the 
Kasparov-Anand 
match 
planned for the autumn was postponed 
until the following year.

Before the next festival in Wijk aan Zee 
the previous year’s tournament was re­
membered, where I scored seven successive 
wins, but in the end Anand finished just half 
a point behind. And many were interested
281

Carry Kasparov on Carry Kasparov: Part Three
in whether there would be a new race 
between us - the probable opponents in a 
forthcoming match for the title. Immedi­
ately after the opening ceremony and the 
drawing of lots we held a joint press confer­
ence, at which we confirmed our readiness 
to play this postponed match in the autumn. 
In passing Vishy commented: '1999 was a 
good year for Kasparov, possibly the best in 
his career, but now Garry has to demonstrate 
everything anew. Therefore he is again under 
pressure.’
Naturally, I was anxious, and mainly be­
cause of my lengthy break in play, but I was 
burning with desire to repeat the previous 
year’s success.
The start went well, although it was very 
nervy. After playing well a prepared varia­
tion of the Griinfeld Defence against 
Korchnoi, I obtained a better endgame, but 
with my inaccurate 22nd move I lost the 
greater part of my advantage and in the 
ensuing time scramble the position almost 
reached a draw. Fortunately for me, the 
illustrious veteran went wrong and resigned 
on the 55th move. This was our last ‘classi­
cal’ meeting (overall score: +13-1=13).
In the second round I was again Black - 
against Piket and, after employing another 
novelty in the Griinfeld I nearly overstepped 
the mark in a complicated battle, but in the 
end it was a draw. In the third round I spec­
tacularly crushed van Wely in an English 
Attack (cf. Game No.56, note to Black’s 12th 
move), and in the fourth I had a difficult 
draw with Adams.
By that time the leading group had taken 
shape: Kasparov, Kramnik and Piket - 3 out 
of 4; Anand, Leko and Morozevich - 2y/i. In 
the fifth round I had White against the 22- 
year-old Muscovite Grandmaster Alexander 
Morozevich, who in this game tried a stun­
ning piece of opening preparation.

Kramnik also won that day (this was his

In the sixth round against Short I ended

advantages against Korchnoi and Moro- 
zevich, and difficulties in games with Adams 
and Short, with whom I usually played very

The leading positions at that moment

Anand and Leko - 5. It was time to cast off 
the shackles, and in the ninth round I won 
with White in a Scotch against Timman (cf. 
Game N0.61, note to White’s 16th move), 
then in the tenth - a good Griinfeld with 
Black against Nikolic. I now had 7V2 out of 
10, a point more than Leko and Kramnik. In 
the n th  and 12th rounds I drew with them, 
having to conduct a difficult defence in a 
Griinfeld against Kramnik.
The result of these duels determined the 
fate of first place: before the last round I had 
8V2 out of 12, with Leko and Kramnik on T/i. 
At the finish both my pursuers had Black 
and contented themselves with draws. 
Therefore in my ‘white’ game with Judit 
Polgar a half-point would more than satisfy 
me. But at the very height of the opening 
battle I suddenly felt the urge to finish 
‘brilliantly’.

As a result, although I scored half a point 
less than in Wijk aan Zee 1999, there was no 
genuine battle for first place. From the press: 
‘In the opinion of many grandmasters, Kas­
parov was far from at his best, and he had an 
unusually large number of dubious positions. 
What told was a lack of practice. But, even 
though not in his optimal form, all the same 
he finished a point and a half ahead of his 
closest pursuers.’
Sergey Shipov: ‘Kasparov, achieved the 
round-by-round score planned in his training 
camp and even exceeded it by quarter of a 
point! There were no problems in the open­
ing. Anand and Kramnik were not at their 
best. In recent times Leko has obviously 
improved, but on seeing his game with van 
Wely, Kasparov was horrified and exclaimed: 
"If my successors will play the Sicilian so 
passively with White, I will have to stay in 
top-level chess for another 10 years!"
‘Morozevich can also be a real rival to Kas­
parov - I think that he has reached the main 
chasing group: Anand, Kramnik, Shirov and 
Leko... The gap between Kasparov and these 
five players is a result of differences in physical 
condition (Garry Kimovich, the eldest of them, 
is in the best shape!) and in opening prepara­
tion (again his work at home is more compe­
tently arranged). If these five do not close the 
gap, we will have to wait for some youngster...’

Second Peak
Fatal Choice
Double-Round Super-Toumament in Linares 
(27 February -10 March 2000): 1-2. Kasparov 
and Kramnik - 6 out of 10; 3-6. Leko, Anand, 
Khalifman and Sbirov - 4Vi.
After my victory in Wijk aan Zee I also 
wanted to perform worthily in Linares: by 
that time the question of an autumn world 
championship had finally been decided. Its 
prize fund of two million dollars was pro­
vided by a London company ‘Brain Games’, 
set up on the initiative of Raymond Keene. 
But my opponent, Anand, would not sign 
the contract, and the situation remained 
unclear, which unnerved both players.
I wasn’t able to prepare fully for this cate­
gory 21 super-toumament. Because of uncer­
tainty regarding its staging I was late in 
receiving my invitation - after I had already 
become involved in my renovated Kas- 
parovChess site with the organization of an 
international knock-out tournament of 16 
grandmasters with a time control of 60 
minutes per game (9-20 February 2000). Of 
course, I also played in it: I beat Barua (2-0), 
van Wely and Adams (each 1V2-V2), but in the 
final I unexpectedly lost to Piket (Vj-i ’/ j).
I remember my trainer saying sadly: 'Once 
again you have had to sacrifice yourself for the 
future of chess.’ Indeed, the internet used up a 
mass of energy and time. Between March and 
June of that year our company organised 
another unique knock-out tournament: the 
first world championship in chess history for 
general education schools. Already then I was 
dreaming of promoting a teaching program 
in schools and organizing chess enthusiasts 
throughout the world via the internet. An­
other dream was to write a book about recent 
chess history, to show its constant progress 
through the play of the world champions, and 
it was precisely then that I began working on
creating the series My Great Predecessors...
The line-up of Linares 2000, although 
slightly shortened, was fully traditional: only 
the old-timer Topalov, who was experienc­
ing a crisis, was replaced by the new FIDE 
champion Khalifman. The organisers col­
lided head-on with all the interested per­
sons, provoking arguments about who was 
now the world champion. Some said that the 
champion was Khalifman, and that Kas­
parov was simply the strongest player, but 
others saw things differently: ‘For llyumzhi- 
nov and perhaps a few people pom  Lenin­
grad it is Khalifman, but the overwhelming 
majority do not consider it to be him. We 
have one world champion...’ (Korchnoi).
Dokhoian and I felt that my creative 
surge, which began in 1999, was already on 
the wane: there was no sign of the freshness 
and energy of the previous year. And 
throughout the tournament I was pursued 
by ‘rises and falls’, even during the course of 
individual games. Nevertheless, the start 
went well: a theoretical duel with Shirov, 
who employed the Petroff Defence, was 
heading for a draw after a sharp tactical 
skirmish, when Alexey suddenly blundered a 
piece, and I was able to win an endgame 
with rook, bishop and two pawns (g and h) 
against rook and three pawns (f, g and h).
In the second round I had an equally sharp 
battle in a Griinfeld with Khalifman: on the 
20th move I missed a chance to seize the 
initiative, and the result was a draw. Also 
interesting was the course taken by my third 
round game with Kramnik, who employed a 
dubious novelty in the Petroff Defence (cf. 
Game No.82, note to White’s 10th move). I 
found the correct set-up, then I went slightly 
wrong, but Kramnik gave me a chance to 
cany out an unusual attack. Alas, short of 
time, I allowed the exchange of my important 
bishop, and on move 22 we agreed a draw.
291

Carry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
In the fourth Tound I won with Black 
against Anand, who played surprisingly 
uncertainly (cf. Game No.26, note to Black’s 
9th move), then in the fifth round I pressed 
on Leko’s position in a Griinfeld with 5 1®rb3, 
but was unable to extract anything Teal - a 
dTaw in a pawn endgame on the 39th move.
The positions in the Tace afteT the first 
cycle were: Kasparov and Kramnik - 31/* out 
of 5; Leko - iVr, Shirov and Khalifman - 2; 
Anand - V/i. The second cycle was also not 
distinguished by the number of decisive 
games: in the eighth round Khalifman won 
against Leko and in the ninth he lost to 
Anand, but the remaining 13 games con­
cluded peacefully. The tournament was a 
record one for the number of draws, al­
though many of them were fighting games.
For me the second cycle began with a bat­
tle against Shirov - another crazy Sicilian. 
From the opening I obtained a dangerous 
position (cf. Game N0.76, notes to Black’s 6th 
move and Black’s 10th move), then I seized 
the initiative, but on the 3lst move I missed 
a real winning chance, and my opponent 
forced a draw. In the seventh round I had 
good chances against Khalifman in a French 
Defence, but I again played inaaccurately, 
and Black set up a fortress.
In the eighth round came the second, key 
game with Vladimir Kramnik. The winner of 
this encounter would almost certainly take 
sole first place in the tournament. With 
White Kramnik tried to impose a battle on 
his opening territory.

'An unusual and highly interesting, large- 
scale battle. Its outcome was quite legiti­

At the finish I felt extremely tired. In the 
ninth round against Leko I employed the 
variation with 6...£ig4 in the Najdorf, ob­
tained a more or less tolerable endgame (cf. 
Game N0.63, note to Black's 10th move), but 
with my ridiculous 20th move I suddenly 
gave up my a6-pawn. In his fright Leko 
thought for a long time, captured the pawn 
- and promptly squandered his entire 
advantage.
A draw was also the result in my ‘white’ 
game with Anand, who was sharing 3rd-6th
2 9 8

Second Peak
places. I gained some advantage from the 
opening (cf. Game No.82, note to White’s 
10th move), but I was unsettled by the 
thought that, in the event of me winning, 
Vishy would finish last on his own, and the 
sponsors’ interest in our match would cool. I 
was tormented by the ‘ghost of Karpov in Las 
Palmas 1996’: I was in danger of losing my 
opponent! Although Anand was literally 
shaking with fright, I was also unable to play 
normally, and after a senes of exchanges we 
concluded peace.
Kramnik also drew, and we shared first 
place, with all our four tie-break indicators 
turning out to be identical! The fifth indicator 
was a drawing of lots. Which of us two would 
be awarded the traditional prize for the 
Linares winner - a model of a mining derrick? 
To avoid this question being decided by the 
blind will of chance, the organisers suggested 
we play a blitz decider. And here, in Dok- 
hoian’s opinion, I made an inexcusable 
psychological mistake: I said that I already 
had several such trophies, and with a ‘Baku- 
like grand gesture’ I gave up this prize to 
Kramnik. My decision proved to be symbolic: 
in the spring Kramnik took the prize, and in 
the autumn he took the world title! Of course, 
I should have agreed to the blitz, but I was 
irresolute, assuming that in the autumn I 
would be playing a match with Anand...
After Linares I flew to Moscow, while 
Kramnik, Anand and Shirov went off to an 
exhibition tournament in Monte Carlo. For a 
further ten days the organisers of the Lon­
don match tried to persuade Anand to sign 
the contract, but after a long delay Vishy 
refused, stating: ‘The negotiations were cut 
short mainly in view of the absence of any 
guarantees for me. I suggested different 
variations, but in vain.’
I don’t know precisely what mountains of 
gold llyumzhinov promised him, but as a
result Anand did not miscalculate: at the 
end of 2000 he won the third FIDE knock-out 
championship, crushing Shirov in the final 
(3V2-V2).
Again I was left without an opponent, and 
I urgently had to decide what to do next. 
With whom should I now play a match - 
Kramnik or Shirov? Dokhoian thought that 
without hesitation the 1998 challenger 
Shirov should be chosen. But I objected: after 
all, in the competitive respect this was not 
interesting - in ‘classical’ play against Shirov 
I had an overwhelming score (+8=8). By 
contrast with Kramnik the score was equal 
(+3-3=17), many games had proved difficult 
for me, and it was clear to everyone that he 
was the most dangerous opponent. And I 
was convinced: the world champion was 
obliged to play against the strongest! I 
wanted to accept a genuinely serious chal­
lenge - that was the style of my entire life.
And I chose Kramnik. He quickly agreed, 
after requesting $50,000 in expenses for 
match preparations, and admitting: 'First I 
consulted with Anand and I still don’t under­
stand why they didn’t come to an agree­
ment.’ Of course, a clause about a return 
match should have been included in the 
contract, and Kramnik would not have 
objected. In the given instance this was a 
sensible idea, since the challenger had not 
participated in the organization of the 
match, he had not gathered the money for 
its staging, as happened in ancient times, 
and he was presented with all this on a silver 
platter (such a sinecure was unprecedented 
in chess history!), moreover without having 
to qualify - and after his win he tn'ed to 
persuade everyone that I must play in a 
qualifier... But all my life I had spoken out 
against obligatory return matches - and I 
decided not to make an exception.
For this choice I was to pay bitterly.

Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
Double Hat-Trick
International Tournament in Sarajevo (16-29 
May 2000): l. Kasparov - S'A out of ll; 2-3. 
Adams and Shirov - 8; 4-6. Morozevich, 
Topalov and Bareev - 6; 7 .1.Sokolov - 4V2; 8- 
11. Movsesian, Short, Kir.Georgiev and 
M.Gurevich - 4; 12. Bacrot - 3.
After Linares I won a rapidplay tourna­
ment (Reykjavik, 1-2 April 2000), taking first 
place in my group (4Vi out of 5), before 
defeating Wojtkiewicz (1V2-V2) and, in the 
final, Anand (l-l; 2-0). And then I began 
preparing for the category 19 super- 
tournament in Sarajevo, timed to coincide 
with the 40th anniversary of the well-known 
Bosna Club, for which I had appeared in the 
mid-1990s.
On this occasion there were not 10 players 
in the tournament, but 12: the eight grand­
masters from the previous year and four 
newcomers. Again, like a year earlier, Kram­
nik declined to play, having begun active 
preparations for our match in the autumn, 
and again he was replaced by Short, who 
lived not far away in Greece.
Shirov was in brilliant form, having evi­
dently decided to demonstrate to the chess 
world that he was the ‘lawful challenger since 
1998’. True, at the start Alexey was unable to 
convert a sound extra pawn in his game with 
Adams, but then he began crushing one 
opponent after another and he took the lead.
In the first round I was paired with the 17- 
year-old French prodigy Etienne Bacrot, who 
at that time was being trained by my former 
long-standing mentor Alexander Nikitin. For 
him this was a battle of the pupils! And 
whereas on that day (and on others) many 
seconds preferred the relaxed atmosphere of 
the press centre, Nikitin and Dokhoian sat 
rooted on one of the front rows of the play­
ing hall.

Carry Kasparov on Carry Kasparov: Part Three
After this good start I began to have prob­
lems. In the second round, with Black in a 
Sicilian (cf. Game No.99, note to White’s 8th 
move), I completely outplayed Adams, but 
was unable to finish him off. In the third 
round, with White in a French, I with diffi­
culty won a very nervy game against Gure­
vich. Then I gained a draw with Topalov (l d4 
d5 2 c4 c6 3 £>f3 £>f6 4 £>c3 e6 5 g3 £)bd7 6 
g3 dxc4l, etc.) and easily defeated Ivan 
Sokolov, who failed to equalise in a Petroff 
Defence (cf. Game No.82, note to White’s 
10th move).
In the sixth round with Short I again had a 
winning position in a Sicilian, but again I did 
not finish him off. In the seventh round I had 
a nervy, crazy duel with Morozevich: attack­
ing, I gave up a mass of pawns and should 
have lost, but on the 18th move my oppo­
nent played his queen to the wrong square 
and the result was a draw.
In the eighth round I had Black against 
the leader - Shirov, who was half a point 
ahead of me, and I employed the fighting 
novelty ll...Wb6 in my traditional Najdorf. 
But Alexey played for the result and did not 
seek a refutation, going into a slightly better 
endgame (cf. Game No.63, note to White’s 
11th move) - a draw on the 27th move. 
Since our closest pursuers won, before the 
final three founds the battle for first place 
sharply intensified: Shirov - 6 out of 8; 
Kasparov, Morozevich and Adams - S'A.
Vladimir Barsky: ‘Shirov was playing 
splendidly, and it appeared that a sensation 
was on the cards. Of course, Kasparov was not 
bound to win all the tournaments in succes­
sion, but for a very long time he had not had 
any other results. Shirov could have earned 
the applause of the entire chess world - it 
seemed all that was needed was a little more 
effort, and he would displace Kasparov from 
his customary first place... But here a new
hero came to the fore - Sergey Movsesian.'
The 21-year-old Armenian Grandmaster, 
then living in the Czech Republic, who before 
this was on 2 out of 8, scintillated in rounds 
9 and 10 with sensational wins over Moro­
zevich and Shirov!
As for me, like a year earlier I managed to 
win all three of my remaining games. The 
win over Bareev was a very difficult one: he 
faltered only on the threshold of my time- 
trouble in a slightly inferior double-rook 
endgame. Then I crushed Kiril Georgiev in a 
Sicilian and before the last round I was at 
last leading the race: Kasparov - 7'A out of 
10; Shirov and Adams - 7.
My remaining game was with Black 
against the formidable Sergey Movsesian. 
Taking account of the fact that both my 
pursuers were very determined (and in the 
end both won!), to take sole first place I had 
to aim for a win, but remember that in the 
event of a loss I might finish third. Therefore 
it would have been unjustified heroism to 
plunge into battle under the motto ‘death or 
glory’.
Our duel also had a personal aspect. In 
the summer of 1999 during the FIDE knock­
out world championship in Las Vegas, while 
customarily criticising the ‘tournament of a 
hundred’ as unsuitable for determining the 
strongest player on the planet, I tried to 
assess objectively the chances of the quarter- 
finalists and I arbitrarily divided the grand­
masters into four groups: the ‘favourites' 
Kramnik and Shirov, the ‘solid’ Adams and 
Khalifman, the ‘unpredictable’ Polgar - and 
the ‘tourists’ 
Akopian, 
Nisipeanu and 
Movsesian (curiously, both ‘favourites’ went 
out in the quarter-finals, and the tourna­
ment was won by the ‘solid’ Khalifman, who 
defeated Polgar, Nisipeanu and Akopian). 
Unexpectedly Sergey was offended by my 
jocular term ‘tourists' and he sharply ex-
304

Second Peak
pressed his objections in the press. Now this 
‘tourist’ was certainly intending to take my 
scalp as a souvenir and to become the 
‘conquerer of the kings’!
In principle, my opponent's fighting mood 
suited me. After taking all the factors into 
account I planned my game strategy - I 
chose a flexible Sicilian set-up, in order to 
launch a counter-attack at the first oppor­
tunity.

Vladimir Barsky: ‘A brilliant achievement 
by Kasparov. However, the tournament has 
shown that here is no gulf between him and 
the ‘rest of the world’. Kasparov is superior to 
his rivals mainly in physical preparation 
(remember that he again scored 3 out of 3 at 
the finish), and in his ability to organise his 
work on chess. In this second factor his de­
voted second Yuri Dokhoian deserves enor­
mous credit - Kasparov’s colossal knowledge 
is systematically 
arranged. Anyone who 
wants to fight for the title of the strongest 
player in the world must in the first instance 
surpass the 37-year-old Muscovite in these 
two components.'
This was my last ‘classical’ appearance 
before the autumn match for the world 
championship. A month later I played in a

double-cycle rapidplay tournament (Frank­
furt am Main, 22-25 June 2000): 1. Anand - 
7V2 out of 10; 2. Kasparov - 6; 3. Kramnik -

lengthy training session in Croatia.
Match with Kramnik
World Championship Match Kasparov -  
Kramnik (London, 7 October - 2 November 
2000): 6V2-8V2.
For understandable reasons I have never 
spoken in detail about my match with 
Vladimir Kramnik. My preparations for it 
were serious, but, unfortunately, inflexible 
and therefore ineffective: hardly any of our 
opening ideas came in useful in the match 
and they were employed only in subsequent 
tournaments. The state of my nervous 
system was also far from ideal. Emotional 
fatigue had accumulated from the constant 
tournament victories and endless organiza­
tional problems with internet projects. I was 
also wom out by a two-year lawsuit with my 
former wife living in the USA, for the right to 
bring my daughter Polina to Moscow at least 
once a year.
We held two big training sessions - in the 
summer on the Adriatic coast and in Sep­
tember on the outskirts of Moscow. On this 
occasion my usual team of Yuri Dokhoian 
and Alexander Shakarov was joined by the 
young grandmasters Andrey Kharlov and 
Mikhail Kobalia. At various stages Boris 
Alterman and Michael Adams also helped.
For White the main emphasis was placed 
on 1 e4. 1 d4 was studied superficially, and
only just before the match did I look a little at 
1 c4 with Boris Gulko, who was passing 
through Moscow. Because of this narrow 
repertoire, in the course of the match I lacked 
flexibility. On the other hand, after 1 e4 we 
made appreciable progress in all of the 
openings from Kramnik’s repertoire: we 
demolished the Petroff Defence (on the back 
of this I beat Adams - Came No.82), we 
combed through the Sveshnikov and Rauzer 
Variations in the Sicilian, and we renovated 
both the Caro-Kann with 3 e5 -&f5 4 £sc3 (in 
this way I later won against Karpov - Game 
No.77), and the French with 3 £sd2 - for 
example, 3...C5 4 £)gf3 £sf6 5 e5 £)fd7 6 c3 
£sc6 7 ^.d3 Wb6 8 0-0 (Kasparov-Bareev, 1st 
match game, Cannes (rapid) 2001) or 4...cxd4 
5 exd5 #xd5 6 &c4 »d6 7 0-0 £>f6 8 Sell? 
Jte7 9 £se4 (Kasparov-Gelfand, Astana 2001).
But we didn’t look at l...e5 2 £sf3 £sc6: 
Kramnik hardly ever played this, and I 
thought that starting from nothing it would 
be too much trouble to prepare for both the 
Ruy Lopez and the Scotch Game. It was only 
at the end of the second session that I said: 
we ought to look at the Berlin Defence 
(Kramnik employed it at Wijk aan Zee in 
1999 against Topalov and reached an infe­
rior endgame), but, although we had a 
Spanish expert in Adams, no deep analysis 
was made. Incidentally, I might have studied 
this new segment of theory back in the 
autumn of 1998, during my Prague match 
with Timman: according to his second, Ivan 
Sokolov, against 1 e4 he had prepared the 
‘Berlin Wall’. Alas, as fate would have it, at 
the time I played only 1 d4.
With Black I did not see any particular 
problems after 1 £tf3 £sf6 2 c4 (Game N0.64), 
and against 1 d4 I chose the well-tested 
Griinfeld Defence, tempted by the idea of 
‘engineer Garry’s hyperboloid’ - to refine 
and ‘sharpen’ on the computer all the main
309

Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
forcing lines of this opening. After spending 
a mass of time, we made enormous progress 
in many directions, looking at literally every­
thing - apart from the old, ‘harmless’ line 7 
£rf3 c5 8 JLe3 in the main variation. And it 
was this that Kramnik employed!
I remember that when, just in case, I 
asked Sergey Shipov to give me some advice 
for Black in the Catalan, he exclaimed anx­
iously: ‘What, do you only have the Griin- 
feld?’ No, in reserve we also had the Queen’s 
Gambit Accepted - it was played by Kharlov, 
and we looked at it a bit. The black positions 
arising in this opening were not altogether 
to my taste, but I knew them and I was 
hoping to defend myself. In subsequent 
meetings with Kramnik the ‘OGA’ served me 
quite well, but in the first attempts - the 4th 
and 6th games of the match - things were 
difficult, and as an emergency I had to 
include the Nimzo-lndian Defence.
In addition I fairly wore myself out by ana­
lyzing l  e4 for Kramnik. He used to employ 
this move very rarely (against me in the mid- 
1990s, and after 1996 only in blitz games), 
but in the summer he used it to beat Leko in 
a TV exhibition match with a time control of 
one hour for the game (Cologne, 14th Au­
gust 2000). However, here also my efforts 
were in vain: in the match with me Kramnik 
did not play this.
It was with this wealth of, as it soon tran­
spired, superfluous opening knowledge that 
I arrived for the match, commenting on 5th 
October at a press conference before the 
start: ‘Kramnik is a player of universal style, 
which makes him a very dangerous oppo­
nent.’ In the given instance the marked 
difference in the ratings of the players - 
2849 against 2770 - did not play any role: it 
was meeting between grandmasters of the 
same class.
The challenger’s official helpers were Ev­
geny Bareev, Miguel lllescas and Joel Lautier. 
But other grandmasters also took part in his 
preparations - among them Vladimir Be­
likov, Sergey Dolmatov (my second in two 
matches with Karpov), Peter Svidler and 
Boris Gelfand, who had come to my place for 
a training session lasting several days before 
the proposed match with Shirov (1998). 
Moreover, Bon's did not consider it necessary 
to wam me that he was now helping my 
opponent. As Kramnik put it, ‘there was no 
systematic work’, but 'at least once a fort­
night they spoke on the phone’ and ‘ex­
changed certain ideas - say, about some 
interesting games’. (Recently Gelfand dis­
closed that he was offered my help before 
his 2012 match with Anand, and he angrily 
declined: how could he accept, since Kas­
parov had helped Anand before the 2010 
match with Topalov? But I only gave the 
champion a few bits of advice by telephone).
Bareev: ‘The team selected was an interna­
tional one, and in the main each worked at 
home, with Kramnik himself holding several 
training sessions with various players... Each 
was responsible for his own personal front. I 
worked on the white pieces, except for the 
Griinfeld Defence. The ‘Berlin Wall’ was pre­
pared by Dolmatov and Kramnik working 
together for about two weeks. As a matter of 
fact, neither Lautier nor I knew what was our 
main weapon against l e4... Kramnik and 
Lautier worked on the Scotch Game. And on 
the main opening for White - the Griinfeld 
Defence - it was lllescas who carried out some 
very serious work.’
The chief arbiter was Andrzej Filipowicz 
(Poland). In the spirit of the times the match 
was of 16 games (and not 20, as in the 1995 
match with Anand), but we still played four 
times a week - on Tuesdays, Thursdays, 
Saturdays and Sundays, with a time control 
of 40 moves in two hours, 20 in an hour, and
310

Second Peak
half an hour for the rest of the game. As has 
already been mentioned, immediately after 
a game the players gave a press conference. 
And, for the first time in the history of such 
matches, before play an anti-computer 
control operated: the players had to pass 
through a special X-ray machine.
But in general the level of organization 
was markedly inferior to my London 
matches with Karpov (1986) and Short 
(1993). The hall of the Riverside Studios in 
which we played and the way to the press 
centre reminded Cenna Sosonko of a cinema 
in Leningrad, where in 1947 he saw the film 
Secret Agent - in fact the cinema looked 
somewhat superior...
When in the first game after my 1 e4 
there followed l...e5 2 £sf3 £*c6 3 ,&b5 
&f6!?, I glanced at my opponent, smiled and 
shook my head. On suddenly encountering 
the ‘Berlin Wall’, I was unable to gain even a 
hint of an advantage - a draw on the 26th 
move. How to breach Black’s defences in this 
‘tedious’ endgame, resembling those which 
arise in the Spanish Exchange Variation? 
From the very start the problem of the white 
pieces raised its head, a problem with which 
my team later struggled unsuccessfully for 
the entire match (cf. Game No.80, notes to 
Black’s 9th move and White’s 10th move).
Before the second game I was not in the 
best of moods, but I was confident about the 
soundness of my Griinfeld. However, an­
other surprise awaited me.

Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
A discouraging start to the match: it was 
not even so much the score, but rather my 
state of mind. I was shocked by the *holes’ in 
my opening repertoire that had been imme­
diately revealed, both for White and for Black. 
I did not know how to breach the ‘Berlin Wall’, 
and I had no desire to check what other 
surprises Kramnik would spring on me in the 
Griinfeld Defence. Almost my entire prepara­
tion had gone down the drain and I had to 
begin working virtually from zero!
Sosonko: 'As Boris Spassky used to say, in 
world championship matches it is important, 
expressing it in wrestling language, to keep 
your opponent on the mat, to create constant 
negative emotions in him. At the start of the 
match Kramnik has been more successful in 
this.'
In the third game, for the only time in the 
match, I was able to gain some advantage in 
the Berlin and to at least set Black problems. 
But Kramnik defended tenaciously and in 
time-trouble, when I began playing with fire, 
he could even have seized the initiative. 
Things concluded with a sharp endgame with 
connected passed pawns on opposite wings 
and a draw on the 54th move.
Subsequently with the white pieces I was 
not able to achieve anything at all (!) and a 
real battle developed only when I was Black.
Before the fourth game there was agonis­
ing indecision: should I or shouldn’t 1 play the 
Griinfeld Defence? We feverishly looked at 
various modifications of the main variation - 
now I was imagining tricks everywhere, and 
in the end I decided to change opening. This 
was a serious psychological concession: how 
much effort had been put into this defence 
before the match! Perhaps I should neverthe­
less have employed the Griinfeld right to the 
end (White doesn’t have a forced win there!), 
but the second game had left too bitter a 
taste in my mouth...
Thus it was that the Oueeen’s Gambit Ac­
cepted came on to the stage. Kramnik was 
somewhat surprised, he chose the variation 
with the exchange of queens (this was in 
accordance with his match strategy), and 
after another novelty he seized the initiative. 
On the 25th move I lost patience, launched a 
risky counterattack and reached a hopeless 
position. But after mutual mistakes in the 
second time scramble Kramnik missed a win, 
and the result was a highly dramatic draw on 
the 74th move.
This miraculous escape could have inspired 
me to great feats in the fifth game, played the 
following day, but this did not happen. On the 
eve of the match, on learning about the double 
games at weekends, Adams phoned and 
warned me: ‘Garry, bear it in mind: the one 
who has the white pieces on the Sunday will 
find it very difficult!’. Indeed, to play with full 
intensity after tense battles on the Saturday 
proved impossible, as was confirmed by the 
fifth, ninth and thirteenth games. In the fifth 
after the unexpected 1 c4 I gained a stable 
plus, but I played insipidly and failed to exploit 
some favourable chances, which led to a draw 
as early as the 25th move.
In the sixth game the Queen’s Gambit Ac­
cepted again occurred. This time Kramnik 
went in for complicated play, employing a 
novelty with a pawn sacrifice. I declined the 
gift and reached a normal position, but after 
a fierce battle, having passed the first time 
control, I made a serious mistake. My oppo­
nent was close to success, he won a pawn, on 
the 56th move he went chasing a second one, 
and - here literally by a miracle I found a 
spectacular draw by perpetual check. Another 
dramatic finish!
Kramnik was consoled by my terrible play in 
the seventh game: 1 c4 c5 2 £)f3 £>f6 3 d4 cxd4 
4 £ixd4 a6!? (this move, instead of the usual
4...e6 5 g3, threw me into a stupor) 5 £)c3 e6 6
316

Second Peak
g3 (transposing into a Sicilian is more active: 6 
e4 ^.b4 7 ^ 3  or 6..Mc7 7 a3, Kasparov- 
Kramnik, 2nd match game, Moscow 2001)
6.. M/C7 7 Wd3?! (I should have given up the 
pawn - 7 i.g2 Wxc4 8 0-0, Kasparov-Kramnik, 
8th match game (blitz), Moscow 2001) 7...^c6 
8 £)xc6 dxc6! (Kramnik had played this against 
Alterman back in 1987 at a session of the 
Botvinnik-Kasparov school; I was hoping for
8.. M xc6 9 e4) 9 i-g 2 e5 10 0-0 i.e6 11 £a4. 
Draw agreed: only Black can have the more 
pleasant position here.
The match was approaching its mid-point, 
and I did not see any ray of hope for myself: 
what to do next and how to regain my previ­
ous form was quite unclear (the situation 
partially resembled the first half of my 1995 
match with Anand). At this point, seeing my 
sufferings in the Queen’s Gambit Accepted, 
Dokhoian persuaded me to look at the 
Nimzo-lndian Defence. Such a restructuring 
in the course of the match was not easy, since 
all the free time had to be spend ‘reinventing 
the wheel’ both for Black, and for White. This 
work took an enormous amount of energy, 
which I later lacked for the play itself.
Nevertheless, before the eighth game I was 
in a good mood. Firstly, Adams and I had 
finally found the time for a proper analysis of 
the ‘Berlin’ and had found a worthy reply to 
the plan with ...'idS-cS (giving hope for the 
ninth game). And, secondly, an interesting 
novelty had been devised in a line employed 
by Kramnik against the Nimzo-lndian.

inoffensive Kramnik was.

This was my last real chance of saving the 
match - bearing in mind that with a score of
8-8 I would have retained my title. But now 
the score became 8-6. In the 15th game in 
desperation I played 1 d4 and employed the 
Catalan Opening. Kramnik ‘partially forgot’ 
the theory and thought foT a long time, but 
did not in fact equalise. However, I was 
unable to develop my initiative and on the 
39th move, now in an equal endgame, I 
offered a draw. And I congraulated my 
successor on his deserved victory in the 
match.
KTamnik: 'For six months I worked myself 
into the ground, following a complete pro­
gram. For this, figuratively speaking, the stars 
rewarded me. I also made a surge in chess 
understanding... I prepared well psychologi­
329

Carry Kasparov on Carry Kasparov: Part Three
cally, much better than my opponent, and I 
chose the correct tactics. I did not aim for 
immediate equality from the opening, but I 
was ready for a dijficult and prolonged 
defence of inferior positions. To some extent 
this was a novel approach.’
Indeed, Kramnik realised full well the 
danger of direct clashes and he endeavoured 
to avoid over-forcing ‘computer’ variations, 
having learned from the memorable 10th 
game of my 1995 match with Anand (Game 
No.19). Thus, in the analysis of the ‘Berlin’ 
endgame the computer is of little use, and 
this defence was deemed 'a good choice 
against Kasparov’. In his euphoria after the 
victory Bareev talked about ‘the triumph of 
human over computer preparation’, and he 
predicted: ‘Is it really possible to take the 
Berlin Defence seriously? Within six months it 
will be destroyed, and in ‘Informator’ there 
will be all the analyses of how White wins.’ 
But 13 years have already passed, and even 
now the ‘Berlin’ is played by many grand­
masters - no one has even come close to 
refuting it...
Speaking more broadly, I can say that 
Kramnik arrived for our match with new 
ideas and he made a great contribution to 
the further development of chess. The 
opening theory, philosophical outlook on the 
opening and tastes of numerous players in 
the early 21st century were formed under 
the influence of this match and the 14th 
world champion. For a time his approach to 
chess became the dominating one.
As for myself, I overestimated the role of 
computer analysis, I did not get the feel of 
my opponent, and I was unable to withstand 
the intensity of a battle in which much had 
to be devised along the way. The wound 
suffered in the second game proved impos­
sible to heal. I was let down by defects in my 
psychological preparation and a lack of 
nervous energy. I did not have alongside me 
an experienced, top-class grandmaster, and 
an overall conception of the match was not 
devised.
In that historic autumn, fate punished me 
for my excessive self-confidence and lack of 
practicality.

Chapter Three
Life after Death
Farewell to Wijk aan Zee
International Tournament in Wijk aan Zee 
(12-28 January 2001): 1. Kasparov - 9 out of 
13; 2. Anand - 8V21 3-4. Kramnik and Ivan­
chuk - 8; 5-7. Adams, Morozevich and Shirov 
- 7V2; 8. Leko - 6V2; 9. Topalov - 5Vi; 10-11. 
Fedorov and van Wely - 5; 12-13. Piket and 
Tiviakov - 4V2; 14. Timman - 4.
In my third Wijk aan Zee, a category 19 
super-toumament, the situation was un­
usually intriguing: I was now playing as an 
ex-world champion, which was psychologi­
cally difficult and uncustomary, and my 
main rivals were the two new champions - 
Vladimir Kramnik (in the historic line) and 
Vishy Anand (in the FIDE line). For me this 
was a very important test: I needed to dem­
onstrate that the London match had been 
merely a temporary failure, and not a total 
catastrophe.
I started very well, using two blacks to 
maximum effect: without problems I de­
feated Tiviakov and Fedorov in closed varia­
tions of the Sicilian - 2 out of 2! But when I 
met Anand after a free day, I realised that I 
would not have an easy life in the event.
In a Ruy Lopez with 3.a6 Vishy chose
5....&C5 (instead of 5-b5 6 Ab3 .&C5, as 
Kramnik played against me, llth  match 
game, London 2000) and gained equal 
chances, but suddenly he embarked on a 
dubious venture on the queenside and 
reached a losing position.

In the fourth round I confidently equal­
ised against Ivanchuk in a rare line of the 
Scheveningen (cf. Game No.7, note to Black’s 
8th move) - a draw on the 28th move. After 
this a leading trio emerged: Kasparov, 
Kramnik and Shirov - 3 out of 4.
And then came the 5th round, the ultra- 
crucial duel with Kramnik. Against 1 e4 my 
opponent again erected the ‘Berlin Wall’, but 
on this occasion he tried to manage without 
...h7-h6. Dokhoian and I had also prepared for 
this: I gained some advantage (cf. Game 
No.80, note to Black’s 9th move) and, in Yuri’s 
opinion, I ‘played enterprisingly', but Black 
nevertheless managed to consolidate. And 
here some incredible events began to occur.

24.. .5h5?

strategy in the Berlin is aimed at preventing 
White from exploiting his pawn majority on 
the kingside, and it could have immediately 
collapsed. But I returned the favour...
25 £>g5?

Usually such moves are not made because of

26 £wg3 Black loses material: 26...Sh4(xh3)
27 2xd4! 2xd4 28 £rf5+ and ^xd4 (this 
simple fork, which neither of us noticed, was 
later pointed out by some journalists). And 
after 25...Shh8 26 f5 he would have been left 
empty-handed, for example: 26...fihe8 27 c3 
&b5 28 2xd8 2xd8 29 4>e3, etc.
The exchange of such blunders was not 
only ‘an indication of the by no means bril­
liant form of both players’ (Kramnik), but also 
evidence of the extreme tension reigning at 
the board and the tournament. In such a 
difficult struggle, nerves play a decisive role.

This win - perhaps not error-free, but 
partly conducted in the ‘good old style’ - 
improved my mood and enabled me to 
reduce the gap behind the leader: Shirov - 
5V2 out of 7; Kasparov and Kramnik - 5.
In the eighth round Leko chose against 
me the ultra-solid Reti Opening, avoiding 
any theoretical discussions, and although I 
obtained a promising position, I could only 
gain a draw. But Shirov won against Tiviakov 
and increased his lead - 672 out of 8 (!), a 
point ahead of me and Kramnik. The ‘cards’ 
had favoured Alexey from the very start of 
the tournament, but he faced a difficult 
finish: Kasparov, Anand, Ivanchuk, Kramnik 
and Morozevich!
To retain chances of first place, in the 
ninth round I needed without fail to win 
against Shirov. And I did everything possible 
to gear myself up for a fight, especially since 
the game was played on an important date 
for me - 30 years since my father’s death. 
Unfortunately, before the game, for the first 
time in my chess career, I did not shake 
hands with my opponent, for which I gave 
this explanation on my ‘Club Kasparov’ 
website:
‘In recent times Shirov has on several oc­
casions made insulating public comments 
about me. My patience snapped when I 
learned that my match with Kramnik was 
supposedly fixed. When I arrived in Wijk aan 
Zee, we had a conversation about this. I said: 
"Alexey, everyone can become impassioned, 
this is understandable, but mistakes should 
be admitted, and so it would be good if you 
were to apologise.” He couldn’t give me a 
clear reply. After this I am unable to shake 
his hand...'

In the tenth round I drew with Black against

In the final rounds the distraught Shirov 
lost to Ivanchuk and Kramnik, with a draw 
against Morozevich. From the press: ‘This 
event, like a mirror, reflected Shirov’s problems: 
the heavy defeat against Kasparov and the 
subsequent poor finish pushed him back 
almost to the middle of the tournament table. ’
However, for me also the finish proved 
difficult. In the 11th round I won a very 
nervy game, full of mistakes by both sides, 
against Timman (this was our last ‘classical’ 
meeting, giving a final score of +20-2=23), 
and I finally took the sole lead, by a margin 
of a whole point. In the remaining games 
with van Wely and Adams I endeavoured to 
keep complete control of the situation, and 
two draws sufficed for first place. And it was 
Anand who burst through to second place. 
After receiving a powerful stimulus from 
Shirov, following his example he defeated 
the same three Dutchmen and as a result 
finished just half a point behind me.
Here is a brief extract from an interview, 
which I gave immediately afterwards in my 
then customary room 207 in the four-star 
Duin Hotel: ‘Before the start I thought that 
‘plus five’ would give first place. I felt that 
the tournament would be too nervy. And 
that was how it turned out: a nervy, big
342

Life after Death
tournament. I played so-so, but the champi­
ons played even worse. On the whole I was 
dissatisfied with my play, but I cannot 
separate it from the situation in the chess 
world and my terrible frame of mind. It is 
very difficult to play normally with such a 
trauma in your heart.’
In a farewell speech at the closing cere­
mony I permitted myself a rather bold 
comment: ‘This tournament has shown that 
there is life after death!’ And with a smile I 
added: ‘However, I am wary of the fact that 
my results in Wijk aan Zee are steadily 
deteriorating: ‘plus seven’, ‘plus six’, ‘plus 
five’... I don’t know what will happen next 
year!’ Alas, before the next tournament I fell 
ill and I never played in Wijk aan Zee again. 
So that this ‘plus five’ turned out to be my 
swan song...
Yuri Vasiliev: 'For three successive years the 
final table at Wijk aan Zee has invariably been 
headed by the strongest piayers in the worid - 
Kasparov, Anand and Kramnik. This was also 
the case in the 2001 tournament, the most 
imposing in its entire history. The name of the 
winner was aiso unchanged: Kasparov. Many 
were hoping that, after iosing the match to 
Kramnik in London in autumn 2000 and 
conceding the worid title to him, Kasparov 
would lose the aura of a super-player, and 
would become an ordinary grandmaster who 
it is possible to beat. This hasn’t happened! His 
hand is still just as strong, his calculation just 
as quick and his eye just as vigilant. The king 
has lost his crown, but not his strength. But 
will this strength be sufficient for him to 
regain the throne?’
Three-Point Margin
Double-Round Super-Toumament in Linares 
(22 February - 6 March 2001): 1. Kasparov -  
7V2 out of 10; 2-6. J.Polgar, Leko, Shirov, 
Karpov and Grischuk - 4Vi.
Before the next Linares it transpired that 
its category would be lowered from 21 to 19, 
since neither of the new ‘chess kings’, who 
had emerged at the end of 2000, would be 
playing: neither Kramnik nor Anand. Before 
the start I made the following comments: 
‘This is a question of responsibility. 
Linares used to be the ‘chess Wimbledon’, 
the most important and most prestigious 
tournament, where the strongest always 
played. Now this won’t be the case. It is 
unfavourable for the new world champions 
to play there; they put there own interests 
first... But there is also another problem with 
Linares: on encountering the refusal of 
Anand and Kramnik, the organisers are 
seeking to replace them on the principle of 
‘resonance’ of names. Everyone knows the 
names of Karpov and Polgar, but, alas, in the 
present-day chess hierarchy these players 
are not rated so highly. It is sad, but there is 
nothing to be done; Linares is Linares, and as 
before I consider it my duty to play there.’
At the start of 2001 Karpov still retained 
part of his once enormous practical 
strength, but he was playing more rarely in 
tournaments higher than category 14-16, 
achieving comparatively modest results. He 
came to Linares for the first time after a six- 
year interval, no doubt with the desire to 
demonstrate something to me and to the 
chess world. True, the nearly 50-year-old ex­
world champion might well be let down by 
his age... Our opponents were the far 
younger Peter Leko, Alexey Shirov, Judit 
Polgar and the 17-year-old debutant Alex­
ander Grischuk, a semi-finalist in the recent 
FIDE knock-out world championship. As had 
been the case since 1998, the grandmasters 
competed in two cycles, and so that no one 
should play three successive games with the 
same colour, the fourth and fifth rounds 
were interchanged.
343

In the meantime Polgar won with White 
against Shirov, so that she and I were lead­
ing the race with 2'h out of 4.
In the fifth round, which concluded the 
first cycle, I had White against Karpov. We 
had not met in ‘classical’ play since Las 
Palmas 1996. This is what Yuri Vasiliev 
reported from the scene of events:
‘That day the tournament hall was unable 
to accommodate all those wanting to watch; 
people were standing in the aisles, and to get 
through to the stage, which was also a scene of 
activity, was extremely difficult There was a 
kind of parade of the top officials of Linares, 
the province ofJaen, and ofAndalucia in gen­
eral. They all wanted to witness the historic, 
166th (!) Kasparov-Karpovgame. You couldn’t 
move for reporters on the stage, while the 
grandmasters sat amongst all this madness.
‘Kasparov concealed a smile with his hand 
and slightly closed his eyes. Karpov was inscru­
table, and this sombre, aloof, impassive face of 
the Great Competitor staggered and drew the 
attention of the Spanish, who know their 
chess. The history of the ancient game has not 
known such a confrontation. Just think: five 
matches for the world championship! They 
have gone through five madly intense 
matches! In each of them there were more 
than 20 games. During one of these matches, 
which lasted nearly six months, in the Land of 
the Soviets there was a change of power, and 
one of the contestants almost died of exhaus­
tion... Karpov-Kasparov: this is a whole epoque 
in chess. And in our life - also an epoque..
‘And here they were sitting before their next, 
166th game, inundated by flashing lights. Just 
like then, back in 1984... And again they were 
ready to uphold their principles. Their views on 
chess. On the struggle. And on life.
‘The smile disappeared from Kasparov's 
face, and he acquired his familiar, slightly 
sinister expression, circulated a countless 
number of times by all conceivable and 
inconceivable publications in the world. But 
Karpov was still impassive. The Alcalde of 
Linares, Juan Fernandez Gutierrez, started the 
clocks, and the great battle began.’
Right from the opening I was able to set 
my opponent serious problems.

6...£>e7
At that time this was the main continua­

bishop with the aim of retaining a flexible 
pawn chain in the event of the exchange 
£sf4xg6 after h2-h4 and ...h7-h5. 6...h6 7 .&e3 
£sd7 8 Wd2, etc., is too slow. 6...f6 is also not 
very attractive (Game N0.87 in Revolution in 
the 70s). But the most energetic is the im­
mediate attack on the centre by 6...C5!, for 
example:
1) 7 J&.e3 £ k6 (Game N0.88 in Revolution in 
the 70s) or the more modem 7....cxd4 8 £sxd4 
.£±>4! (examples: Motylev-Nisipeanu, Roma­

2) 7 h4 h5 8 £>f4 ^.h7! 9 £>xh5 £>c610 dxc5 
.&XC5 11 i.b5 #07 12 i.xc6+ #xc6 13 #f3 
0-0-0 (Game No.89 in Revolution in the 70s) or 
11 jLg2 <£f8 (Shirov-Topalov, Dresden Olym­
piad 2008), also with double-edged play.
It was because of 6...C5 that the variation 
4 £>c3 e6 5 g4 .&g6 6 £}ge2 declined in 
popularity, but this happened later, and at 
that time, in 2001,1 took an optimistic view 
of the complications resulting here.

I arrived for the sixth round in an elated

only decisive game in the tournament... My 
lead over Polgar increased to a point.

launched a desperate attack!

The following day Shirov surprised me by 
his choice of the Spanish Open Variation, 
resembling the tenth game of my match
with Anand (1995). I was able to exploit an 
inaccuracy by my opponent in a very compli­
cated endgame and to securely blockade the 
enemy passed pawns (cf. Game No.19, note 
to Black’s llth  move), after which the win 
became a matter of technique.
In that same eighth round Karpov gained 
his only win in the tournament - against 
Polgar. This settled matters as regards the 
fight for first place: by reaching ‘plus four’ - 
6 out of 8, I was now two points ahead of 
Judit.
The draw with Karpov in the ninth round 
was our last, 167th ‘classical’ game (cf. Game 
No.47 in Kasparov vs. Karpov 1988-2009). It 
did not tum out to be the most vivid, but it 
confirmed a pleasant trend for me that had 
long been taking shape: playing White, 
Karpov no longer created problems for me, 
as he had at one time in our matches; more­
over, I increasingly often obtained comfort­
able and rather promising positions with 
Black. This game determined the final score 
of our serious encounters: +28-20=119 in my 
favour, including +7-1=15 in tournaments.
Finally, I beat Grischuk with White in the 
‘anti-Sveshnikov’ variation l  e4 c5 2 £sf3 
£sc6 3 d4 cxd4 4 <£sxd4 £if6 5 <£sc3 e6 6 ^xc6 
bxc6 7 e5 ^d5 8 £se4 jtb7 (8...#c7 is faT 
more often played - Game No.89 in Part II of 
Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov) 9 JLe2l, 
etc. - also one of the variations that we had 
prepared for the match with Kramnik.
The results of Linares 2001 were truly 
paradoxical. This is not often seen: one 
contestant scored ‘plus five’, and the re­
maining five - all ‘minus one’. Regarding 
this, Seirawan joked: 'For the first time in his 
life Kasparov finished last but one!’. By win­
ning my eighth super-toumament in suc­
cession and finishing thee points ahead of 
my pursuers, I once again demonstrated 
that the 2000 London match was by no
354

Life after Death
means the end of my chess career, for which 
many of my colleagues-cum-rivals were 
hoping.
Here are some interesting observations by 
the well-known trainer Anatoly Bykhovsky, 
who was helping Grischuk in the tourna­
ment:
‘Linares 2001 was memorable above all for 
Kasparov’s performance. None of the other 
contestants played with such intensity and 
will-to-win. It is probable that after losing the 
title of world champion Kasparov has ac­
quired an ultra-important objective - to 
demonstrate that he is still the strongest 
chess player on the planet. And in tourna­
ment play he is now superior to everyone. He 
is a maximalist, in contrast to Kramnik and 
Anand, who apparently do not think that 
they should always try and beat everyone. 
But Kasparov aims for this constantly, in 
every game. And in Linares he played not 
simply for first place, but for the optimum 
result.
'Kasparov’s attitude to the game was al­
ready apparent from, for example - lunch. 
The other contestants spent at least an hour 
on it, talking among themselves and with 
their trainers. But Kasparov lunched very 
quickly and did not allow himself to be 
distracted at all before a game. The behav­
iour of Yuri Dokhoian was also an indication 
of Garry's frame of mind. The other trainers 
strolled about, chatted or drank coffee, but 
Dokhoian and Klara Shagenovna (who has 
been at all the tournaments in Linares, since 
she considers this to be one of the most 
important events for her son) sat in the hall 
and without distraction followed the play of 
their ‘protege’. In general, Kasparov's attitude 
to his own performance provoked admiration 
- although a Linares ‘old-timer’, he played 
here as though for the first time.
‘Naturally, the relations between Kasparov
and Karpov drew attention... The two 'Ks' 
have different aims: Kasparov wants to 
demonstrate (and for this he has every basis) 
that he is still the strongest player in the 
world, whereas Karpov simply wants to play 
chess and maintain his high reputation... But 
they have more things in common. They have 
both been world champion, and both speak 
out against the innovations of FIDE and 
llyumzhinov in the fields of rapid chess and 
the world championship. Karpov and Kas­
parov want to defend classical chess; to some 
extent nothing divides the ‘veterans' - they 
have no fundamental disagreements. When 
they shook hands before a game, played, and 
analysed it after the finish, one sensed their 
benevolent attitude to each other’.
The highly uneasy situation, which had 
developed by that time in the chess world, 
induced the champions of different eras to 
display solidarity. Roughly a month after 
Linares, Karpov, Kramnik and I published a 
joint ‘Appeal to the chess society’ - a decla­
ration in defence of classical chess, tradi­
tional tournaments and matches for the 
world championship (cf. Kasparov vs. Karpov 
1988-2009). The efforts of the champions, 
augmented by the activity of Bessel Kok and 
Yasser Seirawan, led within a year to an 
illusory compromise with the FIDE Board...
Fall of the Berlin Wall
Double-Round Tournament in Astana (19 
May -1 June 2001): 1. Kasparov - 7 out of 10; 
2. Kramnik - 6'/i; 3. Gelfand - 5V2:4-5. Shirov 
and Morozevich - 4V2: 6. Sadvakasov - 2.
Soon after Linares I gave rapid chess its 
due: in Cannes I won the FIDE World Cup (cf. 
p.488), and a month later in Zurich I finished 
second in a tournament to mark Korchnoi’s 
70th birthday. On the whole I played confi­
dently - I won my group (4V2 out of 5), easily
355

Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
beat Korchnoi (1V2-V2) and Short (1V2-V2), but 
in the final I once more ran into Kramnik 
(V2-1V2): with White I was again unable to 
breach the ‘Berlin Wall’, while with Black I 
obtained a good game and could even have 
repeated moves, but I suddenly lost control 
over myself and over the situation.
Kramnik gained a new lease of life after his 
comparative failure in Wijk aan Zee, and the 
next round of rivalry between the 13th and 
14th world champions acquired particular 
importance - this was the category 20 May 
super-toumament in Astana, the new capital 
of Kazakhstan (which for me replaced Sara­
jevo). The day before the start we gave a joint 
press conference, which created enormous 
interest. And in general at this ‘tournament 
of six’ there was an unusually large number 
of spectators, including young players.
The line-up was also not altogether usual. 
To the two 2800 favourites and three 2700 
fighters was added the local 2500 hero, the 
22-year-old Darmen Sadvakasov (on the 
other hand, his trainer was none other than 
Yuri Razuvaev!). It was this debutant who 
nearly spoiled the final picture for me, by 
twice losing to Kramnik (with White in an 
equal endgame, and with Black by blunder­
ing on the 14th move) and gaining two 
draws with me, in both of which I had to 
suffer...
In the first round I beat Shirov with Black 
in a comparatively rare line of the 
Scheveningen (cf. Game No.99, note to 
White’s 8th move) - this good win gave me 
an additional charge of optimism. In the 
second round against Gelfand I employed a 
novelty in the French Defence, which had 
been prepared for the match with Kramnik, 
and I held a definite initiative, but to be on 
the safe side Boris gave up his queen (which 
was not essential) and set up a fortress - a 
draw on the 41st move. But Kramnik, by
beating Gelfand and Sadvakasov, started 
with 2 out of 2.
The next day I had Black against the un­
predictable Alexander Morozevich.

This fighting win enabled me to catch 
Kramnik - we now both had I'/i. out of 3. 
The next day in the rearranged fourth round
came the duel of the leaders. For the first 
time since the tragic second game of the 
2000 match I risked repeating the Griinfeld 
Defence against Kramnik - and I confidently 
gained a draw in a crucial set-up (Game 
No.70 in Revolution in the 70s). My peace of 
mind in this important part of the battle­
field was restored.
But in the fifth round I suffered a misfor­
tune: I was unable to beat Sadvakasov with 
White. After playing a variation of the Eng­
lish Opening, well known from the second 
game of my 1987 match with Karpov, I 
ended up in a dubious position (cf. Game 
No.29 in Kasparov vs. Karpov 1986-87, note 
to White’s 10th move), and although I then 
gained the initiative, this was not enough 
for a win - a draw on the 43rd move.
Meanwhile, my main rival won against 
Morozevich and was leading the race after 
the first cycle: Kramnik - 4 out of 5; Kasparov 
- 3V2. However, the next day I breached 
Shirov’s French Defence (cf. Game No.lO, 
note to White’s 10th move) and again 
caught the leader - we both had 4I/2 out of 6.
In the next three rounds Kramnik beat 
Sadvakasov and scored two draws, while I 
had to be satisfied with half-points: with 
Black against Gelfand in a Griinfeld, with 
White against Morozevich in his sideline of 
the Slav Defence (cf. Game No.62, note to 
Black’s 7th move), and with Black against 
Sadvakasov. This was a terrible game: I tried 
very hard to seize the initiative, and ob­
tained an interesting, promising position, 
but I went wrong and in the end I nearly lost.
Although I was terribly vexed at being 
unable to beat Sadvakasov and catch Kram­
nik, the tournament arbiter Vladimir Dvork­
ovich later saw that this had its plus points: 
‘Had the leaders been equal before the last 
round, their game might not have been the 
main event of the tournament! It is quite
363

Carry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
probable that they would have agreed to 
share the last point and victory in the tour­
nament, as happened at Linares 2000. Now, 
however, there could not be a share of first 
place, but victory for Kasparov would enable 
him to become the sole winner. Winning 'to 
order’ is doubly difficult, but possible; 13 
years earlier Garry managed to beat Karpov 
in the 24th game of the match in Seville and 
to retain the title of world champion. The 
number '13’also operated in Astana...’
And so, before the finish Kramnik was on 
6^/2 out of 9, I had 6, and I was due to play 
the leader with White. I had to compose 
myself for a decisive battle.

In Astana my opponent demonstrated

Of course, I could also have played 3 d4, 
but I didn’t want to avoid the Spanish be­
cause of the Berlin Defence! I considered 
myself obliged to go in for its main variation 
and demonstrate that in it Black did not 
have easy equality. During the six months I 
had already accumulated many ideas here.
3...^f6
I sensed that Kramnik would again erect 
the ‘Berlin Wall’: at that time he constantly 
played this not only against me, but also 
against Leko, Shirov and others.
4 0-0 £)xe4 5 d4 £sd6 6 JLxc6 dxc6 7 dxe5 
■ f5 8 ®xd8+ &xd8 9 <^c3
It would appear that Black has an inferior 
version of the Spanish Exchange Variation: 
apart from the pawn minority on the king- 
side (usually in the Exchange Variation this 
is fully compensated by the two bishops), his 
king, unable to castle, hinders the coordina­
tion of his pieces, and the e5-pawn cramps 
his position (in the Exchange Variation he 
usually plays ...f7-f6). But, on the other hand, 
with his pawn on e5 White’s control of the 
light squares is weakened, and also after the 
exchange of queens the intensity of the 
battle is reduced. And with accurate play 
Black hopes gradually to solve his problems. 
He even does not especially value the two 
bishops, often exchanging the dark-squared 
one, when the ‘unopposed’ light-squared 
one is sufficient for him.
The position is still a middlegame without 
the queens, but there is a great risk that the 
play will quickly simplify and become too 
tedious, not allowing any scope for flights of 
fantasy.
9...h6
Kramnik used to skilfully vary the differ­
ent branches of the Berlin, making it hard 
for me to prepare. Here the computer is 
useless: everywhere the play is viscous and

enced great problems with this, but later I at 
least began making natural moves.

The most forceful: 4l...2g6 42 Sh2 - no 
chances! Black resigned (l-O).
For all its imperfections, this was a very 
precious game: not only a win in a decisive 
encounter, enabling me to overtake a very 
dangerous rival and take first place (in a 
ninth successive tournament!), but also my 
first win against Kramnik after the ‘blank’ 
score in the 2000 match (the overall balance 
of our meetings in ‘classical’ play was now 
+4-5=40), as well as the winning of a crucial 
opening dispute - the fall of the ‘Berlin Wall’!
Soon afterwards I said in an interview that 
my win in Astana ‘not so much buries the 
entire qualifying cycle, about which Kramnik 
is constantly talking, but makes it completely 
pointless in the eyes of the world community, 
including the eyes of sponsors’. It was pre­
cisely then that I was phoned from America 
by a potential sponsor of world champion­
ships, who was supporting my junior chess 
projects, and he asked: ‘Well, is it time to put 
together money for a return match?’.
I began thinking and speaking about this 
immediately after the 2000 London match. 
But I remember our team doctor Alexander 
Polkhovsky looking sadly at me and asking: 
‘After playing a whole match with Kramnik, 
do you not realise who you are dealing with?’ 
Indeed, if Kramnik had resembled Euwe in 
something other than his height, after my 
three tournament victories in 2001 the 
question of a return match would have been 
decided automatically. During Euwe’s time 
the concept of ‘reputation’ was not an empty 
phrase!
Why I did not include in the London con­
tract an item about a return match is some­
thing that is hard to explain, based on the 
logic of Kramnik or Anand, who have always 
been concerned in the first instance about 
their own well-being. But whereas Anand did 
this openly, Kramnik, as has happened many 
times in history, tried hypocritically to cam­
ouflage his personal benefit ‘with the inter­
ests of chess’.
After becoming the challenger and the 
champion without any qualifying process 
(and after before that losing all the qualifying 
cycles in his career), Kramnik promptly de­
clared: 7 went in for this in order to restore the 
qualifying system... The question is about the 
system itself. To a large extent it is of no sig­
nificance who is the strongest. In his time 
Fischer was obviously superior to the remain­
ing candidates. But this did not mean that he 
should have been freed from having to qualify. 
It is a completely natural situation: if you are 
strongest, then you should in fact win the 
qualifying tournament. I understand Kas­
parov’s enormous desire to play a match for 
the world championship, but, I have to admit, I 
don't see the logic in his words... Is he alto­
gether for’ or ‘against’ qualification? I person­
ally think that there should be qualification! 
And he? I should like to hear from him a clear 
and unambiguous reply to this crucial ques­
tion.’
My reply was not only ‘clear and unambi­
guous’, but also quite exhaustive:
‘When I won the title of world champion I 
was the No.l on the rating list, and I regularly 
won matches against Karpov and all the 
tournaments in which I took part, but new 
victories continued to be demanded of me. 
Confirmation was constantly demanded of 
me, and this is probably normal. In the chaos 
of the current situation only one fact can 
remain undisputable: the world champion

Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
should be the strongest player on the planet. 
The London match gave Kramnik the title, but 
he needs to confirm it with victories. The 
champion had the possibility of doing this in 
Wijk aan Zee and Astana. The outcome is 
known...
‘My position has always been very simple: 
if there is a sound qualifying system, the 
automatic right to a return match is an 
incorrect idea. Now I am zealously fighting for 
my right to a return match because I am 
winning all the tournaments in which I take 
part - including those where Kramnik plays. 
He does not now need to seek a new oppo­
nent.
‘It would be very good to create a new 
qualifying system. But for the system to be 
legitimate, one must be sure that the world 
champion is the strongest player on the 
planet. If Kramnik wins a second match 
against me, there will no longer be any 
questions. If he loses, then, although the 
outcome of the London match was right, a 
conclusive change will not yet have occurred.’
After properly restoring my strength at the 
traditional summer training session by the 
sea, I ‘chalked up’ 11 out of 12 in a Europe 
against Asia rapidplay match (Batumi, 17-19 
September 2001), won S'A-2Vi in a double­
round clock simultaneous against the Czech 
national team (Prague, 18-20 October 2001), 
and played quite well in the Botvinnik Memo­
rial - a short match with Kramnik in three 
forms of chess (Moscow, 30 November - 9 
December 2001).
Initially in memory of Mikhail Botvinnik it 
was planned to stage a four-cycle match- 
tournament with three of his pupils - Karpov, 
Kasparov and Kramnik. However, Karpov 
suddenly withdrew, but arrived for the start 
of the FIDE knock-out championship, which 
began three days earlier in Moscow. Since he 
went out in the very first round, chess fans in
the foyer joked: ah, what a pity that Karpov 
withdrew from the match-tournament of the 
three ‘Ks’ - he would still have been in time.
When there were just the two of us left, 
Kramnik insisted on reducing the number of 
classical games to four, so that the match 
should not have too much importance. Our 
chess triathlon began with a draw in ‘classi­
cal’ play (2-2), and in rapidplay (3-3), and 
concluded in victory for me in blitz (6V2-3V2). 
After Astana I played quite successfully 
against my main opponent and did not lose 
to him again in ‘classical’ play. The burden of 
responsibility which pressed on me in the 
2000 match had obviously been lifted.
Who is the Real King?
Double-Round Super-Tournament in Linares 
(22 February -10 March 2002): 1. Kasparov -  
8 out of 12; 2. Ponomariov - 6V2; 3-5. Ivan­
chuk, Anand and Adams - 6; 6. Vallejo - 5; 7. 
Shirov - 4V2.
On this occasion the background to 
Linares was provided not by the preceding 
tournament in Wijk aan Zee (of the Linares 
players, only Adams took part there), but the 
recent FIDE knock-out world championship, 
which produced several sensations. Anand 
was relieved of his title after losing in the 
semi-final to Ivanchuk, who, in turn, unex­
pectedly lost in the final to a rising start of 
Ukrainian chess, the 18-year-old Ruslan 
Ponomariov. The new FIDE champion, who 
strongly resembled Kamsky and Karpov in 
their youth, played freshly and energetically 
- in the preceding rounds he knocked out 
Morozevich, Bareev and Svidler!
Now Ponomariov was making his debut in 
a category 20 super-tournament, and in a 
battle with five of the top ten in the world 
rating list he was eager to demonstrate that 
his success in the knock-out was no accident.
372

Life after Death
The other Linares debutant was 19-year-old 
‘2600’ player Francisco Vallejo - at that time 
the strongest native Spanish Grandmaster.
'Notable by his absence is Vladimir Kram­
nik, whose serious plans for this year would 
appear to be limited only to a match in 
October with the computer Deep Fritz’, wrote 
the Ukrainian journalist Nikolai Fuzik. 
'Vladimir will also have to miss his favourite 
traditional July tournament in Dortmund, 
since on this occasion it will have the status of 
a candidates event, the winner of which will 
earn the right to a match with Kramnik for 
the historic’ version of the world champion­
ship title. But even without him Linares 2002 
promises to be exceptionally interesting. For 
Kasparov, who has not found his niche in 
either of the world championship systems, 
there only remain tournaments in which to 
demonstrate who is the real king in the 
kingdom, regarding which the other partici­
pants may have their own opinion.’
Of course, I was psychologically depressed 
by the absence of any real prospect of playing 
a match for the world championship, and 
initially I was nervous (however, that was the 
case in the majority of similar tournaments). I 
started, like the year before, with three draws. 
In the first round I was unable to beat Vallejo 
with Black, although for a long time 1 had an 
excellent position, and after my opponent’s 
time-trouble blunder 40 Wc2? I could have 
won with 40...^xf5l. But, alas, I took the 
wrong pawn, and White managed to escape. I 
was terribly vexed: surely I wasn’t going to be 
struck by the ‘Sadvakasov syndrome’?
In the second round I was free, then in the 
third I played Vishy Anand and engaged him 
in a complicated, viscous struggle in a 
Paulsen Sicilian. I gained some advantage, 
but in the time scramble a parade of mutual 
mistakes began, and after the time control I 
missed a wonderful chance.

The two missed wins were a pity, but I 
had to move on. The next day I played an­
other viscous game - with Ivanchuk, which 
ended in a draw on the 34th move.
In the fifth round, which took place after a 
general free day, I met Michael Adams, the 
only player who at that moment was on a 
plus score - 2 out of 3.

The fashion for a rapid c3-c4 fell sharply

18 Sa2
Black would have been set far more prob­
lems by the alternative 18 Sell, as I later 
played in a rapid game against Karpov 
(Game No.49 in Kasparov vs. Karpov 1988- 
2009). But I very much wanted to switch the 
rook to the centre, following the example of 
the old game Karpov-Portisch (Lucerne 
Olympiad 1982).
18.. .b6
This move, made after a long think, was 
one that I awarded an exclamation mark to 
in Informator, judging that White was better 
after l8...2cd8 19 Sd2 (19 d5 £>e5 is equal, 
Grischuk-Huzman, Rethymnon 2003). But 
here also after I9...h6 Black has quite a solid 
position: 20 h3 We7 21 c5 £>a5 or 21 d5 £>a5 
22 £d3 Wd7, etc.
The ...b7-b6 idea has a good positional 
basis. Black’s main problem is the vulnerable 
position of his queen, and he needs to solve 
it somehow, without allowing a break­
through by White’s central pawns. Overlook­
ing the radical solution 17-Wc2!, Adams 
found another possibility: place the knight 
on a5, where it will be defended by the b6- 
pawn, and if necessary retreat the queen to 
b7.

This first win in the tournament enabled 
me, with Vh out of 4, to replace Adams as 
the only player on a plus score.
In the sixth round I had my first encounter 
with Ruslan Ponomariov, and against my 
Najdorf he employed the sharp English Attack 
(cf. Game No.17, note to White’s 12th move). 
By the 2lst move a roughly equal endgame 
was reached with rooks and opposite- 
coloured bishops. From the press: 'Possibly the 
most unexpected moment for Kasparov came 
when in an obviously drawn position his 
young opponent decided to fight for some­
thing more. "He’s playing for a win?!” they 
exclaimed in surprise in the press centre.’
On the 31st move Ponomariov suddenly 
gave up his g5-pawn for the a5-pawn, 
allowing me to create a dangerous pair of 
connected passed pawns, and in the time 
scramble he overstepped the mark and 
ended up in a lost position.

A third missed win, and in an important 
game! The next day I chose against Shirov l 
e4 c5 2 £)f3 £)c6 3 .&b5 (since I was psycho­

Variation), played unconvincingly and did 
not achieve anything - a draw on the 26th 
move. But nevertheless I ended the first cycle 
as the leader: Kasparov - 3'A out of 6; Po- 
nomariov, Ivanchuk, Adams, Vallejo and 
Shirov - 3; Anand - 2Vi.
At the start of the second cycle I neverthe­
less won with White against Vallejo, al­
though I again played unconvincingly: I had 
a considerable advantage, but then I gave up 
a pawn without gaining any particular 
compensation for it. However, in time- 
trouble the young grandmaster went wrong, 
and his game went downhill. The lead over 
my pursuers grew to a full point.
In the ninth round I was free, and behind 
me Ponomariov led the chase by beating 
Adams. In the tenth round, in which it was 
Ruslan who was free, I had Black against 
Anand and I seized the initiative in a sharp 
branch of the Najdorf (cf. Game No.93, note 
to White’s 9th move), but by some miracle 
my opponent held out - a draw on the 40th 
move. It need hardly be said how happy 
Vishy was-. foT the first time afteT out 1995 
match he did not lose to me in Linares!
Then I made two further Sicilian draws: 
with White against Ivanchuk and with Black 
against Adams. And two rounds before the 
finish I was caught by Ponomariov: we both
had 6 out of 10, with our closest pursuers on 
just 50%. Thus my second duel with the new 
FIDE champion became the decisive game of 
the tournament.

That was how my record three-year senes

one’. There is no disputing both his superior­
