Garry has won 13 of the last 15 super- 
tournaments. Today only the elusive Kramnik 
remains a dangerous opponent for him.’
Immediately afteT the tournament I 
stated in an interview that KTamnik was 
concerned only about his own interests and 
was neglecting his obligations to the chess 
world:
‘The champion's title had a sacred mean­
ing only because it belonged to the strongest 
player. It is ridiculous when Kramnik talks 
about some ‘official’ title, match ot qualifi­
cation. His unwillingness to play a return 
match has led to a devaluation of the tradi­
tional title, since today KTamnik is not the 
strongest playeT. He had no otheT way of 
demonstrating that he is the strongest, 
other than to play anotheT match with me...
‘Unfortunately, Kramnik has done every­
thing he can to avoid the most dangerous 
opponents, and not only me. (In the Candi­
dates Tournament held in July 2002 I did not 
participate, and neither did Anand, Ponom- 
ariov or Ivanchuk - G.K.). It is staggering that 
Anand and Kramnik did not want to play a 
match against each otheT. On becoming 
champions, they could have come to an 
agreement, but they preferred to Tetain theiT 
split achievements and not place them 
undeT threat.'
Last Olympiad Triumph
35th World Chess Olympiad (Bled, 25 Octo­
ber - 10 November 2002): l. Russia - 38V2 
out of 56; 2. Hungary - 37'A; 3. Armenia - 
35; 4. Georgia - 34; 5-12. China, Holland, 
England, Slovakia, Israel, Yugoslavia, Mace­
donia and Switzerland - 33V2, etc. (alto­
gether - 134 teams). The winning team 
comprised Kasparov (71/2 out of 9), Grischuk 
(7 out of 11), Khalifman (7 out of 9), Moro- 
zevich (7 out of 11), reserves SvidJer (6 out of 
9) and Rublevsky (4 out of 7).
By early 2002 the London firm ‘Brain 
Games’, which had staged my match with 
Vladimir KTamnik, was on the verge of 
bankruptcy and in February it sold the rights 
to staging the next world championship to 
the ‘Einstein Group’ financial company. 
Foreseeing serious problems in attracting 
majoT sponsors ‘undeT Kramnik’, the well- 
known American grandmaster Yasser Seba- 
wan suggested a plan for uniting the world 
championships undeT the aegis of FIDE. This 
idea was supported by me, by Bessel Kok, 
and at the last moment also by Kramnik.
I spent the whole of March and April on 
setting up this new concept of unification, 
assuming that I had no other chance of 
playing a match for the worid champion­
ship: all the illusions with TegaTd to Kramnik
392

Life after Death
had already been dispelled. At the cost of 
enormous nervous expenditure a compro­
mise with the FIDE board was reached.
On the eve of these seemingly historic 
decisions Bessel Kok arranged an excellent 
rapidplay knock-out tournament for the 
Eurotel Trophy (Prague, 29 April - 5 May 
2002). After beating Milos (2-0) and J.Polgar 
(2-0), in the quarter-finals I lost a fierce 
battle to Ivanchuk (1-1; 1-1; O-l), and he lost 
in the semi-final to Anand. The other finalist 
was Karpov, who beat Short, Kramnik, 
Morozevich and Shirov! But in the final 
Anand defeated Karpov, gaining mini­
revenge against him for Lausanne 1998.
On 6th May 2002 the FIDE President Kir- 
san llyumzhinov, together with the 13th and 
14th champions, Kok and Seirawan, signed 
the famous Prague Agreement - ‘Resolution 
on the Unification of the Chess World’. From 
then on FIDE became the sole custodian of 
the World Chess Championship title and the 
only organization staging official world 
championships. But at the same time it was 
obliged to become a management organiza­
tion, to set up a precise schedule which 
would satisfy potential sponsors (essentially 
this was an attempt to carry over into the 
2lst century the positive experience of the 
GMA and PCA), and to approve a unification 
plan, according to which the FIDE champion 
Ponomariov had to play a match with the 
leader of the world rating list Kasparov, the 
‘historic’ champion Kramnik with the win­
ner of the ‘Einstein Group' candidates tour­
nament, and the winners of these two 
matches were to meet in a unifying match 
for the world championship.
The agreement admitted that ‘the unifica­
tion plan is not perfect and will not satisfy 
everyone’. Indeed, soon 22 grandmasters, 
including Anand, Shirov, Leko, Lautier, Yusu- 
pov and almost the entire Russian team,
expressed in an open letter: ‘our concern 
about the violation of sports principles’ and 
called on all parties to ‘resolve the injustice’, 
since 'there are better ways of reunification'. 
Possibly there were indeed other ways, but 
the letter was signed by people who con­
ceived the unification process in completely 
different ways, and it looked like an attempt 
to hinder this process.
At a press conference devoted to the 
opening of a stage of the FIDE Rapidplay 
Grand Prix (Moscow, 1-5 June 2002), I stated: 
‘Many of those who have signed this letter 
do not want any unification at all. Since it 
demands not only sacrifices, but also joint 
energetic work. Without the securing of a 
five-year calendar, and in particular money 
for 2003, we will not get anywhere. The 
enormous work which is now being carried 
out needs the support of grandmasters, and 
notits torpedoing!’
On this occasion I managed to concen­
trate on playing and I won this rapid knock­
out tournament, beating Ehlvest, Lautier 
(both 2-0), Grischuk (1V2-V2), Khalifman (l-l; 
1V2-V2) and, in the final, Radjabov (lyi-’/i). 
‘My immediate plans are associated with the 
world championship. I also intend to play for 
Russia in the Olympiad’, I stated at the 
concluding press conference. ‘But in general 
the year will be dominated by rapid chess: 
unfortunately, there are now no ‘classical’ 
tournaments left...’
Meanwhile, Kramnik’s friends, in confor­
mity with his aim of not playing a return 
match with me, organised a ‘qualifying 
cycle’, which now became part of the unifi­
cation plan. The ‘Einstein Group’ Candidates 
Tournament (Dortmund, 6-21 July 2002) was 
memorable for the absence of four favour­
ites, the participation of the ‘2600’ player 
Lutz and the ridiculous format. The eight 
grandmasters were divided into two double­
553

Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
round mini-groups, the top two players from 
each played semi-final mini-matches of four 
games, and the winners met in a final mini­
match. Success went to Peter Leko, who 
finished second in his group, but then beat 
Shirov and Topalov.
All these months I continued my involve­
ment in organizational work, and I held 
endless discussions, on which masses of 
energy were spent. Already then it became 
clear that all FIDE’s plans were ‘up in the air’. 
This hectic regime led to a disaster for me in 
the rapid match Russia vs. Rest of the World 
(Moscow, 8-11 September 2002). In each 
team there were ten players, who played 
each of the other team members on the 
Scheveningen system, and I scored just 4 out 
of 10! An unprecedented failure and with a 
nightmarish quality of play! Kramnik also 
did not distinguish himself (4 out of 9), and 
the Russian team lost 48-52.
After this serious failure I very much 
wanted to rehabilitate myself at the 2002 
Olympiad which began six weeks later in the 
Slovenian town of Bled, where unforgettable 
triumphs were achieved in their time by 
Alekhine (1931) and Tal (1961). Kramnik 
declined to play for the team - evidently he 
realised that, with my much higher rating, I 
was not going to concede board 1 to him.
On this occasion the Russian team did not 
have any great problems: nearly all played 
well, but especially Khalifman and I. At the 
start we crushed Costa Rica and Belarus (both 
3 V2-V2) - by tradition I did not play in the first 
round, but in the second I opened my account 
with a win. Here is what our team trainer 
Naum Rashkovsky wrote about this: 'Garry 
defeated Aleksandrov in simply classical style: 
his opponent did not even understand what 
had happened, with what strength of player 
he had encountered! He lost without a whim­
per, without making a single move that at
least somehow would have sharpened the 
play. After this game Kasparov was full of self- 
confidence. We all also breathed an obvious 
sign of relief, since in a team much depends on 
the form of the leader...'
In the third and fourth rounds we confi­
dently defeated India and Georgia (both 3-1), 
and I won, correspondingly, against Sasiki- 
ran and Mchedlishvili. 3 out of 3! In a diffi­
cult fifth round match with Armenia (2-2), I 
drew with Black against Akopian. Then 
without me Russia crushed Bosnia and 
Herzegovina - again S’/z-Vz!
After scoring 18V2 out of 24 we were lead­
ing the race by a margin of three points over 
our closest pursuers - the Hungarians. And 
it was they who proved to be our main rivals. 
We only needed to slow up slightly in 
matches with Poland (3-1; I beat Krasenkow) 
and Holland [2V2-1V2), for Hungary to win 
twice 3V2-V2 and reduce the deficit to one 
and a half points. And in the ninth round the 
Hungarians also beat us - 2Vi-lVi.
Playing Black against Leko (cf. Game 
No.93, note to White’s 9th move), I gradually 
gained the initiative, and had an enormous 
lead on the clock and a somewhat better 
endgame, but... With the score standing at 
1-1 Svidler suddenly made an incredible 
blunder of a pawn and lost, and I, on seeing 
this, became nervous, rushed things and 
first lost all my winning chances, and then 
blundered into a two-move fork. Fortu­
nately, in desperate time-trouble Leko 
missed a win, and two moves later we 
agreed a draw.
And so, Russia - 251/2 out of 36, Hungary - 
25. The battle for Olympiad ‘gold’ intensi­
fied! In the tenth round I won a tense Sicilian 
duel against Ye Jiangchuan, taking my score 
to 6 out of 7, while our team beat China (3-1) 
and increased the lead over the Hungarians 
to a point.

Life after Death
The destiny of first place was decided by 
the eleventh round, in which Hungary were 
paired against England and Russia against 
Germany. My opponent was the 31-year-old 
champion of the country Christopher Lutz, an 
outsider in the recent Candidates Tourna­
ment. Before this I had beaten him in Horgen 
(1994), and earlier in a simul’ against the 
West German national team (Came No.103), 
but Olympiad encounters are distinguished 
by their completely special intensity.

‘A splendid example of domination play’

This was my last, 50th win in Olympiads. 
Russia crushed Germany (3V2-V2), whereas 
Hungary beat England only by the minimum 
margin and three rounds before the finish 
they were now trailing us by two points.
In the 12th round we maintained the 
margin by beating Croatia (2V2-1V2). The 
13th round matches Russia-lsrael and 
Hungary-Armenia and the 14th round 
match Russia-Yugoslavia quickly ended in 
draws. My draw with Gelfand (cf. Came 
No.82, note to Black’s 9th move) produced 
the final score in our ‘classical’ meetings 
(+8=8) and also a pleasing result: by scoring 
7V2 out of 9 (+6=3), I stepped on to the 
Olympiad podium as the possessor of the 
highest performance (2933).
‘I can say that I was very happy to hold the 
gold medal in my hand. This is already the 
sixth victory for Russia in Olympiads and my
eighth’, I said at a concluding press confer­
ence in Bled. I made four appearances for 
the USSR and four for Russia, including six 
times on board 1, with an overall score of 
+50-3=29. After 2002 I did not play in the 
Olympiads, and in them Russia did not finish 
first for more than a decade...
The sham FIDE presidential elections, 
which took place at the Congress in Bled, 
were a pure formality: the Kirsan llyumzhi- 
nov team remained in charge. With the 
benefit of hindsight, I have to admit that 
Bessel Kok and I made a serious mistake, by 
going along with Seirawan’s tempting 
unification plan and concluding peace with 
llyumzhinov. It should have been foreseen 
that this plan would collapse, and a battle 
should have been begun for a change in the 
FIDE leadership. Kok should undoubtedly 
have been put forward for the post of presi­
dent: in 2002 llyumzhinov was weakened 
(his power base in Kalmykia had become 
shaky), and Bessel would have had excellent 
chances of winning. The 2006 attempt, alas, 
was too late...
Despite the Olympiad triumph, to some 
extent the departing year marked the end of 
my period of domination in the chess arena. 
This was confirmed in an exhibition match 
of four rapid Kasparov-Karpov games (New 
York, 19-20 December 2002), which I unex­
pectedly lost 1V2-2V2 (cf. Kasparov vs. Karpov 
1988-2009, 
Game 
Nos.48- 51), faltering 
under the burden of numerous problems. In 
particular, I was unnerved and kept in 
suspense by the unclear situation regarding 
my forthcoming match with the computer 
program Deep Junior. It was twice post­
poned, and it was only just before the start 
of the first game that llyumzhinov informed 
me by telephone that within a month the 
encounter with the machine would never­
theless take place.

Double-Round Tournament in Linares (21 
February - 9 March 2003): 1-2. Kramnik and 
Leko - 7 out of 12; 3-4. Kasparov and Anand 
- 6V2; 5. Ponomariov - 5V2; 6. Vallejo - 5; 7- 
Radjabov - 4V2.
Linares 2003 saw the meeting of all the 
participants in the expected Ponomariov- 
Kasparov and Kramnik-Leko matches, as well 
as Anand - the N0.3 in the world rating list 
and the winner of Wijk aan Zee 2003. 
Somewhat apart from this ensemble were 
two ‘2600’ players: the local representative 
Vallejo and the 15-year-old debutant Tei- 
mour Radjabov - the hope of Azerbaijan 
chess. And much depended on which of the 
favourites would score the most points 
against the outsiders.
I hardly prepared for this category 20 su­
per-tournament, which I played just two 
weeks after my ultra-tense New York match 
with the computer program Deep Junior (3- 
3) and experienced clear signs of nervous 
exhaustion.
David Lyada: ‘The anxiety for Kasparov be­
gan with the drawing of lots, when it tran­
spired that in the first round he would have 
Black against Kramnik. And the latter, figura­
tively speaking, is a kind ofthom in Kasparov’s 
flesh. And whereas before the drawing of lots 
Garry was very sociable and amiable, after it 
his face changed. Suddenly he became very 
serious, then he proceeded silently out of the 
Cervantes Theatre (where the opening cere­
mony took place) to the Hanibal Hotel, and, 
after giving his apologies, did not even show 
up for the ceremonial dinner. He went off to 
prepare for the game, and his mother asked 
for a meal to be brought to his room. The 
stellar duel between Kramnik and Kasparov 
turned out to be short... '
We continued our duel in the Queen’s
Gambit Accepted, begun more than two 
years earlier (1st match game (rapid), Mos­
cow 2001), and in a complicated, roughly 
equal position on the 18th move Kramnik 
offered a draw, which I accepted with alacrity.
In the second round I had White against 
Radjabov and, of course, I was not contem­
plating any result other than a win. I gained 
some advantage in a French Defence (cf. 
Game No.10, note to Black’s 7th move), but 
the position remained rather complicated. 
The critical moment arrived on move 21.

terrible time scramble he faltered, allowed
the powerful stroke 38...2xb3+! and suffered 
the loss of material.

After 1 e4 Vishy chose l...c6 2 d4 d5 3 £>d2

In turn, on the threshold of a draw in a 
straightforward rook endgame, Anand sud­
denly began to go wrong and after the fatal 
57-..4h8? he lost. This was my last win over 
Anand - later we played four more draws, 
making the final score of our ‘classical’ 
meetings +15-3=30 (in Linares.- +7=10).
For Vishy this game was a real tragedy 
and it ruined the entire tournament for him. 
I suspect that under its impression he later 
also lost a rook endgame against Leko. And 
yet initially he was playing better than 
anyone and could have taken first place - if I 
had not been in Linares...
And so, after the first cycle things did not 
look so bad for me: Kramnik - 4 out of 6; 
Kasparov, Leko and Anand - Vh. However, I 
drew all my games in the second cycle, 
although I fought as hard as I could. I had 
real winning chances only in. the penulti­
mate round with Vallejo, but I squandered 
them with time-trouble approaching. My 
fighting draw with Anand at the finish was 
also memorable: we were both half a point 
behind the leaders, and in an Accelerated 
Dragon I tried desperately but unsuccess­
fully to seize the initiative.
Despite everything, an interview I gave 
soon afterwards was full of optimism. ‘After 
my loss to Radjabov I set myself a minimum 
program: to win the tournament of the 
strongest players (i.e. without Radjabov and 
Vallejo). Against the main players I scored 
‘plus two’ and, despite bad luck, my ’border­
line’ condition and poor form, I finished just 
half a point behind first place, after missing 
much more. So perhaps things aren’t so 
bad? Is it not rather early for me to be buried 
- as usual, if I miss out on first prize - by 
some well-wishers?’
408

Life after Death
Linares 2003 brought to an end my long 
series of tournament victories. For me this 
was a warning before the planned match 
with Ponomariov: I needed to prepare more 
seriously and revise much anew. However, at 
the age of 40, and still irritatingly dependent 
on decisions of the FIDE board, it was far 
more difficult to reach a new peak.
Evgeny Bareev: To judge by this tourna­
ment (althoughpom it one cannot make any 
judgements) before his match Leko is in 
excellent form, and Kramnik is very strong. 
Whereas Kasparov and Ponomariov are in 
decline. But, remembering what an incredible 
surge he had eighteen months ago, Ruslan 
should be able to overcome the crisis and 
return to his peak form. And Carry too is 
quite capable of preparing brilliantly for an 
individual event and of returning to the 
proper level of his physical and psychological 
condition. There are two very interesting 
matches in prospect. In them the strongest 
players in the world are indeed coming 
together! Incidentally, at present Anand has 
no motivation, he is simply not interested in 
pghting, perhaps because he is not involved 
in this.’
Alas, my hopes of playing in the unifying 
cycle were not destined to be realised...
Instead of Yalta -  to Crete
European Club Cup (Rethymnon, 27 Sep­
tember - 4 October 2003): 1. NAO (Paris) - 13 
out of 14; 2. Polonia (Warsaw) and 3- Kiseljak 
(Bosnia) - 12; 4. Norilsk Nikel - 11; 5. Ladya 
Kazan-1000 (Kasparov - 4-V* out of 6) - 10, 
etc. (altogether - 45 teams).
Initially FIDE planned to hold my match 
with Ruslan Ponomariov in the summer of 
2003 in Buenos Aires, then from 18th Sep­
tember in Yalta, where a Commonwealth of 
Independent States summit was planned. It
was even announced that the symbolic first 
moves would be made for the players by the 
presidents of Russia and Ukraine.
However, Ponomariov was in no hurry to 
sign the match contract: together with his 
manager Silvio Danailov he put forward 
some twenty corrections, demanding that 
‘the lawful rights of the world champion 
should not be encroached upon’. Then the 
list of corrections was reduced to four. After 
accepting two of them, FIDE announced a 
final date for the signing of the contract - 
midday on 28 August. Ponomariov sug­
gested continuing the discussions in Kiev, 
but on 29 August the FIDE President llyumz- 
hinov suddenly held a press conference at 
the Interfax News Agency and cancelled the 
match. Here is an extract from the official 
press release:
‘FIDE shall not allow the selpshness of any 
one player to cause a hindrance to the unifi­
cation process... It is with deep regret that 
FIDE has to cancel the Ponomariov-Kasparov 
match. However, FIDE shall endeavour to 
proceed with the unification process. A 
proposal shall be placed to the forthcoming 
FIDE Congress in Halkidiki, Greece, 27 October 
- 3 November. The winner of the FIDE World 
Championship in December 2003 shall be 
crowned World Champion and he shall play 
Grandmaster Garry Kasparov next year. The 
winner of this match shall then play the final 
unification match.’
My reaction to the cancelling of the 
match was predictable: ‘The situation shocks 
me - I find myself in an idiotic position. I 
expected that my opponent would try my 
nerves, that provocations were possible, but 
I could not imagine that my opponent would 
simply escape! I have suffered serious moral 
damage, and, not unimportant, material 
damage, comparable to the prize fund of the 
match. For six months I have had to decline
409

Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
various invitations and I have invested a lot 
of time and money on preparing for the 
match with Ponomariov.’
My team of helpers comprised Dokhoian, 
Shakarov, Kobalia and, for the first time, 
grandmaster Viorel Bologan.
Later I said: ‘I should like to know who in 
fact wrecked this match. The Ukrainian side 
complicated the situation by raising obsta­
cles in the form of some ridiculous condi­
tions, and effectively the 19-year-old Po­
nomariov was a puppet in the hands of 
influential chess and political officials, while 
I was a hostage of their behind-the-scenes 
intrigues.’
It was rumoured that the Ponomariov 
team received part of the prize fund in 
advance, that the FIDE champion played 
poorly in training matches with Morozevich 
and Short (years later Nigel showed me one 
of the games from the match, which he lost 
SVi-A'A), and that either Danailov & Co., or 
the organisers, decided that it would be 
better not play Kasparov.
The curtain over the secret cancellation of 
the match could some day be opened by 
llyumzhinov himself, but we can only make 
conjectures. Here is the opinion of my oppo­
nent’s representative - Silvio Danailov, the 
current President of the European Chess 
Union:
7 
can firmly say that the Ukrainian side 
was not to blame: neither Ruslan, nor myself. 
It is quite inexplicable why FIDE fought so 
fiercely against our proposals. We had a very 
great desire to play the match. Who in fact 
wrecked it? It is very possible that something 
happened at a high political level in Russia. 
We all know who Kasparov constantly criti­
cises in his articles about politics... I think that 
Kasparov and llyumzhinov know perfectly 
well who in Russia wrecked the match and 
why.
'We have absolutely trustworthy informa­
tion that the day before the cancellation of 
the match Kasparov phoned llyumzhinov and 
said directly: “Accept all Ponomariov’s condi­
tions!" But the following day llyumzhinov 
cancelled the match. We watched his ap­
pearance on Russian television, and he looked 
terrible - it was obvious that for him this was 
a big blow. And one last thing: if Ruslan was 
to blame for everything, why didn’t FIDE 
apply any sanctions against him? The reply 
suggests itself... Of course, it is impossible to 
demonstrate anything.’
Apparently this was destined to happen: 
too many ‘interested persons’ - in both 
chess and in politics - did not want me to 
regain the title of world champion (try then 
getting it back!), llyumzhinov keenly sensed 
this mood, and in addition he has always 
been a faithful soldier of the Kremlin. The 
unification of the world championships took 
place, but only after I left the stage...
And so, in the autumn of. 2003, after my 
intense preparations, I suddenly found 
myself completely without any tourna­
ments. But here Bologan invited me to 
appear in the European Club Cup - to play 
on board 1 for the Kazan team Ladya, the 
2003 Russian champions. And I readily 
rushed into battle, without even signing a 
contract, but restricting myself to a verbal 
agreement with Kazan about payment for 
my participation. I simply needed to play 
chess somewhere!
After arriving beforehand with Dokhoian 
on the Greek island of Crete, we took up 
residence in the cosy village of Panormo, 
some 20 kms. from Rethymnon, where the 
Cup was being held. And on 23 September I 
played a short training match with Zurab 
Azmaiparashvili, at rapidplay (Game No.130) 
and blitz. The score: 2-0 and VA-'A.
The favourites for the European Club Cup

were NAO (Grischuk, Svidler, Adams, Lautier,

But, as often happens, life produced its 
changes.
For two-thirds of the tournament both my 
Ladya team and I myself played very success­

Belgian team, but it was led by quite a 
strong grandmaster, Vladimir Chuchelov, a 
former Muscovite, who had long been living 
in Belgium. The game took place exactly on 
his 34th birthday.

In the second round Ladya managed 
without me (6-0). In the third I won a good 
game against Jobava in a Caro-Kann with 3 
e5 ii-f5 4 ii.e3, after employing an important 
improvement (cf. Game No.129, note to 
Black’s 6th move). After a viscous positional 
struggle things again ended with a direct 
attack on the king.
As a result we defeated the young 
grandmaster team from Tbilisi [4V2-1V2), and 
the following day also Lentransgaz (4-2), 
when with unexpected ease I beat Konstan­
tin Sakaev with Black in a Slav (cf. Game 
No.97 in Part II of Garry Kasparov on Garry 
Kasparov, note to Black’s 10th move). Inci­
dentally, in the early 2000s for a time he 
took part in my preparations: I played some 
training games with him.
Thus I started with three wins. ‘Probably 
the 'highlight of the program’ was the appear­
ance of Kasparov’, Evgeny Atarov, the 64 cor­
respondent, shared his impressions. ‘It was 
evident that, after the forced break of six 
months, the thirteenth world champion had 
terribly missed playing and the tournament 
atmosphere. Even on his only free day Garry 
‘hungrily’ strolled between the boards - in 
dark glasses, hands in his pockets and noncha­
lantly chewing gum; he would glance at the 
score sheets and stand for a long time by 
positions that interested him. And he looked 
completely different - a genuine bird of prey, 
ready to tear its victim to pieces - on days 
when he was playing: the arbiters strictly 
ensured that the public did not crowd around 
the board at which Kasparov was playing... He 
arrived, as for any event that was important 
for him, with his team - trainer and family. 
And all the remaining stars were to some extent 
overshadowed by him. The hall was electrified 
by his presence - as soon as Kasparov finished 
his game, this intensity disappeared, and 
around they were only playing chess.’

Life after Death
After four rounds, having won all their 
matches, the leaders were Ladya (20'/i) and 
NAO (18V2). In view of the short tournament 
distance (just seven rounds), the central 
match between the leaders, which took 
place in the fifth round, could have been 
decisive. And it was a grandiose battle! I had 
White against Alexander Grischuk and 
towards the end of the first time control I 
held the initiative, but my team was losing 
1-2 (on board 2 Bologan lost to Svidler).
Atarov: 'Soon Smirin also appeared in the 
hotel foyer - he had drawn with Lautier and 
he sadly reported to Klara Shagenovna: "We 
would appear to be losing...” At this moment 
Kharlov had a difficult position against 
Vallejo, and even Kasparov's heroic efforts 
against Grischuk should not have been 
enough to save the match.
‘Fenced in by two rows of chairs against 
the spectators, who were pressing in from 
every side, Garry, as though in a cage, kept 
walking from comer to comer - from his 
board to Kharlov’s, from time to time wiping 
his brow with a handkerchief and rapaciously 
glancing first at Grischuk, and then at Vallejo. 
And here a minor miracle occurred, one of 
those that usually occurs with Kasparov: "He 
had nothing, but what a merry-go-round he 
has set in motion!" said the Belgian grand­
master Chuchelov in delight. “How he plays! It 
is something incredible...", those around 
whispered.’

(l-O). A tense battle and an impressive little 
finish! Despite the mistakes, this was one of 
my best games in the 21st century.
The scores became level, and a few min­
utes later Kharlov agreed a draw with 
Vallejo, making the result 3-3. Now the 
destiny of the cup would be decided by the 
two final rounds. But whereas NAO man­
aged to win both matches, Ladya stalled.
The next day we were unable to beat the 
Israeli team Beer Sheva - strangely enough, 
because of me. After four wins in a row, the 
last of which had taken a great deal of effort, 
my play suffered an obvious slump. I was 
desperately in need of a rest, but at the team 
meeting I heard: you have to play! And I went 
into battle, achieved an excellent position, 
and - committed a terrible blunder.

Had it not been for this catastrophe and 
the drawn match (3-3), we would still have 
been in the fight for first place... In the 
seventh, concluding round, Ladya also stood 
better, but we lost to Polonia (2-4), and I 
drew with Black against Ivanchuk (cf. Game

422

Life after Death
As a result we finished only fifth and in 
my six games I scored ‘plus three’. Not bad, 
but the bitter after-taste of my tragic blun­
der remained. ‘It will be interesting to see if 
conclusions will be drawn and will those, who 
financed the project, be able to find a ‘scape­
goat’for the poor performance of the team?', 
inquired the sports correspondent of the 
Respublika Tatarstan newspaper. Of course, 
a ‘scapegoat’ was found: the sponsors 
decided that since the team leader had not 
taken first place, it was altogether not 
necessary to pay him for appearing! Such 
are our Russian customs...
The FIDE Congress, which took place soon 
afterwards in Greece, moved the world 
knock-out championship to the second 
quarter of 2004 and selected as its venue the 
Libyan capital Tripoli (this immediately 
brought to mind the 1996 KaTpov-Kamsky 
match, which nearly took place in Baghdad). 
And I, awaiting a new match opponent, was 
again left in a suspended state. Kramnik and 
Leko were also not in a hurry to play their 
match, citing the lack of sponsors...
I concluded this extremely nervy year with 
another match against a chess program - 
Fritz X3D (New York, 11-18 November 2003), 
which also ended in a draw: 2-2. The historic 
moment was inevitably approaching, when 
it would become pointless even for world 
champions to fight against the computer.
Different Sorts of Draws
Double-Round Super-Toumament in Linares 
(18 February - 5 March 2004): 1. Kramnik - 7 
out of 12; 2-3. Kasparov and Leko - 61/2; 4-5. 
Radjabov and Topalov - 6; 6-7. Shirov and 
Vallejo - 5-
Failing to find an outlet for my efferves­
cent energy on the chess board, I again 
became involved in politics and I headed the 
Committee-2008 ‘Free Choice’, founded on
17 January 2004. For the whole year we 
made public statements about the current 
political situation and the need to unite 
democratic forces, and I made speeches 
about human rights and the character of 
political trials in Russia to the US Commis­
sion for security and collaboration in Europe 
and at the Baltic Development Forum in 
Hamburg. Then in December I took an active 
part in the organization of a Citizens’ Con­
gress ‘For democracy, against dictatorship’.
For the super-toumament in Linares in 
February 2004, which was of the usual cate­
gory 20, I was quite well prepared, but I did 
not play as successfully as I had hoped. What 
nevertheless told were my involvement in 
other matters, and my lengthy lack of prac­
tice. Strangely enough, my result was an 
exact copy of Linares 1998: eleven draws and 
just one win. Only on this occasion there was 
no Anand, the winner of Wijk aan Zee 2004: 
he supposedly was unable to come to an 
agreement with the organisers (the press 
wrote that he wanted to avoid meeting me).
But there are different sorts of draws, and 
if you look at some ten games of mine from 
this tournament, it can be seen with what 
passion I battled, trying to demonstrate that 
I was still the strongest player in the world.
In the first round I had another serious 
battle in the Najdorf with Alexey Shirov. As 
we took our seats at the board before the 
game, we sprung a little surprise on the 
spectators: for the first time after a three- 
year interval we shook hands.

The missed opportunity 3 l-'i,e3+! did 
not seriously spoil my mood. In the second 
round I was eager to ‘repay the debt’ to 
Radjabov for the previous year’s Linares
(Game No.87), and I reached a rook endgame 
with a powerful passed d-pawn and excel­
lent winning chances. But just before the 
control - in my opponent’s time-trouble! - I 
threw away the advantage with my ridicu­
lous 39th move. This draw was the first 
painful blow.
In the third round I had a very compli­
cated Najdorf in my game with Leko (cf. 
Game No.93, note to White’s 9th move). 
After a mistake on the 25th move I was on 
the verge of defeat and I saved myself only 
with a series of difficult moves. In the fourth 
round I was free, and in the fifth I was 
unable to achieve anything against Kramnik 
in a Queen’s Indian with a2-a3 (cf. Game 
No.lOl in Revolution in the 70s, note to 
Black’s 7th move). Then with Black I confi­
dently repelled Topalov’s attack in a Slav and 
with White I won a decent game against 
Vallejo in an Anti-Meran.
That same day Kramnik also scored his 
first win (against Topalov), and Leko his 
second (against Shirov). This unusually 
decisive round concluded the first cycle, 
after which the leading group was as fol­
lows: Leko - 4 out of 6; Kasparov and Kram­
nik - 31/2; Shirov - 3.
In my eighth round game with Shirov a 
rare misfire in my opening preparation 
occurred. In an ‘anti-Marshall’ with 8 h3 (cf. 
Game No.2, note to White’s 8th move), I 
decided to improve on a variation from my 
game with Kramnik (Linares 2003) and I 
played 19 £ih2, underestimating the simple 
equalizing reply 19...^xd5! (such inexplica­
ble ‘dead zones’ in analysis sometimes 
occur). After thinking for a whole 80 minutes 
(which had not happened since the 1987 
match), I made the poor move 20 £ig4?! and 
after 20...h5l I quickly ended up in a difficult 
position, lost a pawn and also used up 
nearly all my time! Fortunately, on the 27th

The next day I had Black against Radjabov. 
This was a festive Saturday - the Linares 
people were marking Andalucia Day, and 
there were many people in the hall. When 
Teimour played 1 e4, I hesitated for 10 
minutes while 1 assessed my playing condi­

preferred the solid l...e5. In a fashionable 
variation of the Scotch an equal endgame 
was quickly reached (cf. Game N0.65, note to 
Black’s 10th move). Then my young oppo­
nent gave up a pawn, and for a long time he 
had compensation for it, but immediately 
after the time control he began to ‘flounder’ 
and with his 45th move he made a serious 
mistake, after which my position became 
easily won.

After the shock I had experienced I

Last year this was sufficient for a share of first

In the 12th round, by a tradition estab­
lished in the 21st century, I employed 
against Kramnik the Queen’s Gambit Ac­
cepted. On the 7th move my opponent chose 
a variation with the exchange of queens, 
and already on the 17th move a draw was 
agreed.
And so, two rounds before the finish Leko 
and I were trailing Kramnik by half a point. 
In the 13th round Kramnik was free, Leko 
rattled off a 19-move draw with Vallejo, 
while I desperately threw myself with White 
against Veselin Topalov - I needed to win! In 
a Spanish ‘anti-Marshall’ I did not play 8 h3, 
as five rounds earlier against Shirov, but 8 
a4 (cf. Game No.2, note to Black’s 13th 
move), and I fought with all my might, 
endeavouring to change my fate.
By the 29th move I had less than ten min­
utes left, and on the board a storm was 
brewing: I concentrated nearly all my pieces 
against the black king, allowing my queen- 
side to be tom apart. When Topalov, true to 
his fighting style, replied with the counter­
thrust 29...f5?l, for the success of my attack I 
had to sacrifice a piece. My heart was 
thumping in my chest, pumping adrenalin 
around my body. I felt that a decisive blow 
was imminent, and that I only needed to 
give a discovered check. But where to move 
my knight - to e6 or to e4, forward or back?

After again missing a certain chance of 
catching the leader and at the least sharing 
victory in the tournament, I experienced a 
terrible vexation and disappointment. More 
than anything I was distressed by such a 
blunder in tactics, which had always been 
one of the strongest aspects of my play.
Nevertheless in the last round I chose 
against Vallejo the same complicated line of 
the Najdorf as against Leko (cf. Game No.93, 
note to White’s 9th move), doggedly tried to 
win and just before the first time control 
was close to my goal. But I squandered an 
obvious advantage, and the result was a 
draw on the 55th move, a long time after 
either Leko or Kramnik had been on the 
stage.
Nikolai Fuzik: 'A drawing epidemic struck 
practically all the competitors... The chess 
‘gods' suffered especially from short ‘grand­
master’ draws. In Linares 2004 the players
who flourished in this occupation were Leko 
and especially Kramnik. True, it was Kasparov 
who was credited with the greatest number 
of draws (ll). However, in his 12 games he 
made 470 moves (on average about 39 per 
game), whereas for Leko and Kramnik it was 
379 (32) and 321 (27) respectively. Moreover, 
Kasparov played only two games shorter than 
25 moves (with Leko and Kramnik), whereas 
Leko played 6 and Kramnik 7. 'Plus one’ is, of 
course, not the result that was expected of 
Kasparov, but he cannot be reproached for an 
unwillingness to fight.’
Sergey Shipov: ‘Kasparov's performance in 
Linares left mixed feelings. On the one hand, 
from the positions reached he could have 
achieved a decent plus score and first place. 
He fought and outplayed his opponents, 
demonstrating his former energy and asser­
tiveness. But only until the fourth hour! I 
think that he lacked concentration and his 
former confidence in his powers. Or perhaps 
he was simply unfortunate! One lucky win 
could have provided a new impulse for the 
next one. But as it was, losing one half point 
after another, Kasparov was not in the best 
frame of mind, which led to fresh losses. In his 
game with Topalov he attacked in his charac­
teristic style and was close to a win, and it 
was only his inner problems that prevented 
him from ‘not strongly, but accurately strik­
ing at the gates'. He confidently won such 
positions when he was a 13-year-old youth...'
After Linares 2004 my self-confidence was 
shaken, and I realised that the time had 
again come to readjust somehow. At the age 
of forty I was much older than most of my 
opponents, who were under thirty or even 
twenty. If age was beginning to affect my 
results and my tactical play was misfiring, 
how long could I remain at the top? I needed 
to thoroughly analyse all aspects of my 
game, and in particular my tactical vision.
431

Carry Kasparov on Carry Kasparov: Part Three
As later victories showed, I was still in 
quite good form, and in reality the problem 
was not the time-trouble mistakes them­
selves, but the fact that I was getting into 
time-trouble. At critical moments a lack of 
practice told. This manifested itself in inde­
cisiveness and a lack of trust in the accuracy 
of my calculations: precious minutes were 
wasted on re-checking variations, which 
should have been played very quickly. Time- 
trouble is a direct consequence of uncer­
tainty...
A couple of weeks after Linares I won, 
with a fair degree of luck, a rapidplay tour­
nament in Reykjavik, where for the first time 
I met the young Magnus Carlsen (Game 
No.131). And in the summer I took part in 
the Tigran Petrosian Memorial (Moscow, 
10-15 June 2004): a world team (Anand, 
Svidler, Adams, Bacrot, Vallejo and van Wely) 
played on the Scheveningen system with a 
Petrosian team (Kasparov, Leko, Gelfand, 
Akopian, Vaganian and Lputian).
At the start I beat van Wely, but that was 
all. The next day I employed the Sveshnikov 
Variation against Anand, and when instead 
of the canonical 10...f5 (Game N0.85) I chose
10...JLg7, 
grandmaster 
Sveshnikov 
ex­
claimed: ‘Wrong move!’. Here I could not 
refrain from responding: ‘What to do, life is 
difficult!’. In the end Vishy and I drew, I 
scored 3V2 out of 6, and the world team beat 
the Petrosian team lX'/i-lT'/i.
That same summer, after lengthy delays, 
the fifth FIDE world knock-out championship 
nevertheless took place in Tripoli. None of 
the previous winners (Karpov, Khalifman, 
Anand and Ponomariov) took part, nor did 
any of the first seven nominees for the 2003 
chess ‘Oscar’. The 24-year-old Uzbek grand­
master Rustam Kasimdzhanov became the 
new knock-out champion, after defeating 
Ivanchuk, Grischuk, Topalov and Adams
(true, all four only in the ‘rapid’ tie-breaks). 
However, it remained absolutely unclear 
when my match with Kasimdzhanov would 
take place, and this uncertainty played on 
my nerves.
In the autumn, having nothing else to do, 
I again played in the European Club Cup 
(Izmir, 2-9 October 2004), but this time for 
the Yekaterinburg ‘Max Ven’ team. After 
losing to my former Ladya team-mate 
Rublevsky, I won against Shirov, the leader of 
the Bosna Sarajevo team (this game pro­
duced a final score in our ‘classical’ games of 
+15=13) and made four draws - 3 out of 6. 
The results of the Cup: 1. NAO - 12 out of 14; 
2. Bosna, 3. Ladya and 4. Max Ven - 11.
Finally, on 13 October, just before the 
World Chess Olympiad and the FIDE Con­
gress in the Spanish town of Calvia, llyumz- 
hinov held a press conference in Moscow, at 
which he announced that the Kasim- 
dzhanov-Kasparov match would take place 
from 7 to 30 January 2005 in Dubai under 
the patronage of the UAE Ministry of De­
fence. The FIDE President confirmed that 
'this match will be held within the framework 
of the Prague Agreement’, and that "before 
the end of 2005 a unification match will take 
place - probably, also in Dubai’.
I couldn’t help thinking: a fresh commit­
ment, but one hard to believe... However, on 
15 October I was obliged to decline an 
invitation to Wijk aan Zee in January 2005, 
where I very much wanted to play after a 
three-year interval (I was replaced by Judit 
Polgar). And a week later I wrote to the FIDE 
Congress, mentioning a more realistic offer 
by the Turkish Chess Federation to take on 
the organisation of the Kasimdzhanov- 
Kasparov match. However, the Congress 
declined to consider this question, citing the 
absence of llyumzhinov.
Meanwhile, on 18 October the long-

awaited Kramnik-Leko match concluded. 
The champion retained his title with great 
difficulty: for almost half the distance 
Kramnik was losing ‘minus one’, and he 
levelled the scores only in the 14th, conclud­
ing game. Thus at least one of the two 
participants in the ephemeral unification

4 Vr, 11. Tseshkovsky - 2V2.
Against the background of the preceding 
failures and the agonisingly awaited match 
with Kasimdzhanov, my first Russian Cham­
pionship was exceptionally important for 
me: I needed to rehabilitate myself! In 
addition, I very much wanted to win in front 
of my eight-year-old son Vadik, so that the 
photographs and cups at home would be 
more meaningful to him. This was an old 
dream of mine - when at the opening of the 
super-toumament in Novgorod in 1997 I 
was asked what I still wanted to achieve in 
chess, I replied: ‘I want my six-month-old son 
to grow up and see me on the stage in the 
capacity of champion.’
Initially it was planned to hold a super- 
toumament with 14 players in which, for the 
first time in many years, all three Russian 
world champions would meet at the board - 
Karpov, Kasparov and Kramnik, as well as the 
former FIDE knock-out champion Khalifman. 
But before the start, as the 64 correspondent 
Vladimir Litus wittily expressed it, 'the players 
began disappearing, as in a well-known 
Agatha Christie novel (14... 13... 12... 11...), at 
the rate of roughly one person a day...’
The first to disappear was Kramnik, who 
reported that he had become unwell during 
his match with Leko and had not yet recov­
ered, as a result of which, on the insistence 
of his doctors, ‘he had to refrain from par­
ticipating in any competitions to the end of 
the year’. After this the executive committee 
of the Russian Chess Federation apparently 
considered the number ‘13’ to be unlucky: it 
reduced the number of players to 12, exclud­
ing one of those who had been personally 
invited - Khalifman! A third unpleasant 
surprise was sprung by Karpov: on 12 No­
vember together with me he took part in a 
press conference devoted to the forthcoming 
Russian Championship, but the next day he 
suddenly withdrew, citing other urgent 
matters... The Russian chess press even 
issued a call: ‘Take care of Kasparov!’
My task was made more difficult by the 
uneven line-up of this category 18 tourna­
ment, which strongly resembled Wijk aan 
Zee or Sarajevo: six rating favourites (Kas­
parov, Svidler, Morozevich, Grischuk, Bareev 
and Dreev) and some unpredictable ‘2600s’. 
Talented young players predominated - I 
was the second oldest competitor after the 
60-year-old Vitaly Tseshkovsky, twice a USSR 
champion.
We played in the very centre of Moscow, 
with a view of the Kremlin - in the main hall 
of one of the restaurants in the gigantic 
Russia Hotel. At one time I had lived there 
with my team for the five long months of my 
first match with Karpov... Soon this vivid 
symbol of the ‘developed socialism’ era was 
deemed to be severely dilapidated and in 
2006 it was demolished (like another historic 
chess hotel - the Sport, which was pulled 
down in the autumn of 2004).
In the first round I won a very nervy game 
with White against Bareev in a Caro-Kann 
with 4-..^.f5: I had a somewhat better end-
433

Carry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
game, and the turning-point occurred only 
in the time scramble before the first control. 
Then with Black I shared the point with 
Korotylev. In the third round I was free, and 
in the fourth I suffered a great disappoint­
ment in my game with Motylev. In an end­
game arising from the Petroff Defence (cf. 
Game No.82, note to White’s 16th move), 
towards the time scramble I outplayed my 
opponent literally out of nothing and seized 
the initiative. In search of counter-chances 
Black gave up the exchange and ended up in 
a hopeless position. I could have won several 
times, but after a blunder on the 66th move 
the game ended in a draw (which provoked, 
as far as I know, a mass of sarcastic com­
ments by my ‘well-wishing’ colleagues).
In the fifth round I had another draw in a 
tense battle with Epishin. My tournament 
position at the mid-distance did not inspire 
particular optimism (Grischuk and Dreev - 
3V2 out of 5; Kasparov and Timofeev - Vh 
out of 4), especially since the most difficult 
opponents were still to come.
The next day I had White against one of 
the leaders - the 35-year-old Moscow grand­
master Alexey Dreev, with whom in the 
1990s I had three times won Olympiad ‘gold’ 
for Russia. A win was desperately needed, 
and I decided to join battle in one of the 
main lines of the Slav Defence, regularly 
employed by Dreev.

9...±b7
A tabiya of the Anti-Moscow Gambit - 
virtually the most complicated and risky 
variation in modem chess.
Black is a pawn up, and for the moment 
he does not experience any particular prob­
lems. But in such positions White’s compen­
sation for the sacrificed material is not 
immediate, but long-term, strategic. He is 
inspired by the moves ...b7-b5 and ...g7-g5: 
pawns don’t move backwards, and it is not

Thus I reached the ‘plus two' mark and 
became one of the two leaders, having half a 
point less than Grischuk but a game in hand.
However, the win against Dreev had 
taken too much effort, and the following day 
I played appalling against Tseshkovsky, 
although the opening was one of my favour­
ite lines of the Sicilian (cf. Came No.37, note 
to White’s 12th move). I simply could not 
decide what to do: equalise or nevertheless 
play for a win? As a result I came under an 
attack and almost lost, but in his traditional 
desperate time-trouble Tseshkovsky threw 
away both his advantage, and a draw... This
439

Carry Kasparov on Carry Kasparov: Part Three
ultra-sharp duel became the turning-point 
of the entire championship!
Litus: ‘At the end of the game, that which 
had long been awaited in the press centre 
occurred. Kasparov came in and began 
commenting on the game. And he did this 
with such enthusiasm, energy and humour, 
that I suddenly sensed it was then that he 
gained his second wind. To all the questions 
the future Russian champion answered 
instantly and he gave an exhaustive reply 
with variations, the spectators listening with 
great interest. Kasparov was bursting with 
energy. Then Garry Kimovich went into the 
auditorium and with his colleagues he began 
discussing the remaining games, something 
he does very rarely.’
Of course, this smile of fortune increased 
my optimism. In the eighth round after 1 d4 
Svidler unexpectedly chose the Slav Defence 
- I...d5 2 c4 c6, and we went in for a rather 
rare set-up: 3 £ ic3 dxc4 4 e4 b5 5 a4 b4 6 
£ia2 £sf6 7 e5 £)d5 8 &xc4 e6 9 £)f3 &e7 10 
&.d2 as 11 £)cl £id7 12 £)b3. In this way I 
had once beaten Ivan Sokolov (Sarajevo 
1999), and now in a multi-piece endgame I 
also overcame Svidler.
That was not all, for in the ninth round I 
scored a fourth successive win - with Black 
against Timofeev, methodically outplaying 
him in a closed Sicilian. And, by reaching 6'A 
out of 8 ,1 moved a point ahead of my main 
rival - Grischuk, whom I had to play with 
Black in the last, eleventh round.
But in the tenth round I had White 
against Morozevich and after a highly origi­
nal opening I gained a big advantage, but 
then I stalled and was unable to break my 
opponent's tenacious resistance. That day I 
as though played two games, attentively 
following events on the adjacent board, 
where the important Korotylev-Grischuk 
game was taking place. In the end Grischuk
rather overrated his position, overstepped 
the mark and unexpectedly lost. Thus I now 
had a point and a half more than him and 
ahead of schedule I became Russian cham­
pion.
Nevertheless my finishing battle with 
Grischuk in a Najdorf (cf. Game N0.76, note 
to Black’s 10th move) was of a crucial nature 
and pleased the spectators. In a time scram­
ble I managed to hold a dangerous position, 
and I concluded the tournament without 
any mishaps, with a weighty ‘plus five’.
At the closing ceremony my son at last 
saw me being presented with a champion’s 
gold medal. He was with me and I happily 
hung the medal round his neck. It was joked 
that Vadik deserved it: every time he came to 
the tournament I was lucky... Suddenly the 
12th world champion, who had disappeared 
two weeks earlier, appeared on the stage to 
make the presentations, and he handed me 
a valuable prize - a chess set made out of 
mammoth ivory (!) in the ‘Karpov Workshop’.
The Russian ‘gold’ helped me to overcome 
the inner crisis and restore the confidence in 
my powers. For the first time I became sole 
champion of the country (in 1981 and 1988 
there was a share of lst-2nd places). The 
success was based on a certain adjustment 
to my playing style: now I expended my time 
more rationally and did not place such an 
emphasis on the opening, as in former 
times, but was ready for a prolonged battle 
in the middlegame and the endgame.
‘All year in tournaments I did not win 
more than one game, and here I scored five 
whole wins! The Russia Hotel very much 
helped me to prepare. Twenty years ago I 
came here, every day, standing at ‘minus 
five’ in my first match with Karpov. Now I 
have scored ‘plus five’ - as it is said, the 
angle of incidence is equal to the angle of 
reflection’, I stated in an interview under the
440

Life after Death
colourful headline ‘I have regained the right 
to vote’. And in another interview I added: 
‘Now I have nothing more to dream about: 
champion of Russia is the last title which 
was not in my collection.’
As for the match with Kasimdzhanov, 
even before the Russian Championship it 
was clear that in January 2005 it was not 
going to happen. And, indeed, soon an 
assistant of the FIDE President announced 
that the match was being postponed until 
the spring, since Dubai had not made finan­
cial guarantees, and that in the competition 
for the organizing countries it was possible 
that Turkey would take part. And llyumzhi- 
nov himself expressed the hope that 'in April 
when financial guarantees are made by the 
Turkish government the Kasimdzhanov- 
Kasparov match will take place, and at the 
end of 2005 its winner will play Kramnik.’.
However, I was no longer much bothered 
about the obvious sabotage of the Prague 
Agreement. The impasse in the battle for the 
world championship had brought me to the 
idea of ending my chess career.
Finishing Line
Double-Round Super-Toumament in Linares 
(22 February -10 March 2005): 1-2. Kasparov 
and Topalov - 8 out of 12; 3. Anand - 6V2; 4. 
Leko - 6; 5. Adams - 5!A; 6-7. Kasimdzhanov 
and Vallejo - 4.
Late in 2004 FIDE finally entered into dis­
cussions with the Turkish Chess Federation 
about the Kasimdzhanov-Kasparov match, 
planned for it to start on 25 April and asked 
for the necessary financial guarantees, with 
a deadline of 29 December. This date was 
later extended to 18 January, and in the 
middle of the month I was informed that the 
guarantees could not be made early than 25 
January.
After waiting so long for this match for 
the FIDE title an enormous fatigue and 
disillusionment 
had 
accumulated. 
My 
patience snapped, and on 18 January 2005 I 
declared that I was ceasing discussions and 
was opting out of the FIDE world champion­
ship cycle, as published in an open letter:
'In 2002 I joined with FIDE in Prague to try 
and unify the world championship. Over the 
past two and a half years, unification 
matches have been scheduled four times and 
each time the deadlines have come and gone 
while the financial guarantees were ignored.
‘Four times I have put my life on hold to 
schedule three months for preparation, play, 
and recuperation. The loss of earnings is easy 
to understand, but the hidden damage is 
psychological. These postponed and cancelled 
events have been deeply unsettling to me 
both professionally and personally. Our 
global chess federation has rarely thought 
enough to even keep me informed, let alone 
compensate me financially or even apologise 
for these repeated frustrations.
7 
called a halt to negotiations last night, 
but resentment at my treatment by FIDE has 
been building for the past three months. My 
life has been totally disrupted for two and a 
half years thanks to this on-again, off-again 
match and I must go on without this con­
stant interference.
‘Perhaps the last straw was watching the 
Corus tournament in Wijk aan Zee currently 
underway in the Netherlands. I was forced to 
give up my invitation to play in this event 
when FIDE insisted that the match would take 
place in Dubai on conflicting dates. It breaks 
my heart to watch such a great event from 
the sidelines. It hurts me, and I believe chess is 
poorly served as well...
‘As of today I have no contract with FIDE 
signed by either player, I have no financial 
guarantee, and 1 know from experience that
441

Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
drafting these documents can take consider­
able time...
‘It’s not about money or winning the title; 
it’s about my disillusionment with the process 
and the others on which it depends. In 2002 I 
dreamed of a legitimate chance to revive - 
and reclaim - the real world championship 
title. That no longer seems to be possible. Even 
if by some miracle the match is held and I 
win, I would bear a great deal of responsibil­
ity and still have no opportunity to unify the 
title. FIDE has proven itself incapable of the 
task while others are unwilling.
‘As for unification, I cannot see an avenue 
to contribute further. For those who saw me 
as an obstacle, I will be one no longer...'
At that moment I had not yet taken a final 
decision to leave the chess scene, but I felt 
very keenly that it was time to change my life. 
This decision began to crystallise after the 
cancellation of the match with Kasimdzhanov 
in Dubai, or more precisely, even slightly 
earlier, at the end of the Russian Champion­
ship, when a cherished dream was realised: 
my son saw a competitive triumph of mine 
with his own eyes. But in February, when I set 
off for Linares 2005,1 already knew definitely 
that this was my last tournament, and I 
accordingly tuned myself up psychologically.
I wanted to finish on a high note, espe­
cially since I had not won in Linares for two 
years, although I had fought with all my 
might. However, it was rather difficult to 
prepare for the tournament: mentally I had 
already embarked on a new path. Much time 
was take up by political battles within and 
around the Committee 2008. My personal 
life had also undergone a transformation: I 
had left my previous family situation and 
was planning to marry Daria Tarasova, a 
young girl from St. Petersburg (in June our 
wedding took place, and on 12 October 2006 
our daughter Aida was born). Nevertheless, I
needed to bring my chess career to a worthy 
finish, and 1 forced myself to get ready.
In Linares everything was as usual: cate­
gory 20, seven participants, two cycles. One 
debutant - the newly-fledged FIDE cham­
pion Kasimdzhanov. Of the favourites, the 
14th world champion Kramnik was missing 
- he had supposedly failed to come to an 
agreement with the organisers (or perhaps 
he had not yet recovered after Wijk aan Zee 
2005:1. Leko - 81/2 out of 13; 2. Anand - 8; 3- 
Topalov - 7I/2; 4-7. J.Polgar, Grischuk, Adams 
and Kramnik - 7).
I made a rather difficult start, and did not 
immediately warm up. In the first round 
Leko put pressure on my position in an 
English Attack (cf. Game N0.66, note to 
White’s 9th move), but he did not make use 
of all his chances - a draw on the 26th move. 
In the second round I now put pressure on 
Kasimdzhanov in a Petroff Defence (cf. Game 
No.82, note to Black's 14th move), but I was 
unable to convert an enormous advantage. 
Then, not without a degree of luck, I beat 
Vallejo with Black in a sharp variation of the 
Queen’s Gambit Accepted.
In the fourth round I was free, and in the 
fifth I met the persistent and cool-headed 
Michael Adams.

After this win I reached 3 out of 4 and 
took the lead, half a point ahead of Anand. In 
the meantime, on 27th February the FIDE 
Presidential Council took a decision which 
llyumzhinov was not afraid to call ‘historic’. 
Contrary to the Prague plan, FIDE tried to 
conclude the unification at one sweep - by 
contesting the title of world champion in a 
double-round tournament with the partici­
pation of Kramnik, Kasparov, Kasimdzhanov, 
Anand, Topalov, Leko, Adams and Moro- 
zevich. But, as expected, Kramnik refused to
446

Life after Death
play, while I was already living in another 
dimension, and we were replaced by Svidler 
and Judit Polgar.
This tournament, held in autumn 2005, 
was brilliantly won by Topalov. In 2006 the 
new FIDE champion played a match with 
Kramnik and lost on the tie-break. In 2007 a 
similar tournament was won by Anand, who 
in 2008 defeated Kramnik and became the 
15th world champion. Since then FIDE has 
reverted completely to matches for the title 
- but without me. The golden dream of the 
chess elite was realised!
I did not conclude the first cycle very well: 
against Anand in a Sveshnikov Variation (cf. 
Game No.49, note to White’s 15th move), I 
extricated myself literally by a miracle, and 
against Topalov I achieved nothing in an 
‘anti-Marshall’ (cf. Game No.2, note to White’s 
8th move). However, I remained leader: Kas­
parov - 4 out of 6; Anand and Topalov - 3V2.
The start of the second cycle was marked 
by a gripping duel with Leko. It appeared that 
I was taking the initiative, but Peter defended 
tenaciously (cf. Game No.100, note to White’s 
6th move) and gained a draw, which gave an 
overall score in our ‘classical’ meetings of 
+3=15. Incidentally, in this tournament Leko 
truly became the ‘drawing king’, all 12 of his 
games concluding peacefully!
In the ninth round I very much wanted to 
achieve that which I had failed to do in the 
second round: beat the FIDE champion 
Rustam Kasimdzhanov, my opponent in the 
wrecked match.

This spectacular win 'in the good old style’ 
added to my confidence and strength. The 
next day I won a rather tedious game 
against Vallejo, gradually outplaying him in 
a quiet Slav Defence. I now already had ‘plus 
four’, whereas Anand and Topalov were on 
‘plus one’.
In the llth  round I was free, and for the 
12th round, with Black against Michael 
Adams, I arrived in an elated mood, ready for 
new creative accomplishments.

It was a pity that the tournament did not 
conclude with this striking miniature. It was 
effectively already won: by scoring three 
successive wins and reaching 7Vi out of 10, 
two rounds before the finish I was one and a 
half points ahead of my nearest rivals - 
Anand and Topalov. It was them that I still 
had to play, but I had no mental strength left 
for a big effort, and also I was terribly op­
pressed by the thought that these were to be 
the last games in my professional career.
A draw with White against Anand would 
guarantee me first place even in the event of 
a loss in the last round, since I had more 
wins with Black - the tie-break which was 
known in advance. And I was unable to force 
myself to fight for a win in a Petroff Defence 
(cf. Game No.82, note to White’s 16th move), 
offering a draw practically without any play, 
something which I still regret. That day 
Topalov won with Black against Vallejo and 
was now just a point behind me.
And so, the concluding round, a game 
with the resurgent Veselin Topalov, who 
seven months later was to win the FIDE 
version of the world championship. To 
complete the historic picture, I decided also 
to annotate this dramatic game, despite the 
painful memories. Up to a certain point 
Black did not play badly...

A difficult, highly painful defeat - one 
wants to say undeserved, but it was defi­
nitely not accidental: my mind was already 
elsewhere. During play I couldn’t stop think­
ing about what words I would use to inform 
the public about the conclusion of my chess 
career, and as a result I cracked under the 
pressure.
But nevertheless I was awarded another 
model of the mining derrick - the traditional 
prize for the winner of Linares, this ‘chess 
Wimbledon’. From 1990 I took part in 14 of 
the 15 super-toumaments held here, win­
ning nine times, three times taking or 
sharing second place, and twice sharing 
third, with an overall score of+66 -7 =95.
That same evening, 10 March 2005, I ar­
ranged a press conference, at which I ‘sud­
denly’ announced my retirement from 
professional chess and my intention to 
concentrate both on writing and on social 
and political activity. In my mother’s eyes 
there were tears, and the assembled col­
leagues and journalists also did not hide 
their emotions. To a question, what had 
provoked this decision, I replied:
‘It’s very difficult to quote one reason. If I 
try I could tell you that as you know I am a 
man of big goals. I have to achieve some­
thing. I have to prove something. In Linares I 
wanted to prove for myself first of all that I 
play better than the others. I did. But I no 
longer see any real goal in the world of 
chess. The complete mess of the last two 
years added bit by bit to my frustration. 
What’s happened with FIDE in the past years 
was scandalous and I didn’t hear a single 
voice of concern or support for Gairy Kas­
parov.
‘After the Prague Agreement I had regular 
disappointments with the entire process, 
and this process was used for advancing the 
agenda of others, eventually at my expense... 
I recognise that in the nearest future there 
will be no chance for a reunified title and
458

Life after Death
frankly speaking there is nothing else I can 
hope for in the world of chess. I haven't lost 
my passion for chess, so maybe from time to 
time I could play for fun, definitely in some 
rapid tournaments. But it should be only for 
fun.’
And, indeed, why should I strain myself in 
tournaments, maintaining the No.l rating in 
the world, if the ‘higher powers’ had decided 
on no account to allow a return match with 
Kramnik? How long could I wait and endure 
this conspiracy of silence? 1 needed to move 
forward and concern myself with something 
else, seeing as there were numerous matters I 
was involved with. I have always thought that 
a person should aim for improvement and, as 
far as possible, change something in their life 
and their surroundings...
The era of confusion in the chess world, 
which began in 1993 after the withdrawal of 
Short and me from FIDE, entered a new phase 
from the late 1990s. The easy money, thrown 
by llyumzhinov at the knock-out tourna­
ments, enticed many grandmasters and 
undermined the historic tradition of world 
championships. True, within a few years it 
became apparent that the winners of the 
'knock-outs’ were not altogether genuine 
champions, and from 2005 FIDE nevertheless 
transformed these tournaments into the 
World Cup, switching to the contesting of the 
title in double-round super-tournaments and 
matches of 12 games, and, from 2008, finally 
only in matches.
In 1993,1 dreamed of uniting the ideas of 
the PCA and the GMA, their managerial and 
trades union functions. I hoped that Short 
would rally western grandmasters around 
the new project, but it quickly became clear 
that he did not enjoy sufficient prestige 
among them. Alas, under the fire of constant 
criticism it did not prove possible to create 
an efficient infrastructure, although in
1993-95 we found - for the only time in 
chess history! - a powerful corporate spon­
sor, and for the first time the leading 
grandmasters made proper eamings. But we 
were led down by a lack of solidarity.
When we signed the Prague Agreement in 
2002, Bessel Kok and I were hoping to im­
prove the working of FIDE from within (what 
optimism was displayed at that time can be 
seen in my introduction to Part I of My Great 
Predecessors)), but with llyumzhinov nothing 
came of this. On the contrary, for a long time 
this agreement delayed changes for the 
better in world chess. Thanks to it llyumzhi­
nov retained the post of FIDE President in 
the 2002 elections and he steers it to this 
day, Kramnik acquired the desired legiti­
macy without any particular obligations and 
striking competitive successes, while Kok 
and I suffered a major failure - and again 
zero solidarity!
The dismal state of world chess, the fact 
that it has effectively become the property of 
the capricious ruler of Kalmykia, is in my 
view a direct consequence of the fact that 
the breakthrough, prepared by the GMA in 
1990 and almost carried out by the PCA in 
1995, was not supported by the chess elite. 
They wanted also to be fed by FIDE, and in 
addition they were afraid of the ‘Kasparov 
dictatorship’. Thus a rare historic opportu­
nity was missed. It stands to reason that I 
bear the moral responsibility for this, but it 
should also be shared with those who cate­
gorically refused to support me and did 
everything possible to prevent the necessary 
changes.
Since 2005 I have not only been active in 
Russian politics, upholding the ideals of 
freedom and democracy. I have also had to 
earn a living, and I have been increasingly 
travelling round the world - for want of any 
eamings in Russia. Over a period of eight
459

Carry Kasparov on Carry Kasparov: Part Three
years I have given more than a hundred 
lectures and seminars on the theory of 
decision taking, at firms including Google, 
IBM, Facebook, General Electric and Fujitsu, 
in major banks, universities and at business 
conferences.
2007 saw the release of my book How Life 
Imitates Chess, which was published in more 
than twenty languages. In it I formulated my 
impressions of the mechanism of taking 
decisions, based on an analysis of my own 
chess experience. At that time the global 
consultants firm Creators Synectics included 
me in its list of 100 top living geniuses, and 
the magazine Time in its list of the 100 most 
influential people of the year. And recently I 
have been working intensively on a book 
devoted to current innovatory problems.
After I stopped playing in official events I 
did not disappear from chess life. I contin­
ued playing blitz on the internet, giving 
simultaneous 
displays 
and 
attentively 
following the development of chess theory. 
In 2006 the publication of the five-volume 
My Great Predecessors was completed, and 
after it there followed Revolution in the 70s 
(2007), three volumes (2008-2010) of my 
complete games with Anatoly Karpov, and 
the three-volume auto-biographical Garry 
Kasparov on Garry Kasparov (2011-2014).
I have worked much and I continue to 
work on the advancement of chess in gen­
eral education schools throughout the 
world, constantly expanding the activities of 
the Kasparov Chess Fund, set up back in
2002 in the USA. In 2011 a European branch 
of the fund was set up, and together with 
the European Chess Union it carried out a 
highly successful campaign in the European 
Parliament to gather the signatures of MEPs 
to support the ‘Chess in Schools’ program. In 
the same year, 2012, an African branch of 
the fund was opened in South Africa.
From time to time I have worked on chess 
with the young stars - Carlsen, Nakamura, 
Giri... I have also played a little myself: in 
2006 I shared first place with Karpov in a 
small blitz tournament, in 2009 I won a 
‘nostalgic’ rapid and blitz match against him 
(cf. Kasparov vs. Karpov 1988-2009), and I 
beat Short ryh-Vh in a blitz match (Leuven, 9 
October 2011).
In 2010 I actively supported my former 
opponent at the chess board, Anatoly Kar­
pov, in the FIDE presidential elections. Kar­
pov proposed a wide-ranging program of 
reform of Russian and world chess. However, 
the Kremlin, as well as the leaders of. the 
Russian Chess Federation, gave preference to 
the ‘old-timer’ llyumzhinov, well known not 
only for his chess and corruption scandals - 
but also his contacts with aliens!
Before the 2014 elections, after talking to 
many people throughout the world, I came 
to the conclusion that, using my experience 
of political battles and many years of fight­
ing for the highest achievements in sport, I 
myself should try and change for the better 
the situation in the chess world, and I de­
cided to stand for the post of FIDE President.
460

Life after Death
Chapter Four
Experiments
Simuls’ against Professionals
As has already been mentioned, throughout 
my chess career I have aimed for unexplored 
experiroents and I have tirelessly blazed new 
trails. Thus in 1996 and 1997 I conducted an 
unprecedented experiment ‘man against 
machine’ - two matches with the super­
computer Deep Blue. And even earlier I was 
the first in the world to began giving simul­
taneous displays with clocks against masters 
and grandmasters - entire Olympiad teams 
from various countries! The current section 
is about these displays.
But first, about the history preceding 
them. Simuls’ with clocks were practised in 
the USSR, and I acquired my first, priceless 
experience back in childhood, at two all- 
union tournaments of pioneers palaces 
(1974 and 1975), where teams of seven 
juniors played in simuls’ against grandmas­
ters - the captains of the opposing teams (cf. 
Part I of Cany Kasparov on Carry Kasparov). 
Later I also gained experience in giving 
simuls’: three times at these tournaments I 
was the captain of the Baku team and each 
time I gave five simuls’. The games were not
preserved, which is a pity: among my oppo­
nents were Khalifman, Epishin, Naumkin 
and other future grandmasters. But I re­
member the results: +26=9 (1981), +27-2=6 
(1985) and +30-1=4 (1987).
Also memorable was the first simultane­
ous display in history where the moves were 
transmitted through space by satellite. This 
was on 30 June 1984. Play was on ten 
boards: I and the five best English juniors 
were in London, and the five best Americans 
in New York. Although four of my opponents
- Adams, Conquest, Ilya Gurevich and Wolff
- were future grandmasters, I won +7=3 (the 
best game was No.93 in Part I of Garry 
Kasparov on Garry Kasparov). There was 
almost the same result in another ‘cosmic’ 
simul’, against ten players who were on five 
continents - in the USSR, USA, Canada, 
England, Belgium, Italy, Switzerland, Austra­
lia, Japan and Senegal: +8-1=1 (a loss to 
Adams and a draw with Ulibin).
From London 1984 I set off to pick up an­
other chess ‘Oscar’ in Barcelona, where I 
gave a simul’ against seven solid Spaniards: 
+3=4 (among those I beat was lllescas). And
461

Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
in December 1985, immediately after my 
unofficial match with Timman (cf. Part II of 
Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov), for the 
first time I took on a professional team in a 
simul’. I was opposed by the Hamburg club 
from the West German Bundesliga, beaded 
by grandmaster Chandler. Before this I bad a 
sleepless night, a two-bour press conference 
in Amsterdam and the flight to Hamburg. I 
began the simul’ just two hours after land­
ing and snatching a meal - I didn’t even 
have time to draw breath!
To this day I remembeT the ironically scep­
tical smiles of the German public: the things 
that the young wotM champion would do in 
OTder to popularise chess. My opponents 
were Teady to play Black on all eight boards, 
and my offer to give them the white pieces 
on four was greeted with joyful surprise. In 
the end I managed to win just one game 
with White, and one, - a memorable one - 
with Black.

But in the other ‘black’ games I lost (in­
cluding to Chandler and Wahls) and for the 
only time over all the years I was defeated in 
a simul’: 3V2-4V2 (+2-3=3).
This severe test taught me an excellent 
lesson: I realised that such simuls’ de­
manded serious preparation! The main 
reason for my failure was not so much
463

Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
exhaustion, but rather a complete lack of 
information about my opponents, which 
prevented me from exploiting their weak 
points. Appreciating this, I aimed for re­
venge, and all the subsequent events con­
firmed the correctness of my diagnosis.
I obtained additional practice at simulta­
neous displays with clocks in 1986-87, at 
sessions of the Botvinnik-Kasparov school. 
These were both good training, and a sure 
way of studying live the pupils’ styles, in 
order to later work on eliminating their 
deficiencies. The simuls’ on five or six boards 
were notable for the strength of the line-up: 
among those playing, already at the master 
level, were the young Kramnik, Shirov, 
Akopian, Tiviakov, Sakaev, Rublevsky, Ulibin, 
Alterman, Serper, Landa, Oratovsky, Gallia- 
mova... Altogether I played 56 simul’ games 
here, of which I won the majority, and lost, 
at different times, only two (to Landa and 
Oratovsky - not the most dangerous of the 
opponents).
Unfortunately, I have not kept the scores 
of these fighting encounters, which were of 
undoubted value for chess. I will give one of 
the rare games that was published - with 
the 14-year-old Vladimir Akopian, played at 
the first session of the school. In that very 
first simul’ which, to the astonishment of my 
young opponents and their trainers, con­
cluded with the score 6-0.

Developing the correct strategy for this 
simul’ was helped by competent preparation 
- a study of my future opponents’ games. 
This success made me more confident that 
in this way I would also subsequently be able 
to impose ‘my play’ on my simul' opponents 
and take them away from those positions in 
which they felt comfortable.
And, indeed, in February 1987 I gained 
more than convincing revenge against 
Hamburg: 7-1 (+6=2). On this occasion 
Chandler was not competing, but the aver­
age rating of the team had increased and in

opening set-ups which I was then preparing 
for world championship matches. In particu­

against the 19-year-old Matthias Wahls.

An unshowy positional masterpiece ‘in 
Petrosian style’.
After this triumph I decided to take on 
national teams, and for a starter in May 
1987 I cmshed the Swiss team 5'A-'A - 
without Korchnoi, but with six international 
masters. It was before that simul’ that I first 
got my hands on a powerful weapon for 
purposeful preparation - the program 
ChessBase, which already then had an enor­
mous database of games. From then on I 
could efficiently and conveniently study the 
play of my opponents, in order then to 
exploit their weak points.
Inspired by these new feats, in December
1988 in the Parisian suburb of Evny I de­
feated the French team ip/i-l'/i (+4-1=1). 
True, not in the team were one of its leaders, 
Renet, or the 15-year-old Lautier, the 1988 
world junior champion, and on board 6 
there was a local club player. Therefore the 
score did not satisfy either me (I was vexed 
by my loss to Sharif), or the French: they 
thought that with a stronger line-up their 
chances would have been by no means 
worse.
And in June 1989 a ‘return match’ took 
place in Evny - a repeat clock simul’ against 
the French national team. Playing now were 
not only Bachar Kouatly, but also Olivier 
Renet (instead of the club player), and they 
held a short training session, with the role of 
team mentor performed by none other than 
Boris Spassky! However, I won by the same 
score A'/i-l'/t (+3=3), beating Renet with 
White and Kouatly with Black, although this 
gripping encounter did not take an easy 
course.
