This was also a notable event: after this 
simul’ I realised that I could compete success­
fully against the strongest national teams. 
The way was open to even more serious tests, 
but in the next couple of years I had no time 
for simuls’ against professionals.
471

Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov: Part Three
On 19th January 1992 I finally made the 
next step: in Baden-Baden I played against 
the German team. For the first time four 
grandmasters played simultaneously against 
me - Hort, Wahls, Lobron and Hertneck. At a 
press conference before the start I said that I 
had analysed 900 games of my opponents!
The display took place in the presence of 
1,500 spectators and was broadcast on TV. 
The prize for a winner was a BMW car, but a 
loser received nothing. The tension was 
enormous, but I managed to withstand it, by 
accurately carrying out my own aim of 
quickly making two draws and concentrating 
on the two remaining games. As a result I 
beat Wahls with White, and, with the score 
standing at 2-1, in time-trouble Lobron 
missed a draw by grabbing a poisoned pawn. 
My confident 3-1 win provoked a furore.
In the autumn of that same year I played a 
simul’ against the Argentine national team 
headed by Panno. In general this team was 
weaker than the German one, but we played 
on six boards and in two rounds - with White 
and Black. I won the first round 4-2, losing 
one game - against Ricardi, then in the second 
round I gained revenge against him and won 
5-1. The overall score was 9-3 (+7-1=4).
After an interval of more than three years 
I again found time for clock simuls’. In 
January 1996 in Rio de Janeiro I won against 
the Brazilian national team headed by Milos 
- 5-1 (+4=2). And in September 1997 there 
came a return match with Argentina. I 
remember that at the start of the display I 
was very nervous: sitting opposite me there 
were now five grandmasters (Panno, Ricardi, 
Spangenberg, Zamicki and Sorin), and it was 
not easy to keep firm control simultaneously 
on six boards. But it all ended well: 4V1-1V1 
in the first round and 4-2 in the second, with 
one defeat - at the hands of Spangenberg. 
The overall score was 8V2-3V2 (+6-1=5).
In the first round game with the legen­
dary Oscar Panno I had the good fortune to 
employ a very interesting novelty.

then <if2, g2-g3, £kl4 and wins.
35 e4 i.b7 36 &e3 -&c6 37 £>f5 -&xe4 38 g4!
Panno overlooked this resource. Black re­
signed (l-O).
In May 1998 I achieved my greatest suc­
cess in such displays, crushing the Israeli 
Olympiad team. This double-round match 
simul’ took place in Tel Aviv and was the 
major event in a grand chess festival, timed 
to coincide with the anniversary of the local 
Kasparov Chess Academy and 50 years since 
the founding of the Israeli state.
The young Israeli team was even stronger 
than the German one: I was opposed by four 
‘2600’ grandmasters at the height of their 
powers - Alterman, Huzman, Smirin and
474

Experiments
Sutovsky (moreover, a rating of 2600 at the 
end of the last century was far more impres­
sive than it is today). Of course, they were 
eager to demonstrate that my ambitions 
were beyond the bounds of possibility. 
Makarychev: ‘And on the first day their open­
ing play was simply exemplary: they obtained 
three very complicated positions, in one of 
which Smirin began outplaying his formidable 
opponent with Black!’
Before this I had twice played Ilya Smirin 
one to one (Game No.42 in Part II of Garry 
Kasparov on Garry Kasparov and Game 
No.32). Our third game also turned out to be 
very publishable.

38 #e6+ Sf7 39 # e 8+ V i-'/i
An entertaining battle!
Makarychev: ‘After getting rid of this mill­
stone around his neck and conceding another 
half point to Alterman, Carry began playing 
with inspiration: with Black he converted a 
positional advantage against Sutovsky and 
he outplayed Huzman literally out of noth­
ing.’ The result of the first day was 3-1. My 
opponents were depressed, but nevertheless 
Smirin said: 'Never mind, tomorrow is an­
other day...’
But the next day brought the Israeli team 
even greater disillusionment - an incredible 
4-0! All the games were interesting, includ­
ing duels with White against Huzman in a 
Najdorf (cf. Game No.45, note to Black’s 12th 
move) and with Black against Alterman in a 
Queen’s Gambit (cf. Game No.96 in Part II of 
Garry Kasparov on Garry Kasparov, note to 
White’s 10th move). At the end of the dis­
play, which I won with the overall score 7-1 
(+6=2), Alterman said: ‘Either we don’t 
understand anything about this game, or we 
weren’t playing a human being.’
In October 20011 faced my last such test - 
a double-round simul’ in Prague against the 
Czech national team, organised by Bessel Kok. 
Again sitting opposite me were young, ambi­
tious grandmasters - Movsesian (2631), 
Hracek (2610), Babula (2566) and Oral (2546). 
Also a serious, solid team!
Sergey Movsesian had ‘old scores’ to settle 
with me (cf. Game N0.66), and I devoted 
particular attention to the games with him. 
After 1 e4 c5 2 £sf3 my opponent chose the
Paulsen Variation (cf. Game No.107, note to 
Black’s 5th move), and after a couple of 
incautious moves he came under a crushing 
attack.

On the second day my opponents were 
eager to get even, and the games took a very 
tense course. The encounter with Tomas 
Oral became especially crucial for me.

Over a period of 14 years I played 11 
simuls’ against the national teams of nine 
countries and I concluded the history of 
these battles on a high note.
Quickly, even more Quickly...
Finally, here is a brief review of my achieve­
ments in rapidplay and blitz. First I must 
mention a friendly blitz match with Tal 
(Tbilisi, 27 December 1978), which ended in 
a 7-7 draw, and a very strong double-round 
blitz tournament (Herceg Novi, 14 Septem­
ber 1983): 1. Kasparov - 131/2 out of 16; 2. 
Korchnoi - IOI/2; 3. Tal - 9V2; 4. Ljubojevic - 
8I/2; 5- Timman - 8; 6. Spassky -  7; 7. Sax -  6; 
8. Larsen - 5I/2; 9. Ivanovic - 3Vi.
My rapidplay match with Short (London, 
4-5 February 1987), which I won 4-2 (+4-2), 
was the first to be broadcast on TV and 
heralded the further flourishing of ‘rapid’.

I have pleasant memories of Paris, where I 
took first place in four out of five Tapid 
knock-out tournaments. In the first Immo- 
par Cup (1990), I beat Speelman (l'A-'A), 
Korchnoi (l-l; 2-1) and Short (l-l; 1-0), in the

the PCA/Intel Grand Prix. In 1994 I beat 
ATbakov (2-0), Hjartarson (2-0), KTamnik (l-l;

cided by the semi-final tie-bTeak game with

Of the ten rapid PCA knock-out tourna­
ments, held in 1994-1996, three were won 
by me, two each by Kramnik, Anand and 
Ivanchuk, and one by Adams (in London 
1995, where I did not play).
The blitz match with Kramnik in the ca­
sino of the Cosmos Hotel (Moscow, 1998) 
was the first chess event to be broadcast on 
the internet. This fascinating clash ended in 
a 12-12 draw (+7-7=10), with the scales 
tipping first one way and then the other.
